Speaker: NA
Text: Wednesday, Sth Deceniber 1965.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. Sir John MCLeay)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read

Speaker: NA
Text: prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: PENSIONS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr LINDSAY presented a petition from

Speaker: NA
Text: certain electors of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: praying that the Parliament will amend the

Speaker: NA
Text: social services legislation to give an imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diate increase in the basic pension rate paid

Speaker: NA
Text: to all social service pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: BOOKLET ON VIETNAM.

Speaker: Mr GALVIN
Text: I ask the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter a question. Is he aware that the South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Minister for Education has

Speaker: NA
Text: stated that he has requested school teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: in South Australia not to use the booklet

Speaker: NA
Text: on Vietnam issued by the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: External Affairs until he has had time to

Speaker: NA
Text: examine it? Will the Prime Minister give an

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance that no more of these booklets

Speaker: NA
Text: will go to South Australia until the wishes

Speaker: NA
Text: of the South Australian Minister for Educa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion are known? Further, before sending

Speaker: NA
Text: these booklets to other States will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister consult with State Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: for Education?

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: Ther e is no

Speaker: NA
Text: obligation on any teacher to use this booklet

Speaker: NA
Text: or to discuss it with his pupils. The booklet

Speaker: NA
Text: is designed to inform headmasters of

Speaker: NA
Text: schools, clergymen and various social and

Speaker: NA
Text: other leaders in the community. I would be

Speaker: NA
Text: surprised to know that we cannot distribute

Speaker: NA
Text: a piece of literature relating to a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: within our jurisdiction without the consent

Speaker: NA
Text: of a State Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Courtnay -Sen d them the Vernon

Speaker: NA
Text: report.

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: Tha t is not a

Speaker: NA
Text: bad idea.

Speaker: NA
Text: SHIPPING.

Speaker: Mr HAWORTH
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service a question

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the hold up of the tanker

Speaker: NA
Text: "Oceanic Grandeur" by members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Seamen's Union. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged that the hold up is due to a broken

Speaker: NA
Text: implied agreement between Ampol Petro-

Speaker: NA
Text: leum Ltd. and the Seamen's Union to man

Speaker: NA
Text: the " P. J. Adams" with an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: crew after the company had been granted

Speaker: NA
Text: a subsidy of Â£1 million by the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. Is this claim correct? If not,

Speaker: NA
Text: what is the reason for this precipitate action

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition. by the Australian Seamen's Union?

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: The " Oceanic

Speaker: NA
Text: Grandeur " has been held up in Moreton

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay by the tugboat employees' organisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I am not certain whether members of that

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation are members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Seamen's Union. The alleged ground for

Speaker: NA
Text: the hold up is that a verbal agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Ampol company and the tug-

Speaker: NA
Text: boat employees has not been observed. In

Speaker: NA
Text: order to prevent this hold up continuing

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been in close consultation with

Speaker: NA
Text: our colleagues in Queensland. I have ascer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained that the tugboat employees' organi-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation is not here operating under the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act

Speaker: NA
Text: but comes within the jurisdiction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Industrial Commission. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland authorities have informed my

Speaker: NA
Text: Department today that the matter will imme-

Speaker: NA
Text: diately come before Mr Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: Harvey. It is hoped that very shortly he will

Speaker: NA
Text: bc able to call the parties together with a

Speaker: NA
Text: view to resolving the dispute quickly.

Speaker: NA
Text: IMMIGRATION.

Speaker: Mr SEXTON
Text: M y question is directed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Immigration. Can he

Speaker: NA
Text: tell the House why 4,000 migrants- a

Speaker: NA
Text: record number-lef t Australia during the

Speaker: NA
Text: September quarter? Can he say what the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of these unsatisfied migrants will cost

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia?

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber's question covers a very wide subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: Actually, migrants are reaching Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in record numbers. More migrants are

Speaker: NA
Text: coming here now than have ever come

Speaker: NA
Text: before and naturally the number of those

Speaker: NA
Text: leaving Australia will be higher than it was

Speaker: NA
Text: before. However, the proportion of those

Speaker: NA
Text: returning overseas, related to the total num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber arriving in Australia, remains much

Speaker: NA
Text: the same. Economic conditions overseas are

Speaker: NA
Text: now much better than they were in the days

Speaker: NA
Text: gone by and migrants who believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: they will be able to get employment that

Speaker: NA
Text: they were denied before are attracted to

Speaker: NA
Text: return to their homelands. This emphasises

Speaker: NA
Text: the point that I made when I returned from

Speaker: NA
Text: my recent trip. I said then that we will have

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing difficulty in attracting migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia because conditions overseas are

Speaker: NA
Text: improving. However, that does not alter

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that good advertising overseas and

Speaker: NA
Text: the efforts of our dedicated representatives,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are responsible for implementing our

Speaker: NA
Text: migration scheme, have resulted in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving a record number of migrants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of the migrants who leave Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: do not do so because they are dissatisfied.

Speaker: NA
Text: Domestic affairs cause some migrants to

Speaker: NA
Text: return to their homelands. In addition, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is a country with a high level of

Speaker: NA
Text: wages and migrants can save their fares to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back to the countries of their birth. This

Speaker: NA
Text: means that we in Australia should use our

Speaker: NA
Text: best efforts to satisfy the needs of migrants.

Speaker: NA
Text: But no country in the world has a better

Speaker: NA
Text: understanding of these needs than Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: has and no country gives migrants the wel-

Speaker: NA
Text: come that Australia gives. We have Good

Speaker: NA
Text: Neighbour Councils, Bring Out a Briton

Speaker: NA
Text: associations and churches all working to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the lot of the migrants here.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although the honorable member may feel

Speaker: NA
Text: that the number of migrants leaving Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia is large, Australia has the lowest

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of return of any immigration country.

Speaker: NA
Text: One country that is competing with us has

Speaker: NA
Text: a rate of return of 30 per cent.; our rate is

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent, or so. In addition, 60 per

Speaker: NA
Text: of migrants who return to their homelands

Speaker: NA
Text: want to come back to Australia.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Immigration a supplementary question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Admitting the truth of all that he has said

Speaker: NA
Text: about the success of our immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: policy in attracting and holding migrants,

Speaker: NA
Text: will the Minister investigate the possibility

Speaker: NA
Text: of retaining some of those who want to go

Speaker: NA
Text: back and of attracting more by asking

Speaker: NA
Text: colleagues to provide houses in advance

Speaker: NA
Text: for migrants who wish to come here, after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has provided houses for to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians who wish to marry and for those

Speaker: NA
Text: who cannot obtain houses today?

Speaker: Mr OPPERMAN
Text: Th e honorable memused

Speaker: NA
Text: ber raises a matter of policy that is not

Speaker: NA
Text: directly related to immigration. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: point out that we have hostels for migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: who come here. Similar hostels are not

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in other countries. Many migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: in hostels are quite happy to be tbere. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has a scheme of hostel subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: which allows migrants to save for the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of buying a house. We have always

Speaker: NA
Text: stressed the need to have sponsored migra-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to Australia. In this scheme, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsor would have accommodation ready

Speaker: NA
Text: for the migrant. I repeat what I said recently

Speaker: NA
Text: in answer to a question. The Liberal Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment that was in office in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia for a long time developed an excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: housing scheme and that State provided

Speaker: NA
Text: more personal nominations for migrants

Speaker: NA
Text: than did any other State. I add that the

Speaker: NA
Text: length of the stay in migrant hostels has

Speaker: NA
Text: fallen from the original average of two

Speaker: NA
Text: years to an average now of eight months.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would suggest that there has been an

Speaker: NA
Text: improvement in housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: HOUSING FINANCE.

Speaker: Sir JOHN CRAMER
Text: My question is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed to the Treasurer. In recent

Speaker: NA
Text: announcements of additional finance being

Speaker: NA
Text: made available for housing, emphasis was'

Speaker: NA
Text: given to loans for new housing to stimulate

Speaker: NA
Text: the building industry. No mention was made

Speaker: NA
Text: of the need forfinancefor the purchase of

Speaker: NA
Text: existing and older homes. Is the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that the maximum stimulus is given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the building industry if finance is made

Speaker: NA
Text: available without discrimination between

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, new or old homes, or between existing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes or homes to be built? Will he see to

Speaker: NA
Text: it that this economic fact is fully under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood by Treasury officials and those dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with housing finance?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Lik e others in

Speaker: NA
Text: the House I respect the particular know-

Speaker: NA
Text: ledge which the honorable gentleman has of

Speaker: NA
Text: the housing industry. He speaks with some

Speaker: NA
Text: authority on these matters, lt is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: his in the announcement made recently the

Speaker: NA
Text: Governor of the Reserve Bank said that in

Speaker: NA
Text: approaching savings banks and proposing

Speaker: NA
Text: them that they increase their current high

Speaker: NA
Text: level of lending for housing purposes he

Speaker: NA
Text: had suggested that the increased lending

Speaker: NA
Text: should preferably be for new rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: houses. I think the objective was to

Speaker: NA
Text: give some quick stimulus to new building

Speaker: NA
Text: I in view of a situation in which there had

Speaker: NA
Text: been some decline from the level of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction in an earlier period of the year.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the honorable gentleman points out, it

Speaker: NA
Text: may be that we could well achieve a some-

Speaker: NA
Text: what similar result if finance went to a

Speaker: NA
Text: person who sells a house and with the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceeds of that sale sets about building a new

Speaker: NA
Text: home. But usually there is involved in this

Speaker: NA
Text: a lag sufficiently long for the bank

Speaker: NA
Text: to have taken the view that in present cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances the quick response looked for

Speaker: NA
Text: could be got more realistically by lending

Speaker: NA
Text: for new housing purposes. However, Sir,

Speaker: NA
Text: I respect the views the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: has on this matter and I will be glad to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue his suggestions further with those

Speaker: NA
Text: who are very much more knowledgable

Speaker: NA
Text: on the matter than I am. In particular I

Speaker: NA
Text: will refer to my colleague, the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Housing, the remarks the honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man has put to me.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATIONAL SERVICE TRAINING.

Speaker: Mr JESS
Text: Ha s the Minister for Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: and National Service seen reports

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters that national service training is

Speaker: NA
Text: having an effect on recruitment for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Military Forces? Could the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: reiterate the existing conditions, and any

Speaker: NA
Text: variations to policy, whereby men may serve

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Citizen Military Forces instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: heing required to render national service?

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: I have seen reports

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last three to four months that

Speaker: NA
Text: young men who might otherwise be called

Speaker: NA
Text: up for national service training were apply-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for membership of the Citizen Military

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces and being accepted. When they

Speaker: NA
Text: found that their birthdays were not drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ballot they then resigned from marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: the Citizen Military Forces and were

Speaker: NA
Text: not subsequently called up for national serprovisions

Speaker: NA
Text: vice training. This matter has received

Speaker: NA
Text: careful attention by my colleagues, the today.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers for Defence, Army, Navy and

Speaker: NA
Text: Air and also by the Department of Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: and National Service. I hope, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the Leader of the Opposition,

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a short statement on the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: immediately after question time.

Speaker: NA
Text: CIVIL AVIATION.

Speaker: Mr DAVIES
Text: I preface a question to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister representing the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Civil Aviation by reminding the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Duck River Co-operative Butter

Speaker: NA
Text: Factory Co. Ltd. at Smithton, Tasmania,

Speaker: NA
Text: at present using three to four Trans-Austerms

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia Airlines DC3's per week to airlift Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: some 24,000 to 30,000 lb. of meat to Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne from the Smithton aerodrome, and

Speaker: NA
Text: that a serious problem has arisen in that

Speaker: NA
Text: we have to accept the decision of the traffic

Speaker: NA
Text: controller at the Wynyard aerodrome before

Speaker: NA
Text: permission can be given for aircraft to land

Speaker: NA
Text: at Smithton. I ask the Minister: Is he aware

Speaker: NA
Text: that the weather patterns at Wynyard and

Speaker: NA
Text: Smithton can be the very opposite of one

Speaker: NA
Text: another because of the effect of the Sisters

Speaker: NA
Text: Hills between Wynyard and Smithton? In

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the double handling, the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: bloom on the meat and increased costs, &c,

Speaker: NA
Text: involved when meat has to be taken back

Speaker: NA
Text: to the factory from the Smithton aerodrome

Speaker: NA
Text: because Wynyard has refused landing per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission, will the Minister give immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: and urgent consideration to either appoint-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a departmental officer at Smithton or

Speaker: NA
Text: authorizing the local agent of T.A.A., who

Speaker: NA
Text: handles these aircraft, to advise regarding

Speaker: NA
Text: weather conditions at Smithton during this

Speaker: NA
Text: in some very busy meat export season?

Speaker: Mr FAIRBAIRN
Text: Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally I am not aware of the facts that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable gentleman has given me in

Speaker: NA
Text: his question. I will see that these facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: passed on to the Minister for Civil Avia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in another place and that the request

Speaker: NA
Text: made by the honorable member is looked at.

Speaker: NA
Text: MARKETING OF DRIED FRUITS.

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Text: I ask the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: General whether the present system of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian dried fruits at home

Speaker: NA
Text: and abroad is definitely exempt from the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Trade Practices Bill 1965,

Speaker: NA
Text: which was passed by this House earlier

Speaker: Mr SNEDDEN
Text: Th e system is not

Speaker: NA
Text: definitely exempted but provision is made

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Bill as it left this House for it to be

Speaker: NA
Text: exempted. The Government has had in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that there are primary industry

Speaker: NA
Text: marketing organisations which should be

Speaker: NA
Text: so exempted. There is power in the Bill in

Speaker: NA
Text: this regard. As a matter of policy the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment has looked at, for instance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Dried Fruits Association and the

Speaker: NA
Text: way it markets its products as a primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry marketing organisation. I am con-

Speaker: NA
Text: is fident that it would be exempted under the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the regulations concerning the

Speaker: NA
Text: COAL.

Speaker: Mr CONNOR
Text: Wil l the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development, at his coming con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference with the New South Wales Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mines, discuss with that gentleman his

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of last May expressing concern

Speaker: NA
Text: at the possible exhaustion through present

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of consumption of New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: hard coking coal reserves by the year 2000?

Speaker: NA
Text: Will he also discuss with the New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales Minister for Mines the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: examining some controls over expanded

Speaker: NA
Text: exports of such coal? In addition, will he

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the Minister for Mines that additional

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves of such coal in New South Wales,

Speaker: NA
Text: when located and proven, be preserved for

Speaker: NA
Text: the steel industry and other Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers?

Speaker: Mr FAIRBAIRN
Text: I t was because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government did show

Speaker: NA
Text: some concern at the rate of depletion of

Speaker: NA
Text: coking coal supplies in New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: and Queensland that we got in touch with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governments of those two States and

Speaker: NA
Text: arranged to hold the conference to which

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member referred. All we are

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking to do is to assess what these

Speaker: NA
Text: -reserves are. We know that at the present

Speaker: NA
Text: moment they are very considerable. Speak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing from memory, I think the known coal

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves in New South Wales are about

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,000 million tons. We believe that less

Speaker: NA
Text: half this quantity will be required by Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia to the end of this century. Neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less we are anxious that a proper assess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of all the resources in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and Queensland should be made so

Speaker: NA
Text: that, after this assessment has been made,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government may be in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: k ow the correct policy it should undertake.

Speaker: NA
Text: n

Speaker: NA
Text: QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE.

Speaker: Sir KENT HUGHES
Text: I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister whether he is in a

Speaker: NA
Text: position yet to reply to two previous

Speaker: NA
Text: questions I asked regarding the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: troops in Vietnam and about which the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman said he hoped

Speaker: NA
Text: to have the information last month.

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member has raised this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter quite a few times with me. As he

Speaker: NA
Text: knows, this matter involves discussions in

Speaker: NA
Text: London. I am happy so say that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of the Borneo clasp for the General

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Medal 1962

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Whitlam - I rise to order, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. I regret to have to take the same

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order as I took yesterday. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are questions on the notice paper to the

Speaker: NA
Text: right honorable gentleman concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters. They have been there since

Speaker: NA
Text: 9th November.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I f there are questions

Speaker: NA
Text: on the notice paper in relation to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter the honorable member's question is

Speaker: NA
Text: out of order.

Speaker: Sir KENT HUGHES
Text: Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: I, too, rise to order. I asked my questions

Speaker: NA
Text: long before the Deputy Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition put his questions on the notice

Speaker: NA
Text: paper.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I s the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied to answer the question?

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: I am always satisfied to give a little

Speaker: NA
Text: information. The information is that Her

Speaker: NA
Text: Majesty has been pleased to approve the

Speaker: NA
Text: award of the General Service Medal 1962

Speaker: NA
Text: with the clasp " Borneo " to Australian ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vicemen in the area who qualify for tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: award. The other case is that of Vietnam,

Speaker: NA
Text: and on this nofinalityhas yet been reached.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is being very actively pursued. I have had

Speaker: NA
Text: than messages about it in the last 24 hours. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope to be able to make an announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: at an early date. When I have the informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, I will make the announcement

Speaker: NA
Text: promptly.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOCIAL SERVICES.

Speaker: Mr MINOGUE
Text: M y question is

Speaker: NA
Text: addressed to the Minister for Social Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now that the Minister for Health has given

Speaker: NA
Text: a lead in removing the disparity between

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners with respect to the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlement card, will the Minister for Social

Speaker: NA
Text: Services follow his example by granting the

Speaker: NA
Text: same rates of pension and supplementary

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to married and single pensioners?

Speaker: NA
Text: Will he also remove the anomaly repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented by the payment of the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral benefit to certain relatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: deceased pensioners and not to other rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives who have the same responsibility to

Speaker: NA
Text: see that deceased pensioners receive decent

Speaker: NA
Text: burials, which now cost at least Â£100? Why

Speaker: NA
Text: is it that the Government persists in treating

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners on the basis of " some chalk,

Speaker: NA
Text: some cheese "?

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: Th e extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner medical service to all persons

Speaker: NA
Text: receiving pensions is another instance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: way in which this Government has extended

Speaker: NA
Text: social service benefits progressively to all

Speaker: NA
Text: sections of the community. The second part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the honorable member's question related

Speaker: NA
Text: to supplementary assistance. The increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary assistance announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer in his Budget speech was for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of extending additional assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: to single pensioners paying rent, who would

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to be the ones most affected by the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost situation in the community. It is felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the present situation single pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners have a greater need than married

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioners. The distinction between single

Speaker: NA
Text: and married pensioners has been explained

Speaker: NA
Text: on a number of occasions in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: during discussions on suggestions for a stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard rate of pension. The practice of paying

Speaker: NA
Text: different amounts to single and married pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioners is customarily followed in every

Speaker: NA
Text: country of the western world, on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: that married people are able to share

Speaker: NA
Text: between them certain household expenses.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member also referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of the funeral benefit. It is felt

Speaker: NA
Text: that pensioners should get the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage of the extended funeral benefit,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is to this category of person that the

Speaker: NA
Text: funeral benefit has recently been extended.

Speaker: NA
Text: WOOL RESERVE PRICES PLAN.

Speaker: Mr MAISEY
Text: I direct a question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Acting Minister for Primary Industry. to be used?

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the widespread interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: wool reserve prices scheme referendum, vot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing in which will close tomorrow, can

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister say when the results of the ballot

Speaker: NA
Text: are likely to be known?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Th e ballot will close

Speaker: NA
Text: at 12 noon tomorrow. The counting will

Speaker: NA
Text: start tomorrow afternoon. It is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: the tallies in the various States will be

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted by tomorrow night. They will be

Speaker: NA
Text: warded to the Chief Commonwealth Elecrocket

Speaker: NA
Text: toral Officer in Canberra, who will add

Speaker: NA
Text: the results from the various States. It

Speaker: NA
Text: hoped that he will be able to give the results

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister on Friday and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister will be able to announce them

Speaker: NA
Text: about noon on Friday.

Speaker: NA
Text: DROUGHT RELIEF.

Speaker: Mr NELSON
Text: M y question is addressed

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Prime Minister. I refer to the agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment between the Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and the Governments of New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales and Queensland on drought relief, as

Speaker: NA
Text: announced in the House yesterday. Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister extend to drought affected

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers in the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: the same kind and level of assistance as the

Speaker: NA
Text: States are extending to their primary

Speaker: NA
Text: producers?

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: Thi s is a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter which falls properly within the juris-

Speaker: NA
Text: diction of the Minister for Territories. It

Speaker: NA
Text: was dealt with originally, as the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member will recall, as a separate matter,

Speaker: NA
Text: with special arrangements being made be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we had a broad and direct responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility in the Northern Territory. Should

Speaker: NA
Text: there be any further developments in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter I am perfectly certain that the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Territories will be most willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House about them at the right

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: REDSTONE ROCKETS.

Speaker: Mr BRIDGESMAXWELL
Text: I ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Supply a question. I refer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: report that Redstone rockets from the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States of America are to be used for space

Speaker: NA
Text: experiments at Woomera. Is this correct?

Speaker: NA
Text: Are these superseded rockets unsafe, as the

Speaker: NA
Text: reports suggest, or are they suitable for the

Speaker: NA
Text: types of experiments to be carried out? Can

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister tell the House anything about

Speaker: NA
Text: the experiments in which these rockets are

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: Fo r some time the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Supply has been carrying

Speaker: NA
Text: on under a joint agreement with the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom experiments in what are known

Speaker: NA
Text: as re-entry physics to judge the technical

Speaker: NA
Text: phenomena that occur when a space

Speaker: NA
Text: vehicle re-enters the earth's atmosphere.

Speaker: NA
Text: These experiments have been conducted

Speaker: NA
Text: that with the Black Knight rocket. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: comnow reached a point at which it would per-

Speaker: NA
Text: forhaps be desirable to have a more powerful

Speaker: NA
Text: that would give greater height and

Speaker: NA
Text: up therefore greater speed of re-entry. For

Speaker: NA
Text: is some time there have been in progress

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations for a tripartite arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: between the United Kingdom, Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: by the United States of America. An agree-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has not yet been finalised, but if it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be it would provide for the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Redstone rocket, which would be sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plied by the United States. It is true that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Redstone rocket is obsolete for orbital

Speaker: NA
Text: flight, for which it was once used, and as

Speaker: NA
Text: an intercontinental ballistic missile, for

Speaker: NA
Text: which use it was designed. But in terms of

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind of experiment that we wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake at Woomera it is not obsolete.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will be no safety problem since the

Speaker: NA
Text: rocket is not to be used for horizontal

Speaker: NA
Text: flight but will be used only for vertical

Speaker: NA
Text: flight for which, apart from any other con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations, it is completely safe. Further-

Speaker: NA
Text: more, the safety precautions at the Woomera

Speaker: NA
Text: rocket range are very strict indeed. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member may rest assured that if

Speaker: NA
Text: the projected agreement is arranged the

Speaker: NA
Text: programme will be carried through with

Speaker: NA
Text: safety and I am sure that it will be com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted with satisfaction.

Speaker: NA
Text: VIETNAM.

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: I direct my question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Army. I ask: Has he

Speaker: NA
Text: inquired into the accusations made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: head of the Saigon bureau of the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States magazine " Newsweek " that an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian adviser serving with the South

Speaker: NA
Text: namese forces had advised a Vietnamese

Speaker: NA
Text: officer to shoot a Vietcong suspect? If the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister has made an inquiry will he say

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the facts are as published in

Speaker: NA
Text: " Newsweek " and will he give to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: details of the inquiry?

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Text: A s I said at the time that

Speaker: NA
Text: the article appeared, I am in the course of

Speaker: NA
Text: investigating this matter. The delay in the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry has been due to thc fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: article does not identify the time and place

Speaker: NA
Text: and does not name the individual concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, delay has been caused because

Speaker: NA
Text: the author of the article, whose name is

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuohy, has been absent from Saigon. How-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, on 4th December he attended a meet-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with the commander of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Army forces in Vietnam at the commander's

Speaker: NA
Text: request. At that meeting the commander

Speaker: NA
Text: asked the correspondent some questions

Speaker: NA
Text: about the article. He asked first whether

Speaker: NA
Text: gave afirst-handaccount and whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: correspondent had seen the incident. To

Speaker: NA
Text: this question he replied: " No". He was

Speaker: NA
Text: asked whether he believed the report to

Speaker: NA
Text: be true. He said: " Yes ". He admitted,

Speaker: NA
Text: ever, that the story might have become

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhat blurred as a consequence of

Speaker: NA
Text: passing through quite a number of hands

Speaker: NA
Text: and admitted that it probably went through

Speaker: NA
Text: quite a number of hands. He was told by

Speaker: NA
Text: the commander that this was a matter of

Speaker: NA
Text: great moment to us in Australia, that it

Speaker: NA
Text: represented a slur on the good name of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian soldiers, that such behaviour as

Speaker: NA
Text: that alleged was contrary to everything that

Speaker: NA
Text: they had been taught in their training and

Speaker: NA
Text: everything that they had been brought up

Speaker: NA
Text: to believe in as soldiers and that the cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: respondent therefore had an obligation to

Speaker: NA
Text: name the soldier concerned. The corre-

Speaker: NA
Text: spondent was told that this was a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: much bigger than just the possible conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: qeunces for one individual. So far he has

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to name the soldier, but is consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing his position. Until this is done I can

Speaker: NA
Text: take the matter no further.

Speaker: NA
Text: MINING.

Speaker: Dr GIBBS
Text: Ha s the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development seen a report that

Speaker: NA
Text: a new silver-lead-zinc lode in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory is to be worked by an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: company? Is this report true? Will the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable gentleman tell the House how

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietmany mineral discoveries have been

Speaker: NA
Text: brought into production or earmarked for

Speaker: NA
Text: production in the last 12 months? Are new

Speaker: NA
Text: mineral discoveries likely to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant contribution to export income in

Speaker: NA
Text: the foreseeable future?

Speaker: Mr FAIRBAIRN
Text: Th e silver-lead-zinc

Speaker: NA
Text: mine to which I think the honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man refers, and which is to be mined by

Speaker: NA
Text: United Uranium, is not a new mine; it is one

Speaker: NA
Text: which was originally mined about 20 years

Speaker: NA
Text: ago and the high quality ore was taken out.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has now been drilled and deposits have

Speaker: NA
Text: proved to be fairly extensive. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that some of the lower quality ore is about

Speaker: NA
Text: to be mined. However, this is not one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the very large discoveries. I am afraid, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable gentleman realises, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: quite impossible for me to detail, in

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to a question without notice, all the

Speaker: NA
Text: discoveries that have occurred in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: it during thc last 12 months, because we are

Speaker: NA
Text: going through a second period of discovery

Speaker: NA
Text: which probably exceeds the discoveries of

Speaker: NA
Text: the gold rush. If the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman puts the question on the

Speaker: NA
Text: hownotice paper I will see that he gets a

Speaker: NA
Text: full reply. I can tell him, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: minerals look like playing a very impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant part in contributing to Australia's ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: port income. This year, Â£120 million worth

Speaker: NA
Text: of minerals were exported, and the Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: of Mineral Resources has estimated that in

Speaker: NA
Text: five years' time the value of our exports

Speaker: NA
Text: of minerals will have risen to Â£280 million

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: SCHOOL CADETS.

Speaker: Mr STEWART
Text: I address a question to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for the Army. Is it a fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: school cadet units are expected to attend

Speaker: NA
Text: week-end bivouacs and two-week camps

Speaker: NA
Text: during summer months? Is it also a fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: thc issue of summer trousers to school

Speaker: NA
Text: cadets has been reduced from two pairs to

Speaker: NA
Text: one pair? If so, what are the reasons for

Speaker: NA
Text: this pinch penny decision and who is

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for it? Do Army authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: expect school cadets to wear the one pair

Speaker: NA
Text: of trousers for the duration of the bivouacs

Speaker: NA
Text: and camps? If not, what arrangements is a

Speaker: NA
Text: school cadet expected to make to protect his

Speaker: NA
Text: modesty while his sole pair of trousers is

Speaker: NA
Text: being laundered? Finally, is there any truth

Speaker: NA
Text: in the rumour that a member of the Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Islands Regiment is to be asked to demon-

Speaker: NA
Text: strate to school cadets the correct way to

Speaker: NA
Text: don their privately supplied lap-laps?

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Text: I am not aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: position described by the honorable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man. 1 shall investigate and find out what

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation is. Perhaps I should say at

Speaker: NA
Text: stage that school cadets, like members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Services going into camp, would doubtless

Speaker: NA
Text: be issued with working dress while in

Speaker: NA
Text: camp as part of a camp issue. This would

Speaker: NA
Text: undoubtedly reduce the strain, even on fhe

Speaker: NA
Text: one pair of trousers, if that is all that

Speaker: NA
Text: have. However, I shall investigate the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and let the honorable gentleman know

Speaker: NA
Text: the result of my inquiries.

Speaker: NA
Text: DROUGHT RELIEF.

Speaker: Mr IAN ALLAN
Text: Ca n the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: give an assurance that the needs of those

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers in drought affected areas

Speaker: NA
Text: who have not exhausted their capital or

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity to borrow and who will thus be

Speaker: NA
Text: excluded from the benefits announced by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister yesterday will be

Speaker: NA
Text: considered by the Government?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Representation s and,

Speaker: NA
Text: on this aspect have come from honorable Government policy?

Speaker: NA
Text: members in various parts of the House,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the honorable gentleman himself

Speaker: NA
Text: on earlier occasions. I can assure him that

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation of those who fall within this

Speaker: NA
Text: category is well recognised by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and consideration is being given to

Speaker: NA
Text: ways and means by which they can be

Speaker: NA
Text: assisted with their problem.

Speaker: NA
Text: PHARMACEUTICAL AND MEDICAL

Speaker: NA
Text: BENEFITS.

Speaker: Mr CALWELL
Text: I ask the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Social Services: Is it a fact that the means

Speaker: NA
Text: test with regard to pharmaceutical and

Speaker: NA
Text: medical benefits as applied to pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: was imposed by the present Government on

Speaker: NA
Text: lst November 1955? Is it also a fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: during the 10-year period that has elapsed

Speaker: NA
Text: since then the Opposition has repeatedly

Speaker: NA
Text: moved amendments seeking the abolition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the means test, without having once re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived any support from any one Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment member? Is it also a fact that not one

Speaker: NA
Text: Government member has ever spoken in

Speaker: NA
Text: protest against the operation of the means

Speaker: NA
Text: test on pensioners in the past 10 years?

Speaker: Dr MACKAY
Text: Loo k up " Hansard ".

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: A s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Evans has just said, the answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the last part of the question asked by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition is to be found

Speaker: NA
Text: in " Hansard ". Many members on the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: this vernment side have frequently advocated

Speaker: NA
Text: the liberalisation of the means test and the

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of the pensioner medical service

Speaker: NA
Text: to all persons in receipt of pension benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: The notable extension this year was made

Speaker: NA
Text: in accordance with this principle. Because

Speaker: NA
Text: they of that extension, after lst January next

Speaker: NA
Text: many people will be in a considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: better position with regard to medical and

Speaker: NA
Text: pharmaceutical benefits than they were

Speaker: NA
Text: previously.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUTOMATION.

Speaker: Mr FALKINDER
Text: I address a question

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Labour and National

Speaker: NA
Text: Service. What steps of a major kind are

Speaker: NA
Text: being taken by the Government or his

Speaker: NA
Text: Department to study automation? Is a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinuing evaluation being made of the effects

Speaker: NA
Text: of the progressive automation of industry

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular, of the effect on future

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Several major

Speaker: NA
Text: methods are adopted by the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that automation will not have a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial and immediate impact on the em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment of people. For example, produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tivity groups have been established on a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide scale. I think more than 2,000 firms

Speaker: NA
Text: are now involved in them. These groups con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinually watch not only the distribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: information between industries and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies but also the impact of automation on

Speaker: NA
Text: their own industries and the likely impact

Speaker: NA
Text: on associated industries. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman would know, too, that the former

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministry of Labour Advisory Council pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lished a pamphlet on the effect of automa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I think it is one of the standard works

Speaker: NA
Text: on the subject. 1 shall obtain a copy and

Speaker: NA
Text: let the honorable gentleman have it.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to the last part of the question, one

Speaker: NA
Text: section of my Department continually

Speaker: NA
Text: watches the impact of automation and the

Speaker: NA
Text: effect it is likely to have upon the growth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the work force, upon unemployment and

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Commonwealth Public Service.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable gentleman can take it that

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter is continually under observation

Speaker: NA
Text: by us. I shall obtain some further informa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and let him have it.

Speaker: NA
Text: SEAMEN'S AWARD.

Speaker: Mr BENSON
Text: I address to the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Labour and National Service a question

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to working conditions for seamen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister will be aware of the interest of

Speaker: NA
Text: all members in any measures designed to

Speaker: NA
Text: bring about better working conditions and

Speaker: NA
Text: continuity of work for seamen. He will recall

Speaker: NA
Text: that some months ago the 195S seamen's

Speaker: NA
Text: award was varied to provide for a stabilisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion scheme. I ask: Is the Minister able to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise whether continuity of work is being

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved? Can be tell us the amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance money paid so far to this

Speaker: NA
Text: industry? Finally, can he say whether all

Speaker: NA
Text: labour quotas have been resolved?

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber will have, of course, a very deep and

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed knowledge of the effects of stabilisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and mechanisation schemes because, if

Speaker: NA
Text: my memory holds good, he was the first

Speaker: NA
Text: chairman of a mechanisation committee

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed on the Australian waterfront to

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the problems of the mechanisation

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sugar industry as they applied to

Speaker: NA
Text: seamen, waterside workers and stevedores.

Speaker: NA
Text: About 16 months ago an agreement was

Speaker: NA
Text: made between the steamship owners and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Seamen's Union of Australia. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: supervised by my own Department and by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Shipping and Transport.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of that agreement considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: improvements in pay and working condi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions of seamen were arrived at in return for

Speaker: NA
Text: which the seamen agreed to stabilise the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to give continuity of work and to

Speaker: NA
Text: get a better turnround time for ships. In

Speaker: NA
Text: addition the exclusive right of recruitment

Speaker: NA
Text: was taken away from the Seamen's Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: These provisions were finally embodied in an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment to the award of 1955.

Speaker: NA
Text: From time to time a report is made by my

Speaker: NA
Text: Department and by the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Shipping and Transport showing how the

Speaker: NA
Text: conditions agreed to had been observed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am glad to be able to inform the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member that there has been a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in the number of days lost in

Speaker: NA
Text: the shipping industry. There were consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able reductions in the first two four-monthly

Speaker: NA
Text: periods; in the first there was a loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: 576 days, involving about 107 ships; and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last four monthly period there have

Speaker: NA
Text: been almost no losses at all, or the loss has

Speaker: NA
Text: been so negligible that it has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: worth while reporting upon. There has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable improvement in the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the moment it appears to be stabilised.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to the second question, concerning

Speaker: NA
Text: attendance money, I think the amount paid

Speaker: NA
Text: since 1st December 1964 is about

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£33,000 already, but that is a small

Speaker: NA
Text: amount compared to the reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: stoppages that has taken place. As to

Speaker: NA
Text: the last question relating to quotas for sea-

Speaker: NA
Text: men, regrettably the steamship owners have

Speaker: NA
Text: not put up proposals to the Seamen's Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: This matter will be brought to the attention

Speaker: NA
Text: of the presidential member of the Concilia-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion and Arbitration Commission and I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that he, in his turn, will bring it to the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the parties.

Speaker: NA
Text: PENSIONER MEDICAL SERVICE.

Speaker: Mr BUCHANAN
Text: M y question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Health relates to the payments

Speaker: NA
Text: made to doctors under the pensioner medical

Speaker: NA
Text: service. The present arrangement is for

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of 16s. for each visit to a doctor's

Speaker: NA
Text: surgery and Â£1 for each home visit a doctor

Speaker: NA
Text: makes to a pensioner, even when pensioners

Speaker: NA
Text: are grouped together in an aged persons

Speaker: NA
Text: home. No payment is made for the time a

Speaker: NA
Text: doctor spends treating pensioners in hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pitals. Will the Minister examine the position

Speaker: NA
Text: to see whether this is an anomaly?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Wit h the exception of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Territories the admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istration of hospitals comes within the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol of the State Governments. However, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is a fact that the honorary system of ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice by doctors applies in all States of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia with one exception-Wester n

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It is a fact also that the medical

Speaker: NA
Text: profession provides services on an honorary

Speaker: NA
Text: basis generally in practically every case

Speaker: NA
Text: where the pensioner or patient is in a public

Speaker: NA
Text: ward. That service still continues. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed at the last conference of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Medical Association when the

Speaker: NA
Text: decision was made to continue the system.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH

Speaker: NA
Text: SUPERANNUATION FUND.

Speaker: Mr COSTA
Text: I address a question

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer concerning recent legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: affecting the distribution of the Â£5.6 million

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus in the Commonwealth Superbered

Speaker: NA
Text: annuation Fund. Has the Treasurer decided

Speaker: NA
Text: on any order of priority for the distribution?

Speaker: NA
Text: If not, will he consider giving preference

Speaker: NA
Text: in priority to the oldest pensioners, because

Speaker: NA
Text: some who were expecting to receive refunds

Speaker: NA
Text: at this time last year have since died?

Speaker: Mr HAROLD HOLT
Text: Earlie r in the

Speaker: NA
Text: session I indicated that as we were not

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide for the full distribution of the

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus owing to the delay in actuarial calsider

Speaker: NA
Text: culations, consideration had been given

Speaker: NA
Text: an interim distribution. In making that

Speaker: NA
Text: interim distribution, I understand, the

Speaker: NA
Text: category of pensioner to which the honorwe

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentleman has referred will be

Speaker: NA
Text: priority. I regret that I am not able to give Rhodesia.

Speaker: NA
Text: the precise date on which the distribution

Speaker: NA
Text: will be made. I assure the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber that everything possible is being done

Speaker: NA
Text: expedite the matter. If, upon inquiry, I

Speaker: NA
Text: that my understanding of the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: not correet, I will let the honorable gentlethe

Speaker: NA
Text: man know the true position.

Speaker: NA
Text: RHODESIA.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Sir ROBERT MENZIES
Text: Kooyong-

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister) -b y leave- 1 wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: inform the House of measures in the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial and economic field which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has decided to take against

Speaker: NA
Text: the illegal administration in Rhodesia. These

Speaker: NA
Text: measures are additional to those that I

Speaker: NA
Text: announced on 16th November. They are

Speaker: NA
Text: taken in the belief that peaceful measures

Speaker: NA
Text: are preferable to military measures and that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to minimise the ultimate damage to

Speaker: NA
Text: Rhodesia, the sooner the sanctions become

Speaker: NA
Text: effective and normal constitutional admin-

Speaker: NA
Text: istration is resumed, the better for that

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is not an easy decision to take

Speaker: NA
Text: because sanctions can hurt very deeply. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, sanctions are designed to impose

Speaker: NA
Text: disabilities, but a system of sanctions which

Speaker: NA
Text: stops short of being effective could easily

Speaker: NA
Text: go on operating for a long, long time,

Speaker: NA
Text: creating irritations, not solving the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: and, perhaps, provoking extreme action on

Speaker: NA
Text: the part of other people. Therefore we have

Speaker: NA
Text: come to the conclusion that, falling in line

Speaker: NA
Text: with the United Kingdom and various other

Speaker: NA
Text: to the countries, we should to some extent

Speaker: NA
Text: intensify our economic measures. In what

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 say it must always, of course, be remem-

Speaker: NA
Text: that our trade with Rhodesia is a

Speaker: NA
Text: small one-no t quite Â£2 million worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: imports altogether annually.

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation tofinancialmeasures, we will

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the Board of the Reserve Bank

Speaker: NA
Text: of Rhodesia, which the British Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has appointed to replace the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: board. We will recognise it as the only

Speaker: NA
Text: able proper authority. Following from this

Speaker: NA
Text: decision, it may be necessary for us to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing restrictions in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: to financial transactions between Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and Rhodesian residents comparable with

Speaker: NA
Text: the restrictions introduced by Britain. Also,

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided to suspend the money

Speaker: NA
Text: given order service between Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: In relation to economic measures, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: to be recalled that we have already placed a

Speaker: NA
Text: find ban on the importation of tobacco from

Speaker: NA
Text: is Rhodesia. We now propose to prohibit also

Speaker: NA
Text: importation of ferro-alloys, chrome ore

Speaker: NA
Text: and asbestos. The ban on imports of

Speaker: NA
Text: tobacco meant that approximately three-

Speaker: NA
Text: quarters of our total imports from

Speaker: NA
Text: Rhodesia were suspended. The inclusion of

Speaker: NA
Text: ferro-alloys, chrome pre and asbestos will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean that we have prohibited imports from

Speaker: NA
Text: Rhodesia affecting more than 90 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the total. The British have banned

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 95 per cent, of their imports

Speaker: NA
Text: from Rhodesia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise that in a relatively small field

Speaker: NA
Text: these measures are severe. However, the

Speaker: NA
Text: unhappy situation with which we are deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing is of grave proportions, involving as it

Speaker: NA
Text: does, not only the cessation of lawful rule

Speaker: NA
Text: in Rhodesia, but also the arousing of

Speaker: NA
Text: emotions in Africa and elsewhere. In all

Speaker: NA
Text: these matters it is our hope that the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the measures now being applied, by this

Speaker: NA
Text: and other countries will mean a return to

Speaker: NA
Text: sanity and negotiation and that Rhodesia

Speaker: NA
Text: will see reason and find a return to a legal

Speaker: NA
Text: and constructive relationship with the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I present the following paper-

Speaker: NA
Text: Rhodesia-Additiona l Financial and Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Sanctions-Ministeria l Statement, 8th Decem-

Speaker: NA
Text: and move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of the paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Calwell)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATIONAL SERVICE TRAINING.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statenient.

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Text: Lowe-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour and National Service) -b y leave-

Speaker: NA
Text: In November of last year, I introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation providing for the re-introduction

Speaker: NA
Text: of national service. I said then that the Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment intended using the national service

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme as a means of encouraging men

Speaker: NA
Text: enlist in the Citizen Military Forces.

Speaker: NA
Text: The roles of the Citizen Military Forces,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Citizen Naval Forces and the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force are of great importance in our

Speaker: NA
Text: defence plans. Thus it was provided that spective

Speaker: NA
Text: men liable to render national service who

Speaker: NA
Text: were ballotted in would be granted provided

Speaker: NA
Text: indefinite deferment of call up if they

Speaker: NA
Text: were, at the time of the ballot, members

Speaker: NA
Text: the Citizen Naval Forces, Citizen Military

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces or active Citizen Air Force. The

Speaker: NA
Text: indefinite deferment was contingent upon

Speaker: NA
Text: men serving efficiently for a total period

Speaker: NA
Text: five years if they had completed at least

Speaker: NA
Text: one year's efficient service at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: the ballot, or for a total of six years if they

Speaker: NA
Text: had completed less than one year's efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: service at the time of the ballot. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: were not members of the Citizen Forces at

Speaker: NA
Text: the time of their registration were required

Speaker: NA
Text: to join those Forces before the ballot if

Speaker: NA
Text: they wished to be eligible for deferment

Speaker: NA
Text: under these provisions. These arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: will continue to apply to members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Forces who have already been

Speaker: NA
Text: granted indefinite deferment of call up.

Speaker: NA
Text: These particular deferment provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: have now been reviewed and as from next

Speaker: NA
Text: year men who register for national service

Speaker: NA
Text: may be permitted to serve in the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces, provided they are acceptable to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Forces, and that there are suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: vacancies for them, instead of being re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to perform national service. Those

Speaker: NA
Text: who wish to follow this course will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to give an undertaking to do so

Speaker: NA
Text: before the ballot relating to the registration

Speaker: NA
Text: of their age group. They may fali within

Speaker: NA
Text: any one of three categories.

Speaker: NA
Text: First, there will be those who have served

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently as members of the Citizen Forces

Speaker: NA
Text: for at least 12 months at the date of

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement of registration of their age

Speaker: NA
Text: group. They will be required to undertake

Speaker: NA
Text: to serve efficiently in the Citizen Forces for

Speaker: NA
Text: a total period of five years. If they are

Speaker: NA
Text: ballotted in they will not be called up for

Speaker: NA
Text: national service provided they serve

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently for that period; if ballotted out

Speaker: NA
Text: they will not, under present arrangements,

Speaker: NA
Text: be called up for national service in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Forces under the normal conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to such service.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, there will be those who have

Speaker: NA
Text: served efficiently as members of the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: to Forces for less than 12 months at the

Speaker: NA
Text: date of commencement of registration for

Speaker: NA
Text: their age group. They will be required to

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake to serve efficiently in the Citizen

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces for a total period of six years, irre-

Speaker: NA
Text: of the result of the ballot. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: be granted indefinite deferment of call up

Speaker: NA
Text: they serve efficiently for the total

Speaker: NA
Text: period; those who fail to serve efficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: of for the full period will become liable for

Speaker: NA
Text: call up for national service, regardless of

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they were or were not ballotted in.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, there will be those who are not

Speaker: NA
Text: of members of the Citizen Forces at the date

Speaker: NA
Text: of commencement of registration for then-

Speaker: NA
Text: of age group. They will be required to give,

Speaker: NA
Text: before the ballot which relates to the regis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tration of their age group, an undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: who to complete a total of six years' efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: service with the Citizen Forces, irrespective

Speaker: NA
Text: of the result of the ballot, if they are

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted as members. For the undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: to be effective they must apply to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Forces, before they complete the

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaking, and be accepted as members.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will be granted indefinite deferment

Speaker: NA
Text: of call-up provided they serve efficiently for

Speaker: NA
Text: the full period; those who fail to serve

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiently for the full period will become

Speaker: NA
Text: liable to call-up for national service,

Speaker: NA
Text: regardless of whether they were or were

Speaker: NA
Text: not ballotted in. Men who wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: avail themselves of the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: serve in the Citizen Forces, in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the provisions I have mentioned, must

Speaker: NA
Text: sign a form of undertaking and forward

Speaker: NA
Text: it to my Department within 14 days of the

Speaker: NA
Text: close of the registration period for their age

Speaker: NA
Text: group.

Speaker: NA
Text: These arrangements will apply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Military Forces, Citizen Naval

Speaker: NA
Text: Forces and Auxiliary Squadrons of the active

Speaker: NA
Text: Citizen Air Force. Revised arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: will apply also to University Air Squadrons

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Citizen Air Force. Those who

Speaker: NA
Text: already members of these squadrons

Speaker: NA
Text: commencement date for registration of their

Speaker: NA
Text: age group and who are ballotted in will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be called up for national service pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided that they satisfactorily complete their

Speaker: NA
Text: two years' service with the squadron,

Speaker: NA
Text: graduate in their faculties and complete

Speaker: NA
Text: five years' service on the Royal Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Air Force Reserve. I f they fail to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements they will be liable to call-up

Speaker: NA
Text: for national service. Full details covering

Speaker: NA
Text: these provisions will be contained in the

Speaker: NA
Text: information sheet attached to the national

Speaker: NA
Text: service registration form which will be availseparate

Speaker: NA
Text: able in the new year. I present the following Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: paper-

Speaker: NA
Text: Service in the Citizen Forces as an alternative to

Speaker: NA
Text: National Service-Ministeria l Statement,

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1965-

Speaker: NA
Text: and move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House take note of thc paper.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Whitlam)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: PUBLIC ACCOUNTS COMMITTEE.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: Swan) -A s Chairman, I

Speaker: NA
Text: present the following reports of the Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Accounts Committee-

Speaker: NA
Text: Seventy-fourth Report-Expenditur e

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance to the Treasurer (Appropriation

Speaker: NA
Text: Seventy-fifth Report-Expenditur e from thc Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidated Revenue Fund for the year 1964-65.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Ther e being no objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, leave is granted.

Speaker: Mr CLEAVER
Text: Thes e reports relate,

Speaker: NA
Text: respectively, to expenditure from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Advance to the Treasurer and to other ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penditure from the Consolidated Revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: Fund in 1964-65. The question fore-

Speaker: NA
Text: shadowed in your Committee's Sixtieth

Speaker: NA
Text: Report, of the desirability of conducting one

Speaker: NA
Text: or two inquiries into these matters and

Speaker: NA
Text: involving one or two reports did not arise

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of the financial year 1962-63 as

Speaker: NA
Text: the limited time available to your Commit-

Speaker: NA
Text: tee precluded the completion of one large

Speaker: NA
Text: comprehensive report; nor did it arise in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the financial year 1963-64 as your

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee confined its inquiry in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial results for that year to an

Speaker: NA
Text: are examination of expenditure from the

Speaker: NA
Text: at the Advance to the Treasurer.

Speaker: NA
Text: In approaching its inquiry into the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: solidated Revenue Fund results for 1964-65,

Speaker: NA
Text: your Committee considered that as several

Speaker: NA
Text: departments would be involved in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure from the Advance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer and other expenditure from the

Speaker: NA
Text: these Consolidated Revenue Fund, considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: economy of time would be achieved if a

Speaker: NA
Text: single inquiry were to be held but that,

Speaker: NA
Text: as the subject matter relating to the two

Speaker: NA
Text: matters was clearly distinguishable, two

Speaker: NA
Text: reports should be submitted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: In its previous report relating to expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture from the Advance to the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: 8th in 1963-64 your Committee drew attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to the unsatisfactory nature of some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: explanatory statements submitted by depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments and indicated that discussions would

Speaker: NA
Text: take place between officers of the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the Treasury and the Committee to

Speaker: NA
Text: produce a suitable pro forma statement for

Speaker: NA
Text: use by departments in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry in 1964-65. Your Committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: Reports. examination of the explanatory statements

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted by departments this year and based

Speaker: NA
Text: on the pro forma statement which was duly

Speaker: NA
Text: developed showed a very substantial im-

Speaker: NA
Text: provement in the quality of the explanations

Speaker: NA
Text: from

Speaker: NA
Text: Act submitted. At the same time, experience in

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of the pro forma statement showed

Speaker: NA
Text: a need for further refinement and your

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee is desirous that further dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions occur between it and represen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tatives of the Treasury in this refining

Speaker: NA
Text: process. During the preparation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pro forma statement for use in connection

Speaker: NA
Text: with expenditure from the Advance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, your Committee developed an

Speaker: NA
Text: additional pro forma for use in the exam-

Speaker: NA
Text: ination of items of expenditure where over-

Speaker: NA
Text: estimating had occurred. The use of this

Speaker: NA
Text: pro forma by departments provided us with

Speaker: NA
Text: information on a uniform basis and in each

Speaker: NA
Text: case showed the history of estimating and

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure for a period of three years.

Speaker: NA
Text: As the Seventy-fourth and Seventy-fifth

Speaker: NA
Text: Reports show, your Committee discovered,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the course of its inquiry, several

Speaker: NA
Text: instances in which errors had occurred and

Speaker: NA
Text: had not been detected in time for their

Speaker: NA
Text: correction to be effected in the Additional

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates. Your Committee has commented

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriately on such circumstances where

Speaker: NA
Text: they have occurred and we believe that they

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect adversely on the departments con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned. The inquiry also showed that, as

Speaker: NA
Text: in previous years, there were explanations

Speaker: NA
Text: for variations from the estimate, which, due

Speaker: NA
Text: to unforeseen circumstances, are acceptable.

Speaker: NA
Text: The inquiry also revealed, however, ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: amples of unsatisfactory estimating where

Speaker: NA
Text: over-confident expectations had not been

Speaker: NA
Text: borne out in reality.

Speaker: NA
Text: As in some cases the evidence submitted

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed a lack of appreciation of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderations which should be taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: account by departments in the formulation

Speaker: NA
Text: of their estimates, your Committee has again

Speaker: NA
Text: enunciated in both the Seventy-fourth and

Speaker: NA
Text: Seventy-fifth Reports, the following prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples for departmental guidance-

Speaker: NA
Text: Each particular estimate should comprise

Speaker: NA
Text: a realistic assessment of the amount

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be required, based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: information available to the depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment when the formulation of estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: is being made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates should not make provision for

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals that are of such an un-

Speaker: NA
Text: certain nature that the department is

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to determine what payments, if

Speaker: NA
Text: any, will be made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Experience, wisely evaluated, should be

Speaker: NA
Text: used as the basis for formulating

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates relating to recurring expenses,

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: The use of the Advance to the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: should be confined to those items of

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure which could not have been

Speaker: NA
Text: foreseen in time for their inclusion in

Speaker: NA
Text: the original or Additional Estimates.

Speaker: NA
Text: I commend the reports to honorablo)

Speaker: NA
Text: members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the reports be printed.

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMONWEALTH OFFICES, PERTH.

Speaker: NA
Text: Report of Public Works Committee.

Speaker: Mr BRIMBLECOMBE
Text: Maranoa) -

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, in accordance with the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the Public Works Committee Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1913-1965, I present the report relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: the following proposed work-

Speaker: NA
Text: Erection of Commonwealth Offices, Perth,

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask for leave to make a short statement

Speaker: NA
Text: in connection with the report.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Ther e being no objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, leave is granted.

Speaker: Mr BRIMBLECOMBE
Text: Th e first com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment I should like to make in connection

Speaker: NA
Text: with this report is to emphasise the need

Speaker: NA
Text: for the speedy completion of this building.

Speaker: NA
Text: Relief is urgently required from the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: standard and overcrowded conditions under

Speaker: NA
Text: which the staff of some Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: offices in Perth, such as the Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: Branch, are at present working. The Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: of Census and Statistics is installing a Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol Data 3200 Computer in Perth. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an expensive piece of equipment and unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunately it is to be located in rented space

Speaker: NA
Text: because there is, at this point of time, no

Speaker: NA
Text: suitable accommodation available in a Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth owned building. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: pressing requirement for new accommoda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the computer because the rented

Speaker: NA
Text: space will be too small in about thee years

Speaker: NA
Text: time to accommodate the expanding needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of the working units located adjacent to

Speaker: NA
Text: the computer.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been suggestions in the Perth

Speaker: NA
Text: Press in recent weeks that public money is

Speaker: NA
Text: being wasted by the construction of build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings such as that proposed in this reference.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth Offices are to be

Speaker: NA
Text: finished in quality materials chosen for their

Speaker: NA
Text: durability and ease of maintenance and are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be air conditioned for the comfort of

Speaker: NA
Text: the staff and the public who use them.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this particular point it might be noted

Speaker: NA
Text: that the computer requires space that is air-

Speaker: NA
Text: conditioned on a 24-hour day basis within

Speaker: NA
Text: fine tolerances of humidity and temperature

Speaker: NA
Text: control.

Speaker: NA
Text: The cost of the building is about Â£1,000

Speaker: NA
Text: per square including about Â£200 per square

Speaker: NA
Text: for air conditioning. The Committeee does

Speaker: NA
Text: not consider that at this figure the cost is

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive or that public money is being

Speaker: NA
Text: wasted. For the price the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: will be obtaining a good quality building

Speaker: NA
Text: which will provide comfortable, but not

Speaker: NA
Text: lavish, conditions for the staff and the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic who will use it. Furthermore, this will be

Speaker: NA
Text: a building which will survive the passage

Speaker: NA
Text: of time better than most and of which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the city of Perth will

Speaker: NA
Text: be proud.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ordered that the report be printed.

Text: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1965. undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill returned from the Senate without

Speaker: NA
Text: WEIPA DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-b y leave-presente d by Dr Forbes,

Speaker: NA
Text: and read afirsttime.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Text: Barker-Ministe r for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this Bill is to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of Parliament to an agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Commonwealth and the State

Speaker: NA
Text: of Queensland for the provision of financial

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to the State for harbour works

Speaker: NA
Text: at Weipa in North Queensland. The Comand

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government's decision in this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter was announced in the last Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) when he

Speaker: NA
Text: said that the Commonwealth would provide

Speaker: NA
Text: a loan to the State up to a maximum of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,635,000 to finance these works. He also

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that an amount of Â£750,000 had

Speaker: NA
Text: been provided in the current year's Estimates

Speaker: NA
Text: for this purpose. Agreement has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: reached between the Commonwealth and the

Speaker: NA
Text: State on the conditions on which this assis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance is to be provided, and the text of the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement is set out in the schedule to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I explain the agreement I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like to give the House some general back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground to the development of Weipa,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is situated in a remote corner of north

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland on the western side of Cape

Speaker: NA
Text: York Peninsula. The potential of the bauxite

Speaker: NA
Text: deposits at Weipa wasfirstrecognised by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Chief Geologist of Consolidated Zinc Pty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd. in 1955, and in 1957 a company known

Speaker: NA
Text: as Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation

Speaker: NA
Text: I Ltd -generall y abbreviated to Comalco-

Speaker: NA
Text: was formed to develop the port and to mine

Speaker: NA
Text: bauxite from a lease of an area of about

Speaker: NA
Text: t of 2,380 square miles. Undertakings to this

Speaker: NA
Text: effect were entered into by Comalco in an

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement with the Queensland Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In accordance with its undertakings Comalco

Speaker: NA
Text: dredged an access channel in Albatross Bay,

Speaker: NA
Text: a built a combined export-import berth and

Speaker: NA
Text: established a small mining township at

Speaker: NA
Text: Weipa. Mining, beneficiating and ship load-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing facilities were constructed and the

Speaker: NA
Text: has at present a capacity to

Speaker: NA
Text: handle about 700,000 tons of bauxite

Speaker: NA
Text: per year.

Speaker: NA
Text: An expansion is under way to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1965. the capacity of the undertaking to 2,500,000

Speaker: NA
Text: tons of bauxite each year. About one half

Speaker: NA
Text: of this production will be shipped to Glad-

Speaker: NA
Text: stone for processing into alumina at the

Speaker: NA
Text: refinery being constructed at that centre by

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland Alumina Ltd. The rest of the

Speaker: NA
