Text: production is expected to be exported to

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, Germany, France and South

Speaker: NA
Text: America. In recognition of the importance

Speaker: NA
Text: the of Weipa the Queensland Govemment, in

Speaker: NA
Text: addition to assuming control of the harbour

Speaker: NA
Text: and purchasing the existing harbour works

Speaker: NA
Text: constructed by Comalco, has undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: to deepen the channel and to provide new

Speaker: NA
Text: improved wharves. I am informed that

Speaker: NA
Text: this work will need to be completed by 31st

Speaker: NA
Text: by December 1966, in order to fit in with ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pansion of the Weipa bauxite undertaking

Speaker: NA
Text: and the timetable for construction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: alumina refinery at Gladstone.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Queensland Government requested

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth some time ago to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide nnancial assistance for harbour works

Speaker: NA
Text: at Weipa and Gladstone. After careful con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sideration the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that assistance of up to Â£1,635,000,

Speaker: NA
Text: on a repayable interest-bearing loan basis,

Speaker: NA
Text: would be offered to the State for the har-

Speaker: NA
Text: bour works at Weipa which the State had

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to carry out. The State Government

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted the Commonwealth's offer, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill before the House seeks Parliament's

Speaker: NA
Text: approval of the provision of assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: accordingly. The terms on which the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealthfinancialassistance is to be pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided are set out in the agreement. The

Speaker: NA
Text: agreement provides for payments to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State in respect of expenditure on the har-

Speaker: NA
Text: bour works after lst July 1965. Interest,

Speaker: NA
Text: at the effective long term Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: bond rate, will be capitalised during the

Speaker: NA
Text: period of construction. Repayments will be

Speaker: NA
Text: spread over a period of 30 years, commenc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on 15th July 1967 and will be made

Speaker: NA
Text: on the credit foncier basis of equal instal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments of principal and interest combined.

Speaker: NA
Text: The harbour works towards which the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth loan will be applied are specified

Speaker: NA
Text: in the schedule to the agreement. These

Speaker: NA
Text: works consist of the deepening of the exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing access channel, the building of a wharf

Speaker: NA
Text: for the export of bauxite into bulk carriers,

Speaker: NA
Text: and improvements and additions to the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing general cargo wharf.

Speaker: NA
Text: The agreement also contains the usual

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions included in agreements of this

Speaker: NA
Text: nature relating to such things as the efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: execution of the works, the payment to the

Speaker: NA
Text: State of working advances, the supply of

Speaker: NA
Text: information by the State and the auditing

Speaker: NA
Text: of expenditure. There is also a provision

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing for the variation of the harbour

Speaker: NA
Text: works specified in the schedule to the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tent proposed by the State and approved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Treasurer in the interests of more

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient fulfilment of the objectives of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Agreement. In conclusion, I would like to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that the Governnient is pleased to be

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the project, which will un-

Speaker: NA
Text: doubtedly make a major contribution not

Speaker: NA
Text: only to the development of an important

Speaker: NA
Text: new industry but also to the development

Speaker: NA
Text: of a particularly remote northern corner of

Speaker: NA
Text: our vast continent. I commend the Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Luchetti)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: SUSPENSION OF STANDING ORDERS.

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Dr Forbes) agreed to-

Speaker: NA
Text: That so much of the standing orders be sus-

Speaker: NA
Text: pended as would prevent two further Bills relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to Decimal Currency-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) being presented and read a first time

Speaker: NA
Text: together and one motion being moved

Speaker: NA
Text: for the second readings; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) being included for the purposes of later

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration with the thirty other Bills

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to Decimal Currency which are

Speaker: NA
Text: set own for resumption of debate on

Speaker: NA
Text: the second readings together.

Speaker: NA
Text: PAY-ROLL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 25th November

Speaker: NA
Text: (vide page 3191), on motion by Mr Harold

Speaker: NA
Text: Holt-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Melbourne Ports) [3.44].

Speaker: NA
Text: - I wish to indicate at the start that whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposition agrees with the material in

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill it intends in the committee stage

Speaker: NA
Text: to move an amendment the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: which will be to exempt from the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of payroll tax municipal or other local

Speaker: NA
Text: governing bodies or an authority established

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of carrying out all or any

Speaker: NA
Text: of the functions ordinarily carried out by

Speaker: NA
Text: such a body otherwise than in the conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: of an enterprise which in the opinion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commissioner is a trading enterprise. I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall outline the purpose of the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: later but I wish to indicate that it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition's intention to move that amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the committee stage when we are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing with clause 3. The Bill amends the

Speaker: NA
Text: Pay-Roll Tax Assessment Act to facilitate

Speaker: NA
Text: the application of a rebate system in

Speaker: NA
Text: connection with the pay-roll tax which

Speaker: NA
Text: applies when certain firms increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of goods they are producing which

Speaker: NA
Text: are sold overseas. This sort of measure is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary apparently because of the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitments which Australia has to such

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies as the General Agreement on Tariffs

Speaker: NA
Text: and Trade which provides that the member

Speaker: NA
Text: countries shall not discriminate in their

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing laws so as to favour an exporter as

Speaker: NA
Text: against other producers in an economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently the only way that this provision

Speaker: NA
Text: can be avoided is to remit certain taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: which technically are described as indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than direct taxes. Payroll tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: regarded as being an indirect and not a

Speaker: NA
Text: direct form of tax. Details along these lines

Speaker: NA
Text: are to be found in a publication by Her

Speaker: NA
Text: Majesty's Stationery Office of 1964 dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with the report of the Committee on Turn-

Speaker: NA
Text: over Taxation to which I will refer later in

Speaker: NA
Text: my speech. In essence, the report points

Speaker: NA
Text: out that as long as a tax is an indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than a direct tax some manipulation

Speaker: NA
Text: of it can be made to assist the promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: of exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: All I wish to draw attention to is the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it is, in my view, rather an unsatis-

Speaker: NA
Text: factory method of dealing with this prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem. We can all agree that Australia has to

Speaker: NA
Text: build up increased export markets. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: been estimated, I think, that we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase our exports in total by some Â£200

Speaker: NA
Text: million per annum over the next seven or

Speaker: NA
Text: eight years if our economy is to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to be able to support the levels of imports

Speaker: NA
Text: to which we have allowed ourselves to

Speaker: NA
Text: become dependent. Using payroll tax as

Speaker: NA
Text: a medium for this increase seems to me to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a fairly inadequate and precarious way

Speaker: NA
Text: of going about things. I direct the attention

Speaker: NA
Text: of honorable members to statistics which

Speaker: NA
Text: are contained in the most recent annual

Speaker: NA
Text: report of the Commissioner of Taxation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to taxation statistics for 1963-64

Speaker: NA
Text: which are part of the 44th annual report

Speaker: NA
Text: to Parliament of the Commissioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation. At page 155 of this document are

Speaker: NA
Text: to be found details of the rebate of payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax on export trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report shows that, for the year

Speaker: NA
Text: 1960-61, 924 separate undertakings were

Speaker: NA
Text: allowed this rebate. These firms between

Speaker: NA
Text: them had paid Â£11,353,000 in payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and were entitled as the result of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the existing legislation to total

Speaker: NA
Text: rebates of payroll tax of Â£2,166,000. In

Speaker: NA
Text: 196162 the number of claims allowed had

Speaker: NA
Text: increased to 1,034 and the payroll tax paid

Speaker: NA
Text: by those concerned was Â£10,400,000. The

Speaker: NA
Text: rebates of payroll tax allowed totalled

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,503,000. In 1962-63 the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: claims allowed dropped to 966. The 966

Speaker: NA
Text: firms concerned had paid Â£9,021,000 in

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax and were entitled to rebates of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,685,000- a fall of some Â£800,000

Speaker: NA
Text: against the rebate entitlement figure for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1961-62. The 1963-64 figures are not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in this report. What I draw attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to is that in terms of export trade as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole the figures are really fairly insub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial. In 1962-63 the figure shows an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in export trade of Â£164 million

Speaker: NA
Text: over the two base years ended June 1960.

Speaker: NA
Text: That increase is much less than the increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia's export trade that we need

Speaker: NA
Text: year by year if we are to survive. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: other export encouragements are given in

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. For instance firms which spend

Speaker: NA
Text: money on advertising their goods in poten-

Speaker: NA
Text: tial export income markets are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: double tax deductions on expenditure on

Speaker: NA
Text: advertising which is applicable to that form

Speaker: NA
Text: of trade. That is another device which has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made but, again, there are serious

Speaker: NA
Text: limitations in respect of how far a country

Speaker: NA
Text: can move in this kind of concession by

Speaker: NA
Text: reason of the commitments which it has

Speaker: NA
Text: under G.A.T.T. and other provisions.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come now to the report of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee on Turnover Taxation to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: referred earlier. Paragraph 186 on page 57

Speaker: NA
Text: states-

Speaker: NA
Text: For reasons which will appear below, the

Speaker: NA
Text: choice of possible methods of assessing a value-

Speaker: NA
Text: added tax would have to take account of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Kingdom's obligations under two inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national agreements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Only one of the agreements referred to

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to Australia. The two agreements

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned are the General Agreement on

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariffs and Trade, which is referred to rather

Speaker: NA
Text: popularly as G.A.T.T. and the other one in

Speaker: NA
Text: the case of the United Kingdom is the

Speaker: NA
Text: European Free Trade Area Convention,

Speaker: NA
Text: which does not concern us. The report con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinues-

Speaker: NA
Text: We summarise the relevant provisions of these

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements in Appendix Â£. They preclude various

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of export subsidy, including subsidies which

Speaker: NA
Text: operate through the taxation system. Briefly,

Speaker: NA
Text: certain "kinds" of taxes, and in particular direct

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes on businesses, may not be remitted in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of exports. The taxes which may be remitted or

Speaker: NA
Text: repaid are:-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) taxes charged at importation, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: customs duties, and

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) other indirect taxes on the goods exported;

Speaker: NA
Text: and then the " amount" of any repayment may

Speaker: NA
Text: not exceed what has effectively been levied at

Speaker: NA
Text: one or more stages on the goods. These obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: are relevant because the advocates of the value-

Speaker: NA
Text: added tax have assumed that it would be remitted

Speaker: NA
Text: on exports . . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The point there, of course, is that as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as Australia is concerned payroll tax has

Speaker: NA
Text: been chosen as the medium to apply this

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy because it is an indirect tax. This

Speaker: NA
Text: method, however, suffers from the

Speaker: NA
Text: deficiency that a form of export trade

Speaker: NA
Text: which is, say, capital intensive rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: labour intensive, is more or less at a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage because the maximum amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate which is available is the amount rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resented by the payroll tax, which is at the

Speaker: NA
Text: rate of only 2 i per cent, or 6d. in the

Speaker: NA
Text: the wages bill of the particular undertaking.

Speaker: NA
Text: A highly mechanised industry, of course, has

Speaker: NA
Text: a relatively small labour component in its

Speaker: NA
Text: total cost, but the amount of subsidy that

Speaker: NA
Text: it can obtain is governed by the payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. There could be firms which perform

Speaker: NA
Text: as well as other firms in terms of increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: exports but which, having a very small

Speaker: NA
Text: labour component in their total costs, would

Speaker: NA
Text: find it very difficult to obtain any appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciable benefit from this kind of assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are other firms, of course, with high

Speaker: NA
Text: labour contents in their total costs and

Speaker: NA
Text: these would receive a considerable advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the amendment proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Bill before us is to correct an

Speaker: NA
Text: anomaly which has been discovered in the

Speaker: NA
Text: operation of the tax rebate scheme as it

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to the motor vehicle industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular. Apparently the difficulty has

Speaker: NA
Text: been that in applying the rebate to what

Speaker: NA
Text: are called knocked down vehicles as dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinct from built up vehicles, the knocked

Speaker: NA
Text: down vehicles have been somewhat at a

Speaker: NA
Text: disadvantage. The Act, as it is currently

Speaker: NA
Text: written, does not appear to cover trade

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked down vehicles. The amendment is

Speaker: NA
Text: designed to overcome this difficulty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course many countries are doing, with

Speaker: NA
Text: respect to their motor vehicle industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: what Australia is trying to do today. They

Speaker: NA
Text: are endeavouring to build up an industry of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own. They are endeavouring to have

Speaker: NA
Text: as low as possible a foreign component

Speaker: NA
Text: their vehicles and as high as possible

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of locally made parts. New

Speaker: NA
Text: Zealand, Indonesia and some Asian and that

Speaker: NA
Text: South East Asian countries, in which Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has been developing a market for

Speaker: NA
Text: these goods, say: "We are quite happy

Speaker: NA
Text: take Australian motor cars but we would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to do some of the assembling ourselves."

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently the law as it currently economic affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: operates places partially assembled vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: or unassembled parts at some disadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: in this trade, in that they do not qualify

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rebate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another factor that must be considered,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, is that unassembled vehicles take

Speaker: NA
Text: up far less space than assembled vehicles.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a big saving in freight charges if

Speaker: NA
Text: parts are packed together for shipping and

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled in the country of destination.

Speaker: NA
Text: With a fully assembled vehicle, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1 on a good deal of the space taken up on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ship is the space that would normally be

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied by the passengers when the motor

Speaker: NA
Text: car was on the road. To pay freight on

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis of space occupied by fully

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled vehicles is a rather extravagant

Speaker: NA
Text: way of exporting them.

Speaker: NA
Text: In order to overcome these two kinds of

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulties this amendment is being intro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced. Apparently at the same time the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government is trying to secure an internal

Speaker: NA
Text: reform that the motor vehicle industry has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a little reluctant to introduce. I refer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the objective of an Australian com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of 90 to 95 per cent, in locally

Speaker: NA
Text: assembled vehicles. One of the conditions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the application of this new benefit is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be a satisfactory level of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian content in the local production and

Speaker: NA
Text: that there should also be a satisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: proportion of Australian-made exports as

Speaker: NA
Text: against imports which are later exported.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the objective is to be achieved some

Speaker: NA
Text: discretion must be allowed. I have heard

Speaker: NA
Text: many rather nasty things said in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: in the last day or two about the discretion

Speaker: NA
Text: in of the Commissioner of Taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Apparently in this case the discretion is not

Speaker: NA
Text: to be exercised by the Commissioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation but by the Secretary of the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of Trade and Industry in conjunc-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion with the Treasurer. Just what the

Speaker: NA
Text: medium of communication between thc two

Speaker: NA
Text: of them is I am not quite sure, but I suppose

Speaker: NA
Text: it would not be difficult to establish. In

Speaker: NA
Text: in any case it is on the recommendation of

Speaker: NA
Text: a the Secretary of the Department of Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: and Industry, confirmed by the Treasurer,

Speaker: NA
Text: a firm will or will not be deemed eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rebate under the amended legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: to One would perhaps think that there ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a little more discretion rather than a

Speaker: NA
Text: little less of it in the operation of modern

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelly -I f it does not go too far.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Well , one can perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: carry discretion too far, and I suppose one

Speaker: NA
Text: should not indulge at all in indiscretion. But

Speaker: NA
Text: it seems to me that sometimes when this

Speaker: NA
Text: nasty word " discretion " is used the impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation is that it will always be applied in-

Speaker: NA
Text: discretely. This is not my experience of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner of Taxation, however. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think he is a sort of inverted Micawber,

Speaker: NA
Text: waiting for something to turn down. He

Speaker: NA
Text: exercises his discretion, as far as he can,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interest of the person concerned just

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as in the interest of the preserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the revenue.

Speaker: NA
Text: So much for this aspect of the Bill. 1 re-

Speaker: NA
Text: peat that this is a rather unsatisfactory,

Speaker: NA
Text: and corner method of going about subsidis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing exports. It has distinct limitations. No

Speaker: NA
Text: matter how successful one may be in pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: moting one's exports, the maximum amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of rebate available to one's firm is

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount of the payroll tax, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is 2 i per cent, of the wages bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: So that if wages represented only

Speaker: NA
Text: half of the total costs, there would

Speaker: NA
Text: be only a rather minor overall incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: available. In this connection, however, I

Speaker: NA
Text: must remind the House that the whole of

Speaker: NA
Text: the rebate allowed, as represented by the

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax payable, will be applied in the

Speaker: NA
Text: direction of the export trade rather than of

Speaker: NA
Text: the total turnover of the company, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps the advantages are a little more

Speaker: NA
Text: significant than they appear.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the Treasurer said in his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech that for the year ended

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1965 the total value of motor car

Speaker: NA
Text: exports was about Â£16 million. The figure

Speaker: NA
Text: for completely assembled vehicles was, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think, Â£8.3 million, and the value of partly

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked down vehicles and components

Speaker: NA
Text: was Â£7.7 million. I think the Treasurer also

Speaker: NA
Text: directed attention to the fact that over a

Speaker: NA
Text: comparatively small number of years our

Speaker: NA
Text: exports of motor vehicles and components

Speaker: NA
Text: were very similar to our exports of wheaten

Speaker: NA
Text: flour. The flour industry has been in exist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence for a long time, and I think in many

Speaker: NA
Text: respects it does not really afford a relevant

Speaker: NA
Text: comparison. I believe that many countries

Speaker: NA
Text: are doing with flour what they are doing

Speaker: NA
Text: with motor cars. They prefer to import their

Speaker: NA
Text: own wheat and make their own flour, for

Speaker: NA
Text: they then build up an industry that is much

Speaker: NA
Text: needed in underdeveloped countries. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer made the point that exports of

Speaker: NA
Text: motor cars and components were becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: a quite significant part of Australia's export

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting to note, when one looks

Speaker: NA
Text: at the details of the statistics provided by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commissioner of Taxation, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: major beneficiary of this payroll tax rebate

Speaker: NA
Text: is the metals, metal manufactures and

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery group of industries which, pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumably, includes the motor car industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: In thefinancialyear 1960-61, out of rebates

Speaker: NA
Text: totalling Â£2,166,000, Â£736,000, or slightly

Speaker: NA
Text: more than one third, went to that group

Speaker: NA
Text: of industries. In 1961-62 Â£2,130,000 out of

Speaker: NA
Text: a total of Â£3,503,000 went to that group.

Speaker: NA
Text: This was nearly two thirds of the total. In

Speaker: NA
Text: hole 1962-63 the proportion had dropped to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,166,000 out of Â£2,685,000. Apparently

Speaker: NA
Text: in that financial year there was relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: a slump in the export performance of that

Speaker: NA
Text: branch of industry. This, of course, may

Speaker: NA
Text: have had something to do with conditions

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas or may even have been the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of retaliatory measures taken by some

Speaker: NA
Text: countries that had formerly accepted ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports of metals, metal manufactures and

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery without introducing tariff diffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: culties. I understand that Japan, for in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, has a fairly high tariff on imports

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian motor vehicles and parts. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know what the arrangement in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia concerning Japanese car imports is,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Japanese car industry seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: having increasing success in capturing a

Speaker: NA
Text: section of the Australian market.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have pointed out, the payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate suffers from the other deficiency that

Speaker: NA
Text: its benefits are limited by the wage com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent in total costs. Therefore, to some

Speaker: NA
Text: extent the capital intensive industries are

Speaker: NA
Text: at a disadvantage compared to the labour

Speaker: NA
Text: intensive industries. Surely we in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: should be encouraging capital intensive

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than labour intensive industries. I

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that the Treasury will further consider

Speaker: NA
Text: this question of the encouragement of ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports, bearing in mind the distinct limitations

Speaker: NA
Text: that apply under the General Agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: on Tariffs and Trade. This form of assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance represented by the rebate in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of payroll tax is rather inadequate when we

Speaker: NA
Text: contemplate the increase in export trade

Speaker: NA
Text: that Australia needs in the years ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: At this stage I should like to discuss the

Speaker: NA
Text: general position of the payroll tax as it

Speaker: NA
Text: applies in our tax structure. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget estimates which were presented

Speaker: NA
Text: to us by the Treasurer at the beginning of

Speaker: NA
Text: this sessional period and with which we

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt not very long ago in this chamber,

Speaker: NA
Text: the right honorable gentleman contem-

Speaker: NA
Text: plated that in the current financial year the

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax would yield a total of Â£82

Speaker: NA
Text: million. Excluding from consideration items

Speaker: NA
Text: such as the Post Office-th e self balancing

Speaker: NA
Text: items-th e payroll tax was estimated to be

Speaker: NA
Text: responsible for Â£82 million out of total

Speaker: NA
Text: tax collections of about Â£2,200,000, or a

Speaker: NA
Text: little more than 3 per cent, of the total. In

Speaker: NA
Text: many respects, the payroll tax represents

Speaker: NA
Text: an unsatisfactory form of tax. However

Speaker: NA
Text: fortunate may be the application of the

Speaker: NA
Text: export rebate, this is a most unsatisfactory

Speaker: NA
Text: form of tax for any modern society to rely

Speaker: NA
Text: on. It came into being in 1941 to finance

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of child endowment. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: that in some respects it is still in theory

Speaker: NA
Text: tied to that benefit. In practice, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: all the money is paid into one fund-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Consolidated Revenue Fund. The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner of Taxation, in his 44th report,

Speaker: NA
Text: at page 81, stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: The rate of payroll tax has remained unchanged

Speaker: NA
Text: since its introduction and is Â£2 10s. per centum

Speaker: NA
Text: of wages in excess of the general exemption.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, this represents a tax of

Speaker: NA
Text: 6d. in the Â£1 on the wage bill of all those

Speaker: NA
Text: employers that are liable to pay it. Referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to the payroll tax legislation the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: missioner stated-

Speaker: NA
Text: A feature of the legislation is the wide scope

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tax. Exemptions are limited to wages paid

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Governor-General

Speaker: NA
Text: Presumably for his own staff-

Speaker: NA
Text: or the Governor of a State, the representatives in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia of the Governments of other countries,

Speaker: NA
Text: public hospitals and certain other hospitals, public

Speaker: NA
Text: benevolent and religious institutions and a few

Speaker: NA
Text: specified organisations such as the South Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. Wages paid to members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force and certain ancillary services are

Speaker: NA
Text: also exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is specifically provided that the Crown in the

Speaker: NA
Text: right of a State, municipal and other local

Speaker: NA
Text: ing bodies and public authorities which do not

Speaker: NA
Text: pay wages from the Consolidated Revenue Fund,

Speaker: NA
Text: are liable for payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is the matter with which the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that we propose to submit in Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee will be concerned. What the Commis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sioner of Taxation did not say in his report

Speaker: NA
Text: was that the Commonwealth Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: own wage bill is specifically exempt from

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax. The Commissioner used the words

Speaker: NA
Text: " the Crown in the right of a State ". The

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown in the right of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: does not pay the tax. I believe that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a certain legitimate ground for grievance

Speaker: NA
Text: on the part of the States over the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth's exempting itself from the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of payroll tax on its wages and specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: providing that the States shall pay the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on the wage bill concerned with their own

Speaker: NA
Text: administration. I suppose that it may be

Speaker: NA
Text: argued: The States may collectively pay

Speaker: NA
Text: some Â£6 million or Â£8 million in tax in this

Speaker: NA
Text: way but if they did not do so they would

Speaker: NA
Text: only receive Â£6 million or Â£8 million less

Speaker: NA
Text: in reimbursements under the formula

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted under the uniform tax arrange-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. That may seem a consoling aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter, but it seems to me to represent

Speaker: NA
Text: a rather silly form of bookkeeping for one

Speaker: NA
Text: to go to all the trouble of imposing a tax

Speaker: NA
Text: of 6d. in the Â£1 on the wage bills of the

Speaker: NA
Text: States and then to say that they are really

Speaker: NA
Text: reimbursed under the overall uniform tax

Speaker: NA
Text: formula for the sums so paid. This seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a silly way of going about the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: A similar sort of escape is not available

Speaker: NA
Text: to municipal authorities. I turn to what are

Speaker: NA
Text: described in the taxation statistics provided

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Commissioner of Taxation as a

Speaker: NA
Text: supplement to his 44th report as " Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Authority Activities (n.e.i.)". This ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: parently means that they are not elsewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: included. There is a special section for

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity, gas and water services, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are subject to public authority ownership.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the purposes of payroll tax statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: they are treated separately. The section

Speaker: NA
Text: given over to public authority activities

Speaker: NA
Text: relates mainly to State administrations plus

Speaker: NA
Text: local government and semi-government acti-

Speaker: NA
Text: vities not related to business undertakings.

Speaker: NA
Text: The figures at page 152 of the taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics show that in June 1964 there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 854 payroll tax returns lodged by

Speaker: NA
Text: employers in this group and that the wage

Speaker: NA
Text: bill of the group in that month totalled

Speaker: NA
Text: govern- Â£40,088,000. This represents about Â£480

Speaker: NA
Text: million annually. That is about one seventh

Speaker: NA
Text: of the total amount of wages on which pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax is collected.

Speaker: NA
Text: Statistics show that for the month of

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1964 the total wages on which pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax was levied was Â£286,923,000 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the component of that amount representing

Speaker: NA
Text: public authority activities was about Â£40

Speaker: NA
Text: million. This year the estimated collection

Speaker: NA
Text: of payroll tax will be Â£82 million. At a

Speaker: NA
Text: rough guess one seventh of that amount-

Speaker: NA
Text: somewhere in the region of Â£12 million-

Speaker: NA
Text: will be collected by the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: from public authority activities. Let us ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude from consideration the part that be-

Speaker: NA
Text: longs to the States as such in the sense of

Speaker: NA
Text: their own direct administration which is

Speaker: NA
Text: rather consolingly looked after in the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: reimbursement arrangements. That leaves

Speaker: NA
Text: about Â£6 million to be borne by the munici-

Speaker: NA
Text: palities and other forms of activity in the

Speaker: NA
Text: -community. Then looking at the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: people concerned, I think it is rather sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: prising to see the total employment in

Speaker: NA
Text: public authority activities

Speaker: NA
Text: tive level, excluding the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report shows that at June 1964 there

Speaker: NA
Text: were 337,000 such employees, 251,000 of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom were males and 86,000 of whom

Speaker: NA
Text: were females. There is a fair body of people

Speaker: NA
Text: in this field. Of course, the only place that

Speaker: NA
Text: the municipalities can go to obtain funds

Speaker: NA
Text: with which to pay the tax is to their rate-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers.

Speaker: NA
Text: One of the difficulties in government

Speaker: NA
Text: today is that local government seems to bc

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming the poor relation in the adminis-

Speaker: NA
Text: trative hierarchy. We have three levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: government-Commonwealth , State and

Speaker: NA
Text: local government-an d basically the local

Speaker: NA
Text: government authority relies on a rather anti-

Speaker: NA
Text: quated property system of rating. In many

Speaker: NA
Text: respects it is a very inequitable form of

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue raising, but in aggregate the munici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pal authorities have this additional burden

Speaker: NA
Text: of about Â£5 or Â£6 million imposed on

Speaker: NA
Text: them by reason of the uncharitable policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Federal Government. If this tax of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£5 to Â£6 million were not imposed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth, it could well adjust the

Speaker: NA
Text: loss of revenue by more equitable methods

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxation. If the Commonwealth did not

Speaker: NA
Text: impose this tax the various municipalities

Speaker: NA
Text: and other semi-governmental bodies in the

Speaker: NA
Text: community would have this additional sum

Speaker: NA
Text: with which to provide services for their

Speaker: NA
Text: payers or their various constituent members.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have talked of this amendment for

Speaker: NA
Text: many years in this House. I think as far

Speaker: NA
Text: back as 1956 or 1957 we moved a similar

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment because we believed that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was a silly, messy, inefficient way of col-

Speaker: NA
Text: lecting revenue and that it put an unneces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary penalty on a very important section of

Speaker: NA
Text: community activity which had no recourse

Speaker: NA
Text: to meeting it other than by raising rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: Local governments are still called upon to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide many important functions. As an

Speaker: NA
Text: example, let us consider the average muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipality in the metropolitan area which

Speaker: NA
Text: might employ between 300 and 500 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The municipality could well have a wages

Speaker: NA
Text: bill in the region of Â£500,000 to Â£1 million,

Speaker: NA
Text: and 2 i per cent, of that is about Â£25,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not believe that I know of any muni-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipality that could not do a great deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: that Â£25,000. I believe that municipalities

Speaker: NA
Text: could apply that Â£25,000 more efficiently

Speaker: NA
Text: than the central government could apply

Speaker: NA
Text: the Â£6 million that it receives from those

Speaker: NA
Text: at the administravarious bodies.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that one of the difficulties that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are suffering from in our governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: system at the moment is the kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: marginal starvation at the State and local

Speaker: NA
Text: government boundaries. Where such things

Speaker: NA
Text: as baby health services or greater provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for library services are required, to take just

Speaker: NA
Text: a couple of examples, local government

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies are often looking about for sums as

Speaker: NA
Text: small as a few hundred pounds and, cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly, a few thousand pounds would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: very welcome bonus to most of them with

Speaker: NA
Text: which I have had any experience. We there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore urge the Government to take a serious

Speaker: NA
Text: look once more at the whole question of

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax. I hope that some day this tax

Speaker: NA
Text: will be abolished because it seems to me

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a very silly form of taxation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed at a flat per centum rate, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that it has remained unchanged since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1941 when it was introduced simply points

Speaker: NA
Text: to the fact that it is regarded as an easy

Speaker: NA
Text: way of raising Â£80 million. But it is cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly inequitable in its application. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: applied whether or not an undertaking is

Speaker: NA
Text: successful. It is not like company tax. At

Speaker: NA
Text: least that tax is levied only if the concern

Speaker: NA
Text: makes a profit. If an industry in a country

Speaker: NA
Text: town or somewhere else were struggling to

Speaker: NA
Text: survive it might be given some relief if

Speaker: NA
Text: rateit were relieved of its payroll tax burden.

Speaker: NA
Text: This tax falls heaviest on the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: which employs the most labour, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: applies irrespective of the state of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: No matter where we live, in the smallest

Speaker: NA
Text: municipality or the biggest, we are still

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians and we should be able to have

Speaker: NA
Text: the same sorts of standards from one part

Speaker: NA
Text: to the other. But the harsh application of

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe payroll tax is a real impediment in some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the smaller municipalities. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested, often the services languish just

Speaker: NA
Text: for the sake of a few hundred or a few

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand pounds. I urge the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: to realise that it is time it gave serious

Speaker: NA
Text: thought to whether the whole structure of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation should be reconsidered, but in par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticular that it should contemplate anew the

Speaker: NA
Text: necessity to continue the payroll tax. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: if it does not want to take the courageous

Speaker: NA
Text: step of abolishing the tax all at once, at

Speaker: NA
Text: least it could move in the right direction

Speaker: NA
Text: here as it is moving in the right direction

Speaker: NA
Text: with the export bounty. It could remove the

Speaker: NA
Text: tax as it applies to municipal and other local

Speaker: NA
Text: governing bodies. I shall formally move

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment in Committee. Meanwhile,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have foreshadowed it and have outlined

Speaker: NA
Text: the detailed case upon which we base our

Speaker: NA
Text: suggestion. We do not oppose the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the measure as they apply to the

Speaker: NA
Text: export bounty, but we would like to see

Speaker: NA
Text: the extension of the exemption to cover

Speaker: NA
Text: not only the Commonwealth as such in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of its employees but also municipal

Speaker: NA
Text: and local government bodies.

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Text: Barker-Ministe r for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army) [4.25] -Befor e the second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: debate goes any further, I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: take the opportunity of indicating the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's attitude to the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadowed by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports ( Mr Crean). The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is unable to accept the amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As is clear from the terms of the amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, it seeks to exempt from payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: wages that are paid by local government

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities and comparable bodies where the

Speaker: NA
Text: wages are not paid in respect of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of a trading enterprise.

Speaker: NA
Text: This proposal has very serious revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: implications. Indeed, as I shall show, it has

Speaker: NA
Text: serious implications in connection with the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of Commonwealth-State financial

Speaker: NA
Text: relations. If implemented, it would involve

Speaker: NA
Text: substantial losses of revenue. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable members that the payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: base is a very wide one. Payroll tax is a

Speaker: NA
Text: levy on all employers whose payrolls

Speaker: NA
Text: exceed Â£10,400 per annum, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: exception of government, vice-regal and.

Speaker: NA
Text: diplomatic establishments, public benevo-

Speaker: NA
Text: lent and religious institutions, public

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals. Commonwealth authorities-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: wages of which are paid out of the Consoli-

Speaker: NA
Text: dated Revenue Fund, as mentioned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Melbourne Ports-

Speaker: NA
Text: and certain international organisations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will agree that this

Speaker: NA
Text: makes the payroll tax base a very wide one

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed.

Speaker: NA
Text: States and their authorities are liable to

Speaker: NA
Text: the tax. On the face of it, the proposal con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained in the amendment foreshadowed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Melbourne Ports

Speaker: NA
Text: would seem to be a fairly simple one, but

Speaker: NA
Text: in practice there would be difficulty in de-

Speaker: NA
Text: fining trading activities and in distinguish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing trading from non-trading activities of

Speaker: NA
Text: local authorities. Further, the functions per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formed by local authorities vary consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ably from State to State. If, therefore, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's proposal were

Speaker: NA
Text: accepted it would be difficult to justify

Speaker: NA
Text: refusing to extend similar exemptions to

Speaker: NA
Text: State Governments and their semi-govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: mental authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honorable members will see the point.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, State authorities in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia do not conduct many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities which are conducted by local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities in Queensland. I mention

Speaker: NA
Text: sewerage services by way of illustration. It

Speaker: NA
Text: would therefore be quite inequitable that

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax should not be levied on a local

Speaker: NA
Text: authority in Queensland but should be

Speaker: NA
Text: levied on a semi-governmental authority

Speaker: NA
Text: which provides a sewerage service in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Needless to say, the granting of

Speaker: NA
Text: widespread exemptions of this type would

Speaker: NA
Text: lead to a considerable loss of revenue, and,

Speaker: NA
Text: all other things being equal, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth would have to seek to replace this

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue from other sources. It is estimated

Speaker: NA
Text: that the cost for a full year of exempting

Speaker: NA
Text: local government bodies from payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: would be of the order of Â£2.9 million. If

Speaker: NA
Text: the exemption were to be extended to semi-

Speaker: NA
Text: governmental authorities, the cost might be

Speaker: NA
Text: as high as Â£13 million. Against that last

Speaker: NA
Text: figure I set the estimated payroll tax collec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the current year. As mentioned by

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Melbourne Ports,

Speaker: NA
Text: it is Â£82 million. Therefore, the possible loss

Speaker: NA
Text: of revenue to the Commonwealth would be

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£13 million out of Â£82 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I have said, this proposal would have

Speaker: NA
Text: serious implications for Commonwealth-

Speaker: NA
Text: State financial relations. Under both the

Speaker: NA
Text: 1959 arrangements and those entered into

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, financial assistance grants are

Speaker: NA
Text: being provided to the States expressly on

Speaker: NA
Text: the understanding that there will be no

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the financial arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: between the Commonwealth on the one

Speaker: NA
Text: hand and the States and their authorities on

Speaker: NA
Text: the other, and, in particular, no change in

Speaker: NA
Text: the liability of the States and their

Speaker: NA
Text: ties to payroll tax. It was, of course, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tended that this understanding would cover

Speaker: NA
Text: local authorities which are constituted under

Speaker: NA
Text: the laws of the States. This was agreed to

Speaker: NA
Text: hy the State Premiers at conferences at

Speaker: NA
Text: which the financial assistance arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: were negotiated. In other words, the finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial arrangements between the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and the States are based on a

Speaker: NA
Text: specific understanding, arrived at after

Speaker: NA
Text: cussions, that local authorities will pay payoutside

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment foreshadowed by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Melbourne Ports

Speaker: NA
Text: would certainly alter this position. If it

Speaker: NA
Text: to the granting of wider exemptions, it

Speaker: NA
Text: would seriously prejudice the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements governing financial assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: grants. Honorable members may care to

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the document " Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Payments to or for the States, 1965-66",

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented at the time when he presented the

Speaker: NA
Text: last Budget. On pages 14 to 16 of this docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, the Treasurer explains the basis of

Speaker: NA
Text: the arrangements governingfinancialassist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance grants. I say this additionally to my

Speaker: NA
Text: point about the discussions which have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken place from time to time between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and the States on the

Speaker: NA
Text: financial assistance arrangements. I regret

Speaker: NA
Text: that when the amendment is ultimately

Speaker: NA
Text: moved the Government will not be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept it.

Speaker: Mr MORTIMER
Text: Grey) [4.31] - I find

Speaker: NA
Text: it extremely regrettable that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has already intimated that it will not accept

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment foreshadowed by the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne Ports ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Crean). I found it difficult to follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: argument submitted by the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Army (Dr Forbes), but no doubt by the

Speaker: NA
Text: time we discuss the Bill in committee we

Speaker: NA
Text: shall have had an opportunity to study thc

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's speech and probably we shall

Speaker: NA
Text: know exactly the point he is trying to make.

Speaker: NA
Text: My thoughts on the amendment were that it

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed only the exemption of local

Speaker: NA
Text: governing bodies from the payment of pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax. I think the Minister was trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: confuse the issue when he made his speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation now before the House is

Speaker: NA
Text: aimed at providing further incentives and

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to exporters and has been made

Speaker: NA
Text: authorinecessary because the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: finally come to the conclusion that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been sadly lacking in providing sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: leadership and encouragement to manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers to enter the export market with

Speaker: NA
Text: the products of our secondary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: With a few notable exceptions, either

Speaker: NA
Text: because of patent restrictions or a very dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinct reluctance on the part of manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: to take the risks and the responsibilities of

Speaker: NA
Text: dis- searching out and supplying fresh markets

Speaker: NA
Text: of the mainland, sufficient considera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion has not been given to building up our

Speaker: NA
Text: export trade with the products of our

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary industries. We on this side of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House believe that the Government must

Speaker: NA
Text: led give more generous encouragement not only

Speaker: NA
Text: to furthering the exports of secondary indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries but also to the expansion of established

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises and the development of new

Speaker: NA
Text: industries within the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: Great credit must go to the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Scientific and Industrial Research

Speaker: NA
Text: Organisation, which has made notable con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributions to the improvement of both our

Speaker: NA
Text: secondary and primary industries, but

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has reached a stage where the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth must take on the responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of planning on national lines for the

Speaker: NA
Text: development of secondary industries,

Speaker: NA
Text: because the tremendous decisions that have

Speaker: NA
Text: now to be faced cannot be solved by States

Speaker: NA
Text: or individual businesses. Many of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunities to start new enterprises or to

Speaker: NA
Text: exploit our natural mineral and other

Speaker: NA
Text: resources are lost to Australian ownership

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the reluctance or inability of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian enterprise to assume the initial

Speaker: NA
Text: risk, or because we do not possess technical

Speaker: NA
Text: advisers capable or willing of appraising and

Speaker: NA
Text: advising on the opportunities that are now

Speaker: NA
Text: open to Australian capital. The Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: of Economic Enquiry has delved very

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughly into this particular subject, and

Speaker: NA
Text: although the Government seems loath to

Speaker: NA
Text: give any real credence to many aspects of

Speaker: NA
Text: the report, it must admit that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee was stating plain common truth and

Speaker: NA
Text: fact when it suggested that a body similar to

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Economic Development Council

Speaker: NA
Text: of the United Kingdom, the Economic

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of Canada and similar bodies in

Speaker: NA
Text: other major exporting countries should be

Speaker: NA
Text: set up in Australia. Such a body, if set up

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia, could consult with and advise

Speaker: NA
Text: industry and the Government on what was

Speaker: NA
Text: economically possible and of the dangers

Speaker: NA
Text: that must be avoided or overcome. More

Speaker: NA
Text: and more are we made aware of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestion that is taking place in our cities and

Speaker: NA
Text: of the absolute need for decentralisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: We kuow of the uncertain outlook in world

Speaker: NA
Text: markets for some of our primary products.

Speaker: NA
Text: We read statistical forecasts of our labour

Speaker: NA
Text: potential if the present rate of immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: is continued, and many students and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentators forecast the need for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industry to develop so that our future work

Speaker: NA
Text: force can be employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The rapidly improving technology of pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary production, and its ability to produce

Speaker: NA
Text: greater quantities with a much reduced work

Speaker: NA
Text: force, throws the additional burden of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: viding employment for our quickly expand-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing work force on to secondary industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government. We are forced, for purely

Speaker: NA
Text: economic reasons, with the absolute neces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity of increasing work opportunity in other

Speaker: NA
Text: fields open to us. In an address delivered

Speaker: NA
Text: at the National Press Club luncheon in

Speaker: NA
Text: which he countered criticism of the Vernon

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee, of which he was a member, Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: John Crawford said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Taking a view of export prospects, it was con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluded that a major effort would have to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase manufactured exports, if export returns

Speaker: NA
Text: were to be adequate to meet the likely growth

Speaker: NA
Text: in demand for imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: He also said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Manufacturers will certainly need to provide an

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing share of exports. They will not be able

Speaker: NA
Text: to do this unless they are efficient, and efficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: is the keynote of the Committee's views and sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gestions' on manufacturing. All the proposals for

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging efficiency are well within normal

Speaker: NA
Text: economic policies adopted by other economies.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the book " The Development of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia ", prepared for the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Research Foundation by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Stanford Research Institute of California,

Speaker: NA
Text: much the same thing is stated. We find

Speaker: NA
Text: following comments-

Speaker: NA
Text: In the past, and to a great extent still,

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia has relied upon exports of primary products

Speaker: NA
Text: to purchase its imports of equipment, petroleum,

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturing materials and other producers'

Speaker: NA
Text: goods. The growth of manufactures has been pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: marily for the local market. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: At present most Austrahan enterprises lack the

Speaker: NA
Text: built-in research facilities, managerial experience

Speaker: NA
Text: and marketing know-how to compete effectively in

Speaker: NA
Text: world markets. There are examples of small as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as large enterprises being successful with

Speaker: NA
Text: exports; but the change from local markets shel-

Speaker: NA
Text: tered by tariff protection and import restrictions

Speaker: NA
Text: to the ruthless competition of world markets

Speaker: NA
Text: requires a degree of sophistication still lacking

Speaker: NA
Text: in most enterprises.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dependence on technology derived from over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas often results in export restrictions being writ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ten into patent and licensing agreements. The rela-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive shortage of trained technicians and research

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities also makes it difficult for management

Speaker: NA
Text: to appraise the risks involved in new enterprises

Speaker: NA
Text: or extension into new markets. There is more

Speaker: NA
Text: potential risk capital than is often realised. The

Speaker: NA
Text: most serious deficiency in Australian enterprise is

Speaker: NA
Text: the reluctance of management, largely for lack of

Speaker: NA
Text: adequate experience and research assistance, to

Speaker: NA
Text: take calculated risks in new developmental ven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures, as it does for example in building con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction in the cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign enterprise, often with minimum invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, is able to calculate and assume such risks,

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementing the initial investment by local

Speaker: NA
Text: borrowing and reinvestment of profits. If Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian firms were equipped with more adequate

Speaker: NA
Text: built-in research and technical facilities, they

Speaker: NA
Text: could borrow the necessary capital, abroad if

Speaker: NA
Text: not within Australia, and hire technicians, and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore reap the profits of enterprise which now

Speaker: NA
Text: accrue to foreign firms.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Labour Party supports the move to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide rebates of payroll tax for increased

Speaker: NA
Text: export sales as, in fact, it falls directly in

Speaker: NA
Text: line with the long established policy of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Party which is to reduce indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation untU it is finally removed, except

Speaker: NA
Text: where an indirect tax is needed to achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: the purpose of planning or regulation. Over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas industrialists, more often than not with

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance from their governments, train or

Speaker: NA
Text: hire specialists in marketing and economic

Speaker: NA
Text: research. These highly trained specialists,

Speaker: NA
Text: again more often than not working in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: junction with their own country's economic

Speaker: NA
Text: and development council, assess potential

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign markets and report back the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems and possibilities attached to sales

Speaker: NA
Text: development and the attendant risks. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government must share the responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: with private enterprise in this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the question of local go-

Speaker: NA
Text: the vernment and municipal bodies, a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of which have approached me asking that

Speaker: NA
Text: Ausrepresentations be made for exemption from

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of payroll tax. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Melbourne Ports ( Mr Crean)

Speaker: NA
Text: has foreshadowed an amendment in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of which he made some good points. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: my experience that if there is one common

Speaker: NA
Text: factor more than another which unites all

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian local government bodies it is

Speaker: NA
Text: without doubt the resentment they share in

Speaker: NA
Text: having to pay Federal payroll tax. Objec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions have been raised by all local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment bodies in my electorate to paying

Speaker: NA
Text: this iniquitous imposition. They are all

Speaker: NA
Text: joined with the Municipal Association of

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia in its continued and vigorous

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign for the complete exemption of all

Speaker: NA
Text: local governing bodies from the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax. Over a long period representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions have been made to the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer and to individual members

Speaker: NA
Text: of Parliament by organisations registering

Speaker: NA
Text: protests against a Federal policy which re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quires local government to load its rates

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to pay a Federal revenue tax. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is firm in the belief that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer cannot justify further delay in

Speaker: NA
Text: giving these bodies complete exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: from the payment of payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: Knowing the great interest country

Speaker: NA
Text: members take in local government, and

Speaker: NA
Text: their knowledge of the greatly increased

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities attached to local governvaried

Speaker: NA
Text: ment bodies over the years, coupled with

Speaker: NA
Text: fhe fact fhat their burden has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: to the extent that even with the most limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: stringent and careful management they are

Speaker: NA
Text: continually and consistently in debt and

Speaker: NA
Text: unable to keep up with the demands made

Speaker: NA
Text: on them, I ask members of the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party whether their local government bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: are happy to pay the payroll tax or

Speaker: NA
Text: whether they raise the same objections

Speaker: NA
Text: do those in my electorate. If they do,

Speaker: NA
Text: what does the Country Party plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: about it? Will it vote for the Labour Party

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment' or ignore the justice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: claim of these local bodies? We can hope

Speaker: NA
Text: only that when a division is called justice

Speaker: NA
Text: will prevail. The Australian Council of it

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government Associations claims

Speaker: NA
Text: that is has made numerous representations

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Treasurer on behalf of local capital

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities seeking exemptions from the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment ot payroll tax but that it has

Speaker: NA
Text: never been given any reason that comwithin

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely answers the points raised by local

Speaker: NA
Text: government. We trust' that on this occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer will answer these questions

Speaker: NA
Text: and will not go into a brown study to of

Speaker: NA
Text: search for reasons for refusing the requests.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hope he will agree with the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party amendment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In support of their claims to total

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption, local bodies claim that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ignores the principle involved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the ridiculous state of affairs whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: a higher level of government imposes a

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue tax on a lower level of government

Speaker: NA
Text: which is non-profit making and which has

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely limited means of raising finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: In pointing out that State Governments

Speaker: NA
Text: pay payroll tax, the Treasurer seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: ignore the fact that this is taken into

Speaker: NA
Text: account when the States are reimbursed

Speaker: NA
Text: under the uniform tax system. No reim-

Speaker: NA
Text: bursement or adjustment is made to local

Speaker: NA
Text: government bodies, which are, in most

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, totally dependent on the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and the States, as well as on incomes

Speaker: NA
Text: from their own rates, for finance to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: all commitments. I am sure that the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments assist local government

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies to the best of their financial

Speaker: NA
Text: ability- I know this is so in South Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: -bu t under our present system of Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: control the States are to an astonishing

Speaker: NA
Text: degree dependent on the Federal Treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: for finance to carry out their many and

Speaker: NA
Text: commitments. Accordingly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: ability of the States to provide finance to

Speaker: NA
Text: local government bodies is extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: To ascertain whether consideration was

Speaker: NA
Text: being given by local government bodies to

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing rates I contacted a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: them. Invariably I was told that rates had

Speaker: NA
Text: as been increased from time to time but that

Speaker: NA
Text: if they were increased excessively there

Speaker: NA
Text: do would be a definite burden on property

Speaker: NA
Text: owners. Let me refer to the position in

Speaker: NA
Text: Whyalla, which is an industrial town with

Speaker: NA
Text: a large percentage of workers' homes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: local government authority there states that

Speaker: NA
Text: is extremely reluctant to increase rates as

Speaker: NA
Text: the average ratepayer already pays between

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£18 and Â£20 a year on the unimproved

Speaker: NA
Text: value of his property. It is claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that many of the functions undertaken by

Speaker: NA
Text: local government authorities are of a social

Speaker: NA
Text: or welfare nature which could well come

Speaker: NA
Text: the ambit of the Commonwealth's

Speaker: NA
Text: activities and be met by Federal income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax revenue. Local government authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: express real concern at the growing nature

Speaker: NA
Text: the activities which are not their direct

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility but which they are called

Speaker: NA
Text: upon to finance. They frankly state that

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot afford to continue to do this

Speaker: NA
Text: and at the same time properly discharge the

Speaker: NA
Text: ever growing obligations which properly

Speaker: NA
Text: belong to them. It is claimed that payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax is an uneconomical tax and a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: penalty on the employer, creating additional

Speaker: NA
Text: book work. It is claimed that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: collecting the tax is high in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Local government authorities are con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned with the development of the areas

Speaker: NA
Text: which they serve-wit h the continued and

Speaker: NA
Text: in some cases rapid development of those

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. Morefinanceis needed each year by

Speaker: NA
Text: local government bodies. If the Treasurer

Speaker: NA
Text: were to make a survey of the absolute needs

Speaker: NA
Text: of this important arm of government even

Speaker: NA
Text: he must concede the necessity to make

Speaker: NA
Text: larger grants to local government bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: rather than grab back from these bodies

Speaker: NA
Text: sums of money, whether they be large or

Speaker: NA
Text: small, that are desperately needed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Year

Speaker: NA
Text: The table shows that the amount of pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax paid by local government authorities

Speaker: NA
Text: has assumed alarming proportions. In 1963-

Speaker: NA
Text: 64 the amount paid reached the astonishing

Speaker: NA
Text: total of Â£2,600,000, which is more than

Speaker: NA
Text: twice as much as was paid in 1954-55.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have referred to the major objections

Speaker: NA
Text: raised by local government authorities to the

Speaker: NA
Text: payment of this tax, which deprives them of

Speaker: NA
Text: the finance that they desperately need for

Speaker: NA
Text: kerbing, paving, sealing, maintenance and

Speaker: NA
Text: 101 other projects. In considering the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's amendment, the Treasurer must take

Speaker: NA
Text: into account the added burden and responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bilities imposed on State Governments and

Speaker: NA
Text: local government authorities by our

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration programme. There is more than

Speaker: NA
Text: general agreement that we must step up

Speaker: NA
Text: immigration and individually share the

Speaker: NA
Text: areas from which they are derived. Every

Speaker: NA
Text: effort must be made to boost our secondary

Speaker: NA
Text: exports. I know that this view is shared

Speaker: NA
Text: generally by honorable members on both

Speaker: NA
Text: sides of the House. So we must agree that

Speaker: NA
Text: the rebate of Â£1,150,000 paid to 435

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting firms during the first three months

Speaker: NA
Text: of this financial year was a step in the

Speaker: NA
Text: right direction. If we agree with this action,

Speaker: NA
Text: how much more must we agree that local

Speaker: NA
Text: government must be given the same

Speaker: NA
Text: privilege, for there is surely no local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment body which has not assisted in every

Speaker: NA
Text: way possible any industry which has moved

Speaker: NA
Text: into its area. To indicate the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: work undertaken by local government

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities over the past 10 years, with the

Speaker: NA
Text: concurrence of honorable members I in-

Speaker: NA
Text: corporate in " Hansard" a table showing

Speaker: NA
Text: the amounts of payroll tax paid by local

Speaker: NA
Text: government authorities in the years 1954-

Speaker: NA
Text: State

Speaker: NA
Text: N.S.W. Vic. Qld. S.A. W.A. Tas. Total

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities attached to our immigration

Speaker: NA
Text: programme, but we cannot ignore the hard

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that a faster than natural growth of

Speaker: NA
Text: population places a greatly increased strain

Speaker: NA
Text: on the financial resources of the States and

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly on those of local government

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: A further matter which the Treasurer is

Speaker: NA
Text: asked to consider is the total exemption

Speaker: NA
Text: from local government assessments enjoyed

Speaker: NA
Text: by Crown lands and government buildings.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will refer in more detail to this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: later if time permits, but for the present I

Speaker: NA
Text: will deal with specific areas. I recently had

Speaker: NA
Text: discussions with the Whyalla City Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. Last year it paid Â£1,150 in payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. This year the Commission estimates that

Speaker: NA
Text: it will pay about Â£1,500. Non-ratable build-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings included in the Commission's area are

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General's Department depots

Speaker: NA
Text: and post offices. Four years ago the popula-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the area numbered 17,000. Today it

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers 22,000. Two-thirds of the area

Speaker: NA
Text: tinder the control of the City Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: is still Crown land and therefore non-

Speaker: NA
Text: ratable. Nevertheless the Commission is

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to build roads around or through

Speaker: NA
Text: that area. The Commission has an overdraft

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£50,000. The Commission has large sums

Speaker: NA
Text: of money outstanding in loans..

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the affairs of the Cowell

Speaker: NA
Text: District Council. Most of the State instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalities pay rates to the Council. The

Speaker: NA
Text: only Commonwealth buildings in Cowell are

Speaker: NA
Text: those owned by the Postal Department and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Civil Aviation. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: non-ratable. Rates are not paid in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the aerodrome. The Council is obliged

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a compulsory grant to the local

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital under the Public Hospitals Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: That grant amounts to Â£1,250 a year. A new

Speaker: NA
Text: road between Cowell and Cleve is held up

Speaker: NA
Text: through lack of funds. At least two other

Speaker: NA
Text: important road projects in the area, which

Speaker: NA
Text: have been examined by the Highways

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, are held up because of lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of funds. The Mangalo Road, which is near

Speaker: NA
Text: a silo, and the Miltowie Road now bear

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy grain traffic and traffic carrying full

Speaker: NA
Text: loads of superphosphate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Cummins District Council states that

Speaker: NA
Text: within its area are 100,000 acres of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: ratable property. This property consists of

Speaker: NA
Text: Crown land, the Uley Basin, Engineering

Speaker: NA
Text: and Water Supply Department catchment

Speaker: NA
Text: areas and government buildings and

Speaker: NA
Text: schools. The Council pays a compulsory

Speaker: NA
Text: grant of Â£1,900 to local hospitals under the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Hospitals Act. Of this amount Â£400

Speaker: NA
Text: is paid in respect of Port Lincoln Hospital

Speaker: NA
Text: and Â£1,500 in respect of Cummins Hos-

Speaker: NA
Text: pital. The loss in rates not paid on non-

Speaker: NA
Text: ratable properties would amount to between

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£7,000 and Â£10,000 a year. If we add to that

Speaker: NA
Text: amount the amount lost by not rating the

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital, we find that the Council is out

Speaker: NA
Text: pocket by up to Â£13,000 a year. New areas

Speaker: NA
Text: are being opened. A road has been congood

Speaker: NA
Text: structed from Kapinnie to Kiama. No rates

Speaker: NA
Text: are received from the Government Produce

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, which is a fairly big Departthose

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Rates are not paid by the Forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: Department, the Postmaster-General's

Speaker: NA
Text: Department or the Engineering and Water

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply Department. The rate earning provide

Speaker: NA
Text: capacity of an area of 1,817 square miles

Speaker: NA
Text: has been virtually taken away, although

Speaker: NA
Text: rates of Â£100,000 would have been received

Speaker: NA
Text: from this area.

Speaker: NA
Text: At Port Pirie, the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government makes use of all the services,

Speaker: NA
Text: but does not want to contribute to their

Speaker: NA
Text: cost. Of the total area administered by tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, 20 per cent, is non-ratable property

Speaker: NA
Text: owned by the Commonwealth and State

Speaker: NA
Text: Governments. If these Governments paid

Speaker: NA
Text: rates, it is estimated that the rates would

Speaker: NA
Text: total Â£21,562. The Council pays a contri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution to the hospital. Payroll tax for the

Speaker: NA
Text: lastfinancialyear amounted to Â£1,555. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Council at Jamestown makes a voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution to the hospital. The amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of book work involved is out of proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: to the amount of payroll tax that is paid.

Speaker: NA
Text: At Tumby Bay, the main project not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted because of lack of finance is the

Speaker: NA
Text: ablution block at Tumby Bay caravan park.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Council applied for a subsidy for 1965-

Speaker: NA
Text: 66, but this was refused. A total of Â£36,000

Speaker: NA
Text: was allocated to the Tourist Bureau in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. Applications were made for sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidies amounting to Â£55,000. In this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: an application was made forfinancialassis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tance to seal a road in Tumby Bay, but no

Speaker: NA
Text: money was allocated. No money has been

Speaker: NA
Text: allocated up to the present for the sealing of

Speaker: NA
Text: the road to Cummins and to Ungarra. The

Speaker: NA
Text: road is sealed to Lipson, but from there

Speaker: NA
Text: about 15 miles is unsealed. Heavy transport

Speaker: NA
Text: uses the road. Fertiliser is carried one way

Speaker: NA
Text: and wheat the other. Goods sent to Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: are transported over these roads before they

Speaker: NA
Text: reach the main highway. The rates lost

Speaker: NA
Text: on non-ratable Government properties

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to Â£976. The Council borrowed

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£18,300 this year to buy road making

Speaker: NA
Text: equipment. Next year it would like to go

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead with a few more roads. Township

Speaker: NA
Text: streets always need attention.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Council at Cleve comments that

Speaker: NA
Text: rates, like most taxes, must be considered

Speaker: NA
Text: of within the ability of the people to pay. The

Speaker: NA
Text: ability of people to pay may not be as

Speaker: NA
Text: in this area as it is in more closely

Speaker: NA
Text: settled areas, although the amenities pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided by the Council must be as good as

Speaker: NA
Text: provided in the more closely settled

Speaker: NA
