Text: areas. Payroll tax in this district represents

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1 for every day of the year. If this amount

Speaker: NA
Text: were paid into a long term loan, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: additional medical facilities or a

Speaker: NA
Text: mile or two of roads. The Council's financial

Speaker: NA
Text: position is not bright. It is hoped that not

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 10 per cent, of its revenue will

Speaker: NA
Text: be overdrawn. It pays a contribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,700 per annum to the Cleve hospital.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Council hopes that, with increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue and by reducing work slightly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next financial year, it may break even.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Commonwealth Railways at Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Augusta were a private enterprise and paid

Speaker: NA
Text: rates, the rates would amount to Â£23,000

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum. The Post Office, including the

Speaker: NA
Text: line depots and so on, would pay Â£900.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would include residences, on which

Speaker: NA
Text: rates are now paid. The Council at Port

Speaker: NA
Text: Augusta pays Â£700 in payroll tax. It makes

Speaker: NA
Text: a contribution of Â£2,400 per annum to the

Speaker: NA
Text: hospital. Â£700 to the fire brigade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£10,000 for parks, gardens and so on. It

Speaker: NA
Text: pays customs duty on the diesel fuel it uses,

Speaker: NA
Text: and this amounts to Â£350 per annum at

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate of ls. a gallon. The Council applied

Speaker: NA
Text: to thc Department of Customs and Excise

Speaker: NA
Text: for an exemption, but the application was

Speaker: NA
Text: refused. Work held up because of lack of.

Speaker: NA
Text: finance is mainly work on the roads. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Council cannot afford an Olympic swimming

Speaker: NA
Text: pool or a public library because of lack

Speaker: NA
Text: of funds. It has borrowed for a lot of work.

Speaker: NA
Text: Rates on Commonwealth buildings would

Speaker: NA
Text: amount to one-third of the total rate

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue. I could give details of the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: of many other councils if I had time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I ask the Treasurer to give very symabolition

Speaker: NA
Text: pathetic consideration to the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: propose to move. The local government

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies in my area are desperately in need

Speaker: NA
Text: of finance and they consider that the

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax is a definite imposition on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: I join with the councils in asking that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer accept the amendment.

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: Newcastle) [5.1] -Th e main

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the Bill is to exempt from

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax the Commonwealth War Graves

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission and to extend the export incencompany

Speaker: NA
Text: tives scheme to motor car manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of vehicles that are exported in

Speaker: NA
Text: knocked down condition. We on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House completely support the incluability

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of the War Graves Commission in the

Speaker: NA
Text: list of those exempted from payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: We also support the extension of the

Speaker: NA
Text: incentives scheme. We will, therefore, supsideration

Speaker: NA
Text: port the Bill. However, in the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: stage the honorable member for Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: Ports ( Mr Crean) will move an amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that is designed to exempt from payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: all municipal bodies, local councils and

Speaker: NA
Text: similar authorities doing the work normally

Speaker: NA
Text: performed by local government bodies. We

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that these organisations at least

Speaker: NA
Text: should be exempted from the payment of

Speaker: NA
Text: this iniquitous form of taxation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Payroll tax is an unnecessary form

Speaker: NA
Text: of taxation which places an unneces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sary burden on the economy as a whole.

Speaker: NA
Text: Last year, payroll tax collections amounted

Speaker: NA
Text: to Â£75,038,000 and it is expected that this

Speaker: NA
Text: year the tax will yield Â£82 million. This in

Speaker: NA
Text: itself imposes an unnecessary burden on the

Speaker: NA
Text: general price structure and the economy as

Speaker: NA
Text: a whole. No matter how we regard payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax, the Â£75 million collected last year and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Â£82 million expected to be collected this

Speaker: NA
Text: year will have a very definite effect on tbe

Speaker: NA
Text: cost structure of Australia. Motor cars

Speaker: NA
Text: exported in a knocked down condition will

Speaker: NA
Text: now be excluded from this form of taxation,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the price of motor vehicles purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: by industry in Australia will be increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax. Not one item that is needed by

Speaker: NA
Text: the community will remain unaffected by

Speaker: NA
Text: this tax. The costs of foodstuffs, clothing and

Speaker: NA
Text: the general cost of living will be increased

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the imposition of payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this tax were abolished, I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: living costs would decline by the Â£82 million

Speaker: NA
Text: that is expected to be collected this year.

Speaker: NA
Text: For a government that is allegedly concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: at the inflationary spiral in this country, the

Speaker: NA
Text: of this tax is one method whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: we inflation can be curtailed to some extent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) said

Speaker: NA
Text: paysome years ago, and has continued to say,

Speaker: NA
Text: that if payroll fax were eliminated the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury would have to obtain the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue from other sources. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: agrees that other sources would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: paybe explored, even if it meant increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: income tax or even if it meant increasing

Speaker: NA
Text: tax. Those two fields could afford

Speaker: NA
Text: in to supply the necessary revenue. Indirect

Speaker: NA
Text: a forms of taxation are inequitable because

Speaker: NA
Text: they do not take into consideration the

Speaker: NA
Text: of the person to pay. Payroll lax

Speaker: NA
Text: is an indirect form of taxation. So is sales

Speaker: NA
Text: tax which is imposed on cigarettes, petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: export and many other commodities. No con-

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever is given to the ability

Speaker: NA
Text: of the individual to pay. A person on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wage pays the same amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: customs and excise duty on tobacco and

Speaker: NA
Text: cigarettes as does a person on an income

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£5,000 or Â£10,000 per annum. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition strongly supports the elimina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of all forms of indirect taxation. It

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that a direct tax should be

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed in the incomes of individuals and

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. Therefore, although the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition will move to provide additional

Speaker: NA
Text: exemptions from payroll tax basically it

Speaker: NA
Text: believes that the tax should be eliminated

Speaker: NA
Text: completely, and it will work in that

Speaker: NA
Text: direction.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have to realise that originally payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax was introduced in 1941 as part of two

Speaker: NA
Text: pieces of legislation introduced at that

Speaker: NA
Text: time. The Commonwealth Arbitration

Speaker: NA
Text: Court, rather than increase the basic wage,

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended to the government of the

Speaker: NA
Text: day that a scheme of child endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: should be introduced. Two bills were

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced into the Parliament at the one

Speaker: NA
Text: time. One was to provide for the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of child endowment, the other was to levy

Speaker: NA
Text: payroU tax which at that time was to

Speaker: NA
Text: meet the cost of child endowment. The tax

Speaker: NA
Text: an.ounted to 2 i per cent, on the wages

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to employees in certain industries

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the Commonwealth. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer, in a report in payroll tax pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented to the Parliament on 17th May 1960

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then, the direct connection between

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax and the financing of child endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has for budgetary reasons been terminated.

Speaker: NA
Text: In fact, thousands of people throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia have been of the opinion that

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax is a direct tax levied to finance

Speaker: NA
Text: child endowment, but on the Treasurer's

Speaker: NA
Text: own say-so in that report, that purpose has

Speaker: NA
Text: been terminated. Payroll tax today is

Speaker: NA
Text: another means of raising revenue for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Consolidated Revenue Fund and nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: else, It is in order, therefore, to advocate

Speaker: NA
Text: the abolition of payroll tax and to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that a direct form of taxation be substituted.

Speaker: NA
Text: The organisations at present exempted

Speaker: NA
Text: from payroll tax are set out in the FortyFourth

Speaker: NA
Text: Fourth Report of the Commisssioner of

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation. At page 81 under the heading Authority

Speaker: NA
Text: *' Payroll Tax " the Commissioner said-

Speaker: NA
Text: A feature of the legislation is the wide

Speaker: NA
Text: of the tax. Exemptions are limited to wages

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by the Governor-General or the Governor

Speaker: NA
Text: of a State, the representatives in Australia of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governments of other countries, public

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals and certain other hospitals, public

Speaker: NA
Text: benevolent and religious institutions and a few

Speaker: NA
Text: specified organisations such as the South Pacific

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. Wages paid to members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Defence Force and certain ancillary services are

Speaker: NA
Text: also exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it is possible to exempt all of those

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations, and the salaries paid to mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers of the Defence Forces and other ancil-

Speaker: NA
Text: lary services, why cannot local government

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities be exempted? Why should we

Speaker: NA
Text: not exclude all State Government instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalities from the payment of this tax?

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Railways is exempted. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should State railways pay payroll tax and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Railways be. exempted? Per

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of a question asked by Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: MCClelland in another place, a reply was

Speaker: NA
Text: furnished giving the amount of payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by State railways throughout Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: during the year 1963-64. It amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,427,864. Why? I ask honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite that question. I ask any Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment supporter to give some explanation

Speaker: NA
Text: why State railways should be required to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax when Commonwealth Railways

Speaker: NA
Text: is completely exempted from the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of such a tax. The two instrumentalities

Speaker: NA
Text: perform identical work. There is no differ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence between Commonwealth Railways, the

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales Railways, the Victorian

Speaker: NA
Text: Railways or the South Australian Railways.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Crean -The y are often carrying the

Speaker: NA
Text: same goods.

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: Tha t is correct, ln South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia the South Australian Railways

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Commonwealth Railways operate

Speaker: NA
Text: together. In Western Australia the two

Speaker: NA
Text: systems perform the same duties, operating

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside each other. One system has to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay payroll tax and the other one is com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely exempted. There is no justification

Speaker: NA
Text: for this haphazard treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: In order to show the burden imposed on

Speaker: NA
Text: State Governments by payroll tax I refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: page 152 of " Taxation Statistics 1963-64 "

Speaker: NA
Text: which are the latest figures available. The

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics are a supplement to the Forty-

Speaker: NA
Text: Report of the Commissioner of Taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. I refer to the column headed " Public

Speaker: NA
Text: Activities (n.e.i.)". As the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne Ports told us,

Speaker: NA
Text: scope " n.e.i." means " not elsewhere included ".

Speaker: NA
Text: In this column we have the salaries and

Speaker: NA
Text: wages paid by payroll taxpayers for each

Speaker: NA
Text: month of the financial year 1963-64. The

Speaker: NA
Text: total amount paid during the year was Â£427

Speaker: NA
Text: million, which on the basis of 2 i per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: means that these authorities paid Â£10.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million in payroll tax for 1963-64. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously impossible for the payment of this

Speaker: NA
Text: tax not to have had some effect on the total

Speaker: NA
Text: price structure and the cost of operating

Speaker: NA
Text: these public authorities throughout Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another column on the same page is headed

Speaker: NA
Text: "Electricity, Gas, Water and Sanitary Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices". The total amount paid in wages

Speaker: NA
Text: under that heading was Â£140 million, which

Speaker: NA
Text: represents approximately Â£3.5 million paid

Speaker: NA
Text: in payroll tax. What does this Â£3.5 million

Speaker: NA
Text: really mean when related to the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: electricity, gas, water and sanitary services?

Speaker: NA
Text: I am sure honorable members on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government side have received representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and complaints from various organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and people in their electorates com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaining that they have been unable to get

Speaker: NA
Text: sewerage, or that there are inadequate sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plies of electricity, water or gas. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people want gas as well as electricity but

Speaker: NA
Text: they cannot get it because the local authority

Speaker: NA
Text: has not sufficientfinanceto carry out the

Speaker: NA
Text: reticulation required. I am certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: complaints have been received in other elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torates as well as mine. Continual requests

Speaker: NA
Text: are made for these amenities to be provided.

Speaker: NA
Text: If this tax were removed it would make it

Speaker: NA
Text: much easier for authorities to provide these

Speaker: NA
Text: amenities.

Speaker: NA
Text: Figures available indicate that a sum of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£14.1 million is paid in payroll tax by State

Speaker: NA
Text: Government authorities. I believe that that

Speaker: NA
Text: could be eliminated completely. I admit, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer has said on previous occa-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions, that if payroll tax were abolished

Speaker: NA
Text: there would have to be a readjustment of

Speaker: NA
Text: State tax reimbursements. So what? What if

Speaker: NA
Text: there had to be a readjustment of reimburse-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments by the Commonwealth to the States?

Speaker: NA
Text: It would stop the stupid-an d I emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: the word "stupid"-arrangemen t between

Speaker: NA
Text: the States and the Commonwealth whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: we have a government taxing governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: How silly can we get? How long can we

Speaker: NA
Text: continue this stupid process of government

Speaker: NA
Text: taxing government. The bookwork must be

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminated. That is what has to be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: The administrative costs must be eliminated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole burden of collecting this tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: placed on the various government instru-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentalities which have to pay the tax. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: certain of one thing. It is that the saving

Speaker: NA
Text: of a considerable amount of money-n o

Speaker: NA
Text: one can assess the exact amount-woul d

Speaker: NA
Text: result from the elimination of this tax. At

Speaker: NA
Text: least a saving would be reflected in the

Speaker: NA
Text: general price structure of the country as a

Speaker: NA
Text: whole. The Minister for the Army (Dr

Speaker: NA
Text: Forbes), who assists the Treasurer, gives

Speaker: NA
Text: that as one of his weak old reasons why

Speaker: NA
Text: the elimination of payroll tax could not be

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to deal with local government.

Speaker: NA
Text: The amendment that the Opposition has

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadowed is an important one. If honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members examinefigureswith regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: local government they will see that the

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons why payroll tax should be elimi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nated are perfectly clear. To give an

Speaker: NA
Text: example, I mention that New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: local governments employ 43,000 people.

Speaker: NA
Text: These local governments pay by way of

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax Â£1.3 million per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Throughout Australia payroll tax paid by

Speaker: NA
Text: local government amounts to Â£2.6 million.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at another aspect of this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Local government has to pay payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: these to the Commonwealth. Does the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth reciprocate and pay to local authori-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties rates on its properties in municipal

Speaker: NA
Text: council areas? Of course it does not. The

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue lost to local government through

Speaker: NA
Text: non-ratable property in 1960 was Â£722,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1965 the figure will be approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£1,100,000. The 1965 figure is an approxi-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate one but the 1960figureis the factual

Speaker: NA
Text: figure of the loss of rates to local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment because the Federal Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fuses to pay rates with respect to its various

Speaker: NA
Text: instrumentalities such as post offices, custom

Speaker: NA
Text: houses and numerous other Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: properties. We know that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Banking Corporation pays rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another question I want to raise.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for the Army said earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: today that no rates were paid by the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government to water and

Speaker: NA
Text: severage authorities in South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia. I want to say to the Ministar

Speaker: NA
Text: that in Newcastle, on information

Speaker: NA
Text: given to me this afternoon, the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government makes an ex gratia pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment which is the equivalent of water board

Speaker: NA
Text: rates on Commonwealth properties. So,

Speaker: NA
Text: some justification exists for local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment insisting on, requiring and expecting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth to make some ex gratia

Speaker: NA
Text: payment on its properties. That is a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: and a reasonable proposition. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: niember for Grey ( Mr Mortimer) has out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined what has taken place in his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: as far as local government is concerned. In

Speaker: NA
Text: my own electorate of Newcastle, the City

Speaker: NA
Text: Council pays Â£27,000 a year in payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Council loses Â£25,000 per annum on

Speaker: NA
Text: non-ratable Commonwealth property in the

Speaker: NA
Text: municipality of Newcastle. In other words,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government, by impos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this tax and failing to pay rates on the

Speaker: NA
Text: land it uses, is costing the ratepayers of

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle Â£52,000 a year or approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: one sixth of a penny in the pound. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that the elimination of payroll tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: one way in which the Government can make

Speaker: NA
Text: a contribution to local government. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: positive assistance to loaal government by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government is long overdue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Local government bodies do not receive

Speaker: NA
Text: enough assistance. I believe that the day is

Speaker: NA
Text: not far distant when the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will. have to devise some

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme with State and municipal govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments whereby a certain amount of income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax and company tax will be set aside and

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to local government possibly on the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis of so much per head of population.

Speaker: NA
Text: Local government authorities today are

Speaker: NA
Text: being required to carry out undertakings

Speaker: NA
Text: that they were not expected to carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: in years gone by. Their undertakings are

Speaker: NA
Text: just too numerous to go into. I believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: is time that the Federal Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: the State Governments gave much more

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to local government than what

Speaker: NA
Text: they have been doing. This can be done in

Speaker: NA
Text: a practical way in the manner in which I

Speaker: NA
Text: have suggested. If the necessity for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle City Council to pay payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: were eliminated, the result would be that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Council would gain Â£27,000 per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Commonwealth were to pay rates on

Speaker: NA
Text: its properties in Newcastle, the City Council

Speaker: NA
Text: would gain immediately Â£25,000 per annum.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of these two matters the Council

Speaker: NA
Text: would gain Â£52,000. This, in itself, would

Speaker: NA
Text: be of great assistance to the Council. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Grey listed all the

Speaker: NA
Text: things that should be done for the councils

Speaker: NA
Text: in his electorate. Those councils, too, could

Speaker: NA
Text: be assisted if the requirement to pay payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax was eliminated and the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: paid rates on its land in those council

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no justification for the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth imposing payroll tax on local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The New South Wales Government

Speaker: NA
Text: does not charge local authorities stamp duty;

Speaker: NA
Text: nor does it require them to pay land tax. I f

Speaker: NA
Text: the New South Wales Government can see

Speaker: NA
Text: its way clear to exclude local government

Speaker: NA
Text: from the payment of those two taxes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth should be able to exempt

Speaker: NA
Text: local authorities from the obligation to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is one other matter with which I

Speaker: NA
Text: would like to deal. I would like to hear

Speaker: NA
Text: some members of the Country Party say

Speaker: NA
Text: something on this point. I am sorry that

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Mallee ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull) is not here, because I am certain

Speaker: NA
Text: that if he were, he would have something to

Speaker: NA
Text: say on it. He would accept my challenge.

Speaker: NA
Text: I noticed a short time ago that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Interior ( Mr Anthony) was in the

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. But I can see that his time has

Speaker: NA
Text: expired and he has had to retire. I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with the application of payroll tax to

Speaker: NA
Text: assist in the decentralisation of industry. We

Speaker: NA
Text: hear a lot about this subject from time to

Speaker: NA
Text: time, particularly from Country Party mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: bers. I bring to the notice of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members that some months ago the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bendigo ( Mr Beaton)

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed a motion in which he advocated

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of a joint parliamentary

Speaker: NA
Text: committee to deal with decentralisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: to endeavour to find some practical solution

Speaker: NA
Text: to the decentralisation of industry in Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia. But I notice also that on 29th April

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965, the day the motion was submitted, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for the Interior was speaking when

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate was interrupted, as the time for

Speaker: NA
Text: discussion had expired. The Minister was

Speaker: NA
Text: granted leave to continue his speech when

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate was resumed. The Minister is a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Country Party, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: continually advocating decentralisation. He

Speaker: NA
Text: is also one of the people in that party who

Speaker: NA
Text: have done nothing about decentralisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Country Party has been the junior

Speaker: NA
Text: partner of this Government for the past 16

Speaker: NA
Text: years. Yet we have not seen any progress

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever towards decentralisation. When-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever any member of the Opposition brings

Speaker: NA
Text: forward a resolution dealing with decen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralisation, the Government permits a

Speaker: NA
Text: debate on it in the initial stages but we can

Speaker: NA
Text: areas. never have a vote on i t

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer in particular to the motion moved

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Bendigo.

Speaker: NA
Text: Paragraph (4) (b) (ii) provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tliat this House notes with grave concern-

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) That more than one-third of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: population of Australia is centred in Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne, and recommends to the Government as

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of extreme urgency in the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: balanced development and defence that-

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) the committee make recommendations in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to-

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) concessions in individual, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: This paragraph proposes the use of taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: lo assist the decentralisation of industry. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have in Australia two zones in which taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion allowances are granted to residents.

Speaker: NA
Text: Zone A takes in the northern half of

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia, the Northern Territory

Speaker: NA
Text: and a slice of northern and western Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land. Anybody residing in Zone A is entitled

Speaker: NA
Text: to claim an allowance of Â£270 plus half the

Speaker: NA
Text: dependant's allowance. People living in Zone

Speaker: NA
Text: B are entitled to claim Â£45 plus one-twelfth

Speaker: NA
Text: of the dependant's allowance. What is wrong

Speaker: NA
Text: with using this form of incentive to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage industries to leave capital cities

Speaker: NA
Text: and thus assist in decentralisation? Could

Speaker: NA
Text: we not introduce some system under which

Speaker: NA
Text: firms would be exempted from the payment

Speaker: NA
Text: of payroll tax if they establish new industries

Speaker: NA
Text: at least, say, one hundred miles from any

Speaker: NA
Text: capital cities? We could lay down definite

Speaker: NA
Text: and positive zones so that firms establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: industries in those zones could claim

Speaker: NA
Text: exemption from the payment of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: or portion of the payroll tax normally pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: able. In 1962-63 exporters enjoyed the

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of a reduction in payroll tax to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of Â£2,685,000. If we can make this

Speaker: NA
Text: concession to encourage exports, why can

Speaker: NA
Text: we not do something similar to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: decentralisation of industry?

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like some members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party to rise and say why this

Speaker: NA
Text: form of taxation concession should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: used to encourage decentralisation. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like them to tell us what their Party, which

Speaker: NA
Text: forms the junior partner in the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, is doing to bring about decentralisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of industry. I know as well as they do

Speaker: NA
Text: that they are very much opposed to decen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralisation of industry because they realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that the moment industries move into their

Speaker: NA
Text: electorates their seats in the Parliament will

Speaker: NA
Text: be in jeopardy. I have always been of the

Speaker: NA
Text: opinion that it is sheer humbug and hypo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cracy on their part to advocate decen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralisation of industry. I ask honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Country Party to rise and

Speaker: NA
Text: tell us their views on this matter. I am very

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased to see that the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mallee is with us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull -Wh y do you always

Speaker: NA
Text: pick on me?

Speaker: NA
Text: pany, sales or other taxation

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: -Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Mallee is the only member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party, in my experience in this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament, who has been prepared to rise

Speaker: NA
Text: in his place when a member on this side

Speaker: NA
Text: has made an attack on his Parly. I would

Speaker: NA
Text: like to hear what he has to say as to why

Speaker: NA
Text: a payroll tax concession should not be used

Speaker: NA
Text: as a means of encouraging industries to

Speaker: NA
Text: move out of the capital cities and into the

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas where they would provide

Speaker: NA
Text: employment for country people and assist

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of so many of our

Speaker: NA
Text: country cities that need new industries. I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the honorable member for Mallee and

Speaker: NA
Text: his colleagues of the Country Party whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they will support the Labour Party in hav-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the motion of the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bendigo on decentralisation brought on

Speaker: NA
Text: for discussion. It is item No. 6 under the

Speaker: NA
Text: heading " General Business". I ask them

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell us, secondly, whether they are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to support us in a move to have pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax concessions granted as an incentive

Speaker: NA
Text: for industry to move out of the capital

Speaker: NA
Text: cities. I also ask Government members to

Speaker: NA
Text: say why local government authorities should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be given the financial assistance that

Speaker: NA
Text: they would receive if the amendment that

Speaker: NA
Text: will be moved by the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Melbourne Ports ( Mr Crean) in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee stage were accepted.

Speaker: NA
Text: I support the Bill. I believe it is a step

Speaker: NA
Text: in the right direction to assist export

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. I agree with the proposal to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clude the War Graves Commission as one

Speaker: NA
Text: of the exempted bodies. But I ask Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment members to support the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: that will be moved by the Opposition to

Speaker: NA
Text: include local government authorities and

Speaker: NA
Text: similar instrumentalities as bodies eligible

Speaker: NA
Text: for exemption from this iniquitous form of

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation.

Speaker: Mr LUCHETTI
Text: Macquarie) [5.29] -

Speaker: NA
Text: This Bill seeks to amend the Payroll Tax

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1941-63. The debate gives me an oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity to speak for the harried and over-

Speaker: NA
Text: burdened ratepayers of Australia. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: them are pensioners who are ineligible for

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary assistance and are in a serious

Speaker: NA
Text: financial position. It is necessary for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: consider the Bill from this broad standpoint:

Speaker: NA
Text: What does it propose to do? That has been

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed in detail by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Melbourne Ports ( Mr Crean), who

Speaker: NA
Text: analysed the legislation and its ramifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must also ask: How will it affect the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy?

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 should like to begin by indicating my

Speaker: NA
Text: support for the amendment which has been

Speaker: NA
Text: foreshadowed by the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne Ports and to express the hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this debate the Parliament will

Speaker: NA
Text: receive a message from the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: affirming the need to relieve ratepayers and

Speaker: NA
Text: local government authorities of the require-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to pay payroll tax in respect of work

Speaker: NA
Text: of very great importance to this nation. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been looking through a booklet en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled "Taxation Statistics 1963-64" and I

Speaker: NA
Text: have discovered that in that year all the

Speaker: NA
Text: public authorities in Australia paid wages

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to Â£427,116,000. The payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: collected for the year amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£68,221,735, or 5.7 per cent, of the total

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes paid during the year. The payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by local government authorities is,

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore, really a small item. It represents

Speaker: NA
Text: a very meagre proportion of the total amount

Speaker: NA
Text: paid by taxpayers throughout Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I agree with the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle ( Mr Jones) that this is an

Speaker: NA
Text: iniquitous and unjust tax. It bears harshly

Speaker: NA
Text: upon people already carrying heavy burdens.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no better system, to my mind, of

Speaker: NA
Text: imposing taxation than by a graduated scale

Speaker: NA
Text: of income tax which falls on all the people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The booklet to which I have referred tells

Speaker: NA
Text: us that 854 returns were furnished by public

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities for the year 1963-64, covering

Speaker: NA
Text: 337,342 wage and salary earners. On

Speaker: NA
Text: examination it will be found, as I have

Speaker: NA
Text: already said, that the amount of payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: involved is quite small, and I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government could devise

Speaker: NA
Text: some other satisfactory means of obtaining

Speaker: NA
Text: the revenue. The total number of groups

Speaker: NA
Text: which furnished returns in that year was

Speaker: NA
Text: 38,234, of which, as I said a moment ago,

Speaker: NA
Text: 854 were public authorities. The amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money involved is small, the field to be con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered is a broad one and the payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: does not meet modern requirements for the

Speaker: NA
Text: collection of necessary government finance.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have already said that there were 337,342

Speaker: NA
Text: wage and salary earners employed by local

Speaker: NA
Text: government authorities in 1963-64. Of these

Speaker: NA
Text: 250,680 were males and 86,662 were

Speaker: NA
Text: females.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wholeheartedly support the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Grey ( Mr Mortimer) the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Newcastle and the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Melbourne Ports in their

Speaker: NA
Text: contention that the payroll tax, as a means

Speaker: NA
Text: of collecting necessary revenues, is un-.

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable, unjust and wrong. It is time the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government departed from its piecemeal

Speaker: NA
Text: approach to this matter and arranged for

Speaker: NA
Text: a re-assessment of the whole situation to see

Speaker: NA
Text: what can be done. If the Government feels

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is necessary to include the War

Speaker: NA
Text: Graves Commission as one of the exempted

Speaker: NA
Text: bodies-an d we wholeheartedly agree-an d

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is necessary to relieve the burden on

Speaker: NA
Text: the motor vehicle industry so that it may

Speaker: NA
Text: actively engage in world competition and

Speaker: NA
Text: promote our export drive, then surely it

Speaker: NA
Text: should accept the proposition that payroll

Speaker: NA
Text: tax should be completely removed in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of stimulating the entire economy.

Speaker: NA
Text: If it is good for the motor vehicle industry

Speaker: NA
Text: then surely it would be good for the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: community. It is about time the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at this matter seriously to see how

Speaker: NA
Text: far it can go along the road I have suggested.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Newcastle has

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with the subject of decentralisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: what might be accomplished in this direction

Speaker: NA
Text: by payroll tax concessions. If such conces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions are sound for the purpose of promot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing exports, then surely they are also sound

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of developing industries in

Speaker: NA
Text: country districts, industries that must meet

Speaker: NA
Text: greatly increased costs for such services as

Speaker: NA
Text: telephones and the transport of raw

Speaker: NA
Text: materials to factories and of manufactured

Speaker: NA
Text: products from factories to markets. So I

Speaker: NA
Text: say to the Government this afternoon that if

Speaker: NA
Text: it professes to think of the value of the

Speaker: NA
Text: rebate of payroll tax for export promotion

Speaker: NA
Text: it ought to promote decentralisation by lift-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this tax in country areas. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment ought to deal with the problems of

Speaker: NA
Text: expanding industries in country centres.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is neither time nor opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: discuss this aspect of the payroll tax prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem this afternoon since it does not con-

Speaker: NA
Text: form to the broad principles of the measure

Speaker: NA
Text: that we are considering.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Speaker, all honorable members know

Speaker: NA
Text: the great problems that face our country

Speaker: NA
Text: cities and towns today in building up their

Speaker: NA
Text: population and even in maintaining their

Speaker: NA
Text: existing population. I believe that if the

Speaker: NA
Text: lifting of the payroll tax would achieve what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government professes to hope for in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of decentralisation, we ought to go to

Speaker: NA
Text: the full distance in stimulating industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: country districts and repeal this tax insofar

Speaker: NA
Text: as it affects decentralised industries in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian hinterland. We ought to promote

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of our country centres, and

Speaker: NA
Text: this is one way in which the national

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament undoubtedly could help to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the establishment of industries

Speaker: NA
Text: in country centres. Frequently we hear in

Speaker: NA
Text: this chamber from the Minister for National

Speaker: NA
Text: Development ( Mr Fairbairn) and the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Trade and Industry ( Mr MCEwen)

Speaker: NA
Text: expressions of the Government's interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: decentralisation. But Ministers have never

Speaker: NA
Text: matched their brave words with the actions

Speaker: NA
Text: that are necessary.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have in my hand a cutting from the issue

Speaker: NA
Text: of 2nd December 1965 of the "Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Morning Herald "- a very important pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lication. This cutting contains a diagram

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been prepared by an electronic

Speaker: NA
Text: computer and which shows the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: damage, in varying degrees, that would

Speaker: NA
Text: result in the Sydney metropolitan area if a

Speaker: NA
Text: hydrogen bomb of one megaton power were

Speaker: NA
Text: detonated in Martin Place. A vast area

Speaker: NA
Text: would be devastated and atomic fallout

Speaker: NA
Text: would occur over an even wider area. This

Speaker: NA
Text: diagram shows the destruction and damage

Speaker: NA
Text: that would occur in the great hub of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial and commercial life of our nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I emphasise that this diagram has been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared not by human hands but by an elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tronic computer. Surely this indicates the

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency of the need for action today. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: known, Mr Speaker, that a submarine out

Speaker: NA
Text: to sea could fire projectiles at any of the

Speaker: NA
Text: centres on our coastline. One submarine

Speaker: NA
Text: could cause widespread destruction and

Speaker: NA
Text: chaos and bring ruin to our countryside.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest this afternoon that this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be carefully examined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Sir Robert Menzies) and

Speaker: NA
Text: everybody else concerned. The payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: is an irritating burden on local government

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities. It represents a charge upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: ratepayers. Indeed, to them it really repre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sents a tax upon a tax. Insofar as it is of

Speaker: NA
Text: this character it is an evil. This evil ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to be removed. The Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has failed to acknowledge the role of local

Speaker: NA
Text: government and the work that it does

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout this country. This Government

Speaker: NA
Text: refuses to recognise the importance of local

Speaker: NA
Text: government by entering into a partnership of

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Repeatedly honorable members

Speaker: NA
Text: on this side of the Parliament have sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted pleas for the holding of a conference

Speaker: NA
Text: between representatives of the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth and the State Governments and local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities for the purpose of considering

Speaker: NA
Text: the respective spheres of influence and func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and responsibilities so that each section

Speaker: NA
Text: of government may perform its rightful task

Speaker: NA
Text: in the development of this country. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth has repeatedly refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: take part in such discussions.

Speaker: NA
Text: City, municipal and shire councils, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: discharge of their functions, are invariably

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned with national objectives. Councils

Speaker: NA
Text: provide many services for the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth. We have heard the honorahle mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Herbert ( Mr Harding) describe the

Speaker: NA
Text: great work that is going on in the Towns-

Speaker: NA
Text: ville area as a result of the new flood of

Speaker: NA
Text: servicemen who quite properly are going

Speaker: NA
Text: north for the defence of Australia. As a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequence, new and important tasks and

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibilities have been imposed on local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities in the Townsville area. This

Speaker: NA
Text: means that the local ratepayers are obliged

Speaker: NA
Text: to submit to heavy rating for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: providing amenities and services. In addi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion, they are compelled to pay payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: on the money expended on wages for this

Speaker: NA
Text: work. This is the sort of thing that happens

Speaker: NA
Text: all the time. Recently the honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Newcastle in a question that he asked

Speaker: NA
Text: in this chamber directed attention to the

Speaker: NA
Text: need for a new aerodrome to serve the New-

Speaker: NA
Text: castle area. He pointed out that the burden

Speaker: NA
Text: of providing it would inevitably fall on the

Speaker: NA
Text: local ratepayers in the area administered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Newcastle City Council because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government had refused to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept its responsibility for providing a

Speaker: NA
Text: much needed aerodrome to serve the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: What are the services and amenities which

Speaker: NA
Text: are provided by local authorities and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of which represents a heavy burden

Speaker: NA
Text: on local citizens? Water supplies, sewerage,

Speaker: NA
Text: roads, streets, parks, playgrounds, halls,

Speaker: NA
Text: community centres, libraries, health services

Speaker: NA
Text: and the like all are needed increasingly as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the flood of migrants to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, for some time councils have

Speaker: NA
Text: been engaged on the construction of homes

Speaker: NA
Text: and on land development needed for fac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories to establish new industries in the

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign for decentralisation. All this rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resents development work in country centres

Speaker: NA
Text: and rural areas. Surely the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: has a responsibility at least for ensuring

Speaker: NA
Text: that councils, which are engaged on impor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant work for the nation, should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: subjected to a burden such as that to which

Speaker: NA
Text: they are subjected by the imposition of

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax. If this Government did the right

Speaker: NA
Text: thing it would accept its responsibility, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve councils of the burden of payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: and itself undertake many of the works

Speaker: NA
Text: carried out by councils since those works

Speaker: NA
Text: are essential to the progress and develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Australia and the expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: our nation. If they were not undertaken by

Speaker: NA
Text: councils the Commonwealth would be

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to undertake them just as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: obliged to undertake in this National Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: and in its own Territories work of the kind

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken elsewhere by councils.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Commonwealth does a grievous

Speaker: NA
Text: wrong to councils. It spends money ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained direcdy from the Australian tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers. Yet it obliges local authorities to

Speaker: NA
Text: borrow and to pay interest on their borrow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings in order to meet their commitments

Speaker: NA
Text: while at the same time they are also re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quired to pay payroll tax. The Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth refuses to do anything to help coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: cils to discharge their obligations. This sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of situation does not make sense and the

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner it is corrected the better. The fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth in its own Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tories incurs expenditure on services such

Speaker: NA
Text: as are provided elsewhere by councils em-

Speaker: NA
Text: phasises the need for early attention to be

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the matter. The tax burden imposed

Speaker: NA
Text: on local authorities is growing all the time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Councillor J. M. Smith, President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Shires Association of New South Wales, in

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast No. 722 made on behalf of that

Speaker: NA
Text: Association, said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Investigation has shown that since 1947 rates

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased by no less than 550 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: tbe same period the wholesale price index has

Speaker: NA
Text: by 149 per cent. This means that after allowing

Speaker: NA
Text: higher costs due to depreciated money values,

Speaker: NA
Text: Councils have been forced-i n order to meet their

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations-t o raise their rates by no less than

Speaker: NA
Text: 160 per cent, beyond this point per head of

Speaker: NA
Text: population.

Speaker: NA
Text: This indicates the burden imposed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: people in our communities as the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: paying their rates to local councils. Recently

Speaker: NA
Text: in New South Wales local government elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were held and many a good alderman

Speaker: NA
Text: and many a good councillor perhaps suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: fered a defeat because he had been obliged

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase rates in his area. The responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility ought to have been sheeted back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Parliament for failing to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: its responsibility in this field. The great work

Speaker: NA
Text: of our councils is emphasised in the periodic

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcasts of the Local Government Asso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciation. In broadcast 811 the speaker was

Speaker: NA
Text: Alderman A. E. Shaw, President of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government Association of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales. He pointed to the great

Speaker: NA
Text: development in the Lismore area and men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned that the city of Lismore won the

Speaker: NA
Text: local government prize, the A. R. Bluett

Speaker: NA
Text: Memorial Award, for its great work. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: During 1964 the Lismore City Hall was com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pleted. The building consists of two levels-on e

Speaker: NA
Text: occupied by the main auditorium capable of seating

Speaker: NA
Text: 1,000 people and the other consisting of three

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller auditoriums with all modern associated

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. It cost Â£177,500-finance d entirely from

Speaker: NA
Text: loan funds. Thus the people of Lismore are now

Speaker: NA
Text: amply provided for by way of entertainment and

Speaker: NA
Text: cultural activities of all kinds. Two baby health

Speaker: NA
Text: centres

Speaker: NA
Text: That is building up the nation-

Speaker: NA
Text: of modern design, fully equipped, were also pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vided-on e near the business centre and the other

Speaker: NA
Text: at South Lismore, catering for maternal and infant

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is national work of the highest order,

Speaker: NA
Text: yet the payroll tax is levied on the spending

Speaker: NA
Text: of that money to build up this beautiful city

Speaker: NA
Text: and to advance this country. Tbe report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the broadcast continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: A feature of the Council's activities was the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision made for industrial development. An area

Speaker: NA
Text: of 82 acres has been set aside and a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: start made with the provision of roads of access,

Speaker: NA
Text: water and sewerage, and electricity. The result is an

Speaker: NA
Text: area ideally suited for industry in reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: proximity to residential areas. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Lithgow, Bathurst, Goulburn, Orange and

Speaker: NA
Text: Over all the other cities are engaged in similar

Speaker: NA
Text: risen work. The responsibility rests with the

Speaker: NA
Text: for Commonwealth Government to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter. The tax levied on local govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is Â£2.6 million. This burden of Â£2.6

Speaker: NA
Text: million ought to be waived. It is a burden

Speaker: NA
Text: which is utterly unjust and utterly unfair,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it is something that cannot be justified

Speaker: NA
Text: in any circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: When one thinks of the struggling

Speaker: NA
Text: councils trying to make ends meet one

Speaker: NA
Text: realises that the Commonwealth has a

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility to review its attitude in regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to this matter. The responsibility of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth to pay rates should be un-

Speaker: NA
Text: doubted and never disputed. Yet the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government will haggle over

Speaker: NA
Text: making some ex gratia payment to a council

Speaker: NA
Text: for the purpose of carrying out its duties

Speaker: NA
Text: in its respective area. When the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government spends money on ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices, no payroll tax is levied, but when

Speaker: NA
Text: a local authority spends money on the work

Speaker: NA
Text: alongside that of the Commonwealth this

Speaker: NA
Text: burden is imposed. I put to the House that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Government occupies a

Speaker: NA
Text: privileged position. That is admitted. It has

Speaker: NA
Text: the constitutional power, it has the avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able finance, it has the taxation resources,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it should also look with responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: to other departments and organisations of

Speaker: NA
Text: government to see that this burden does

Speaker: NA
Text: not reach the breaking point at which it

Speaker: NA
Text: stands at the present time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The problem of rates is one of the most

Speaker: NA
Text: serious ones affecting the people of our

Speaker: NA
Text: country. When this legislation is finally

Speaker: NA
Text: passed, if the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: refuses to accept the amendment to be

Speaker: NA
Text: moved subsequently by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Melbourne Ports it should review

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole matter of the payroll tax. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: in my hand a letter addressed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer ( Mr Harold Holt) by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Secretary of the Australian Council of Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government Associations dated Hth July

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965. The letter states-

Speaker: NA
Text: As you are well aware, representations have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made by the Australian Council on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of occasions seeking exemption of local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities from the payment of payroll tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the last meeting of the Australian Council,

Speaker: NA
Text: I was directed to resubmit the request for your

Speaker: NA
Text: further consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no doubt that you are well aware of

Speaker: NA
Text: the grounds on which local government considers

Speaker: NA
Text: it should be freed from the payment of this tax

Speaker: NA
Text: but perhaps it would be relevant to restate the

Speaker: NA
Text: points which motivate the Australian Council in

Speaker: NA
Text: making its submission.

Speaker: NA
Text: These, of general consideration, are-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) PayroU tax in itself in an uneconomical

Speaker: NA
Text: tax because it penalises the employer-

Speaker: NA
Text: whether governmental or private-wh o

Speaker: NA
Text: employs the most people.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) The cost of collection of the tax is high

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the revenue received.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) In 1961 the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: legislated granting rebates of the tax

Speaker: NA
Text: imposed on wages paid by producers

Speaker: NA
Text: for exports. These rebates amount to at

Speaker: NA
Text: least Â£2 million per annum. If this

Speaker: NA
Text: can be done for exporters, it could

Speaker: NA
Text: equally be applied to local government,

Speaker: NA
Text: which makes no profit but serves the

Speaker: NA
Text: community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aspects peculiar to local government-

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Councils draw their revenue in the

Speaker: NA
Text: main from land rating. Hence,

Speaker: NA
Text: in calling on councils to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribute to the Commonwealth, the

Speaker: NA
Text: latter, in effect, is demanding a

Speaker: NA
Text: share of councils' income from

Speaker: NA
Text: rating. It is a tax on a tax. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: understood that the amount collec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted by the Commonwealth in pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: roll tax from local government,

Speaker: NA
Text: approximates Â£21 million per

Speaker: NA
Text: annum. This is a substantial sum

Speaker: NA
Text: which councils can ill afford.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore, this "loss" must

Speaker: NA
Text: minimise to that extent, the works

Speaker: NA
Text: which may be carried out by local

Speaker: NA
Text: authorities.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The Commonwealth, while levying

Speaker: NA
Text: local government, is not willing to

Speaker: NA
Text: pay rates to local government on

Speaker: NA
Text: properties wbich it owns.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) There is no equity in one governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: authority imposing burdens on

Speaker: NA
Text: another. It presupposes that the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities of councils are of a lesser

Speaker: NA
Text: significance than those of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth; whereas, in fact, the

Speaker: NA
Text: services given by councils are basic

Speaker: NA
Text: to community living.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Any body-whethe r it be State or

Speaker: NA
Text: local government-concerne d with

Speaker: NA
Text: the development of the country and

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenditure of a large propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of its revenue on capital de-

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment, should not have to pay

Speaker: NA
Text: a tax on wages of labour employed

Speaker: NA
Text: in carrying out such works.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Council is aware that in reject-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing its claims on earlier occasions, it has been

Speaker: NA
Text: contended that because State Governments and

Speaker: NA
Text: semi-governmental authorities have to pay tax, then

Speaker: NA
Text: it is logical that local government shouid do so

Speaker: NA
Text: also.

Speaker: NA
Text: In that regard, 1 am to point out that the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth directly assists the States in meeting

Speaker: NA
Text: their commitments but no such arrangement

Speaker: NA
Text: applies for local government. It is true that local

Speaker: NA
Text: government does get some assistance in the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: struction and maintenance of roads in sparsely

Speaker: NA
Text: populated areas, but had it not been given, there

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been little hope of improving local

Speaker: NA
Text: roads with the limited financial resources available.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the financial year 1963-64, the contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: by local government by way of payroll tax to the

Speaker: NA
Text: coffers of the Commonwealth, amounted to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£2,600,000. This is more than double what was

Speaker: NA
Text: Financial Year

Speaker: NA
Text: These statistics show that the burden of

Speaker: NA
Text: payroll tax has assumed frightening propor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions to local government generally.

Speaker: NA
Text: lt is apparent that the greater the degree of

Speaker: NA
Text: Local Government participation in the tripartite

Speaker: NA
Text: federal system of Government in Australia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: heavier the tax burden it must shoulder for

Speaker: NA
Text: another form of government administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since many of the functions undertaken by Local

Speaker: NA
Text: Government are, in the final analysis, of a social

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare nature and therefore, more properly the

Speaker: NA
Text: province of the Commonwealth, to be met from

Speaker: NA
Text: Income Tax (which now embraces the former and

Speaker: NA
Text: separate Social Services Tax)

Speaker: NA
Text: Which, of course, has been eliminated-

Speaker: NA
Text: the inequity of continuing to impose Pay Roll

Speaker: NA
Text: Tax on Local Government is surely apparent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thc Australian Council is concerned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: growing extent to which Local Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: each of the States is called upon tofinanceactivi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties which are not directly its responsibility and

Speaker: NA
Text: it urges most strongly the view, that the time has

Speaker: NA
Text: come when Local Government simply cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: afford to continue to do this and at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time properly discharge the obligations which

Speaker: NA
Text: properly belongs to it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your sympathetic consideration of this submis-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion will be appreciated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer replied that the matter would

Speaker: NA
Text: be considered with the Budget. The Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: has come and gone, but the payroll tax

Speaker: NA
Text: remains a burden on ratepayers throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I shall be delighted to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the amendment when it is moved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: paid 10 years ago-a s the following table clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: shows.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: which then follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: Section 15 of thc Principal Act is amended by

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the following paragraph:-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Section proposed to be amended-

Speaker: NA
Text: 15. The provisions of this Part shall not apply

Speaker: NA
Text: to wages paid-

Speaker: NA

Text: Melbourne Ports) [5.57] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I formally move-

Speaker: NA
Text: After "amended" insert-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) by inserting after paragraph (ba) the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing paragraph:-

Speaker: NA
Text: " (bb) by a municipal or other local

Speaker: NA
Text: governing body, or an

Speaker: NA
Text: authority established for the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of carrying out all

Speaker: NA
Text: or any of the functions ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: narily carried out by such a

Speaker: NA
Text: body, otherwise than in the

Speaker: NA
Text: conduct of an enterprise

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in the opinion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner, is a trading

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprise;".

Speaker: NA
Text: I explained the amendment in my second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question put-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the words proposed to be added ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Cream's amendment) be added.
