Speaker: NA
Text: 11 CUSTOMS TARIFF (DUMPING AND

Speaker: NA
Text: SUBSIDIES) BILL 1965.

Speaker: NA
Text: AYES.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 16th September

Speaker: NA
Text: (vide page 978), on motion by Mr Bury-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Yarra) [8.0] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs

Speaker: NA
Text: Mortimer, J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nicholls, M . H .

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1961 to

Speaker: NA
Text: give power to determine or define an export

Speaker: NA
Text: Pollard, R. T.

Speaker: NA
Text: Reynolds, L . J.

Speaker: NA
Text: price where goods that are imported to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are, in the opinion of the Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: subject to reasonable grounds for believing

Speaker: NA
Text: that the documentary export price or other

Speaker: NA
Text: information provided in respect of them is

Speaker: NA
Text: Tellers: not adequate to determine what the price

Speaker: NA
Text: Coutts, W. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Duthie, G. W. A .

Speaker: NA
Text: should be. When the Bill was introduced the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Housing ( Mr Bury)

Speaker: NA
Text: NOES. pointed out that the level of any

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes, T. E. F.

Speaker: NA
Text: Irwin, L . H .

Speaker: NA
Text: protection granted to an economic and

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient Australian industry should be based,

Speaker: NA
Text: or is based, on the assumption that goods

Speaker: NA
Text: imported into Australia are sold by the

Speaker: NA
Text: exporter at a fair and reasonable price not

Speaker: NA
Text: Mackay, M . G.

Speaker: NA
Text: Maisey, D. W.

Speaker: NA
Text: below normal value. This means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: export price should be not less than the

Speaker: NA
Text: Nixon, P. J.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opperman, H . F.

Speaker: NA
Text: price at which the goods are available in the

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic market of the country of export.

Speaker: NA
Text: From that concept comes the concept of

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping. If goods are exported from one

Speaker: NA
Text: country to another at a price which is

Speaker: NA
Text: Swartz, R. W. C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Turner, H . B.

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly less than that, then the practice

Speaker: NA
Text: is called dumping.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has told us that it frequently

Speaker: NA
Text: happens that goods are sold for export at

Speaker: NA
Text: Turnbull, W. G.

Speaker: NA
Text: prices which, in comparison to their normal

Speaker: NA
Text: values, are not fair and reasonable and

Speaker: NA
Text: PAIRS, which are deliberately set at unduly low

Speaker: NA
Text: Menzies, Sir Robert

Speaker: NA
Text: Hasluck, P. M . C.

Speaker: NA
Text: levels. There could be many purposes for

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting conduct of this kind-t o capture

Speaker: NA
Text: a market in some other country then, when

Speaker: NA
Text: having captured it and perhaps eliminated

Speaker: NA
Text: producers in that country or competitors

Speaker: NA
Text: from elsewhere, to bring the price back to

Speaker: NA
Text: one which may give the exporter a greater

Speaker: NA
Text: return. It may be that a country possesses an

Speaker: NA
Text: industry which is planned to expand and, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the course of doing this, it may pay to sell

Speaker: NA
Text: the products of that industry at lower than

Speaker: NA
Text: what could be regarded as normal values.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes exporting, which can be defined

Speaker: NA
Text: as dumping in the manner that the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has looked at the matter, may not, in fact,

Speaker: NA
Text: be an uneconomic process, it may not be a

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate one to damage or to exclude a

Speaker: NA
Text: competitor, but it may be the result of the

Speaker: NA
Text: particular stage of development of the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has told us that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has taken the view that dumping in

Speaker: NA
Text: all its forms must be countered whenever it

Speaker: NA
Text: damages or threatens to damage an Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian industry. Until this amendment was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced the law was that evidence was

Speaker: NA
Text: required from the importer or from other

Speaker: NA
Text: people to endeavour to ascertain what, in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, was the normal value of the commodity

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned that might have been suspected

Speaker: NA
Text: of being dumped. For all practical purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister and the Department were

Speaker: NA
Text: limited to the evidence that was procurable.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have been told that a complete review

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made of the Act and its short-

Speaker: NA
Text: comings in relation to the dumping prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tices that were impairing the protection to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industry. The Bill incorporates

Speaker: NA
Text: the result of this review.

Speaker: NA
Text: One clause is of special significance and

Speaker: NA
Text: the rest are incidental. Thatclause, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, is clause 3. It vests in the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Customs and Excise a power to deter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mine the export price of goods exported to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia where, in his opinion, there are

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable grounds for believing that the

Speaker: NA
Text: documentary export price has been fixed

Speaker: NA
Text: with a view to avoiding dumping duty or

Speaker: NA
Text: other special duties payable in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the provisions of the Act. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: has pointed out that this amendment has a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide effect. It introduces into the legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: an element of flexibility necessary to counter

Speaker: NA
Text: all the various practices that have arisen.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition recognises that difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of the kind that have been described

Speaker: NA
Text: may arise and that the Department and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister need power to be able to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with them. But, of course, this is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary power. We realise that when we

Speaker: NA
Text: give the Minister power we are really giving

Speaker: NA
Text: it to the Department. Let us be quite frank

Speaker: NA
Text: about this: The Minister will do what he

Speaker: NA
Text: is advised to do; he will not be making the

Speaker: NA
Text: investigations himself but he will rely upon

Speaker: NA
Text: and trust those who are in a position to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise him. We are giving a very arbitrary

Speaker: NA
Text: power to determine the export price of goods

Speaker: NA
Text: where tbe Minister is not satisfied with the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence that becomes available to him. I

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasise to the House that this is in fact

Speaker: NA
Text: a very arbitrary power and one that could

Speaker: NA
Text: go wrong. It will have to be watched very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully. A power of this sort can be

Speaker: NA
Text: dangerous and it should not be lightly

Speaker: NA
Text: given nor should it be lightly used.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have seen a little of this in recent years

Speaker: NA
Text: and I know that there are interests involved

Speaker: NA
Text: that do not always lead the parties con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned to act impartially. I have seen a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of cases where Australian manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facturers have been very quick on the draw

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of some competition from over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas. One feels, as I have felt from time

Speaker: NA
Text: to time, that the Department is a little more

Speaker: NA
Text: inclined to take notice of the manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: than it is to take notice of the importers-

Speaker: NA
Text: who also have a considerable amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: capital and interest involved-whe n it

Speaker: NA
Text: comes to a question of deciding between one

Speaker: NA
Text: and the other. 1 have noticed this recently

Speaker: NA
Text: particularly with imports from countries

Speaker: NA
Text: that may not be popular with Conservative

Speaker: NA
Text: people in Australia. I am referring to

Speaker: NA
Text: countries like China and some of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munist countries in Europe. I know from

Speaker: NA
Text: my own experience that importers of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: modities from countries like those and also

Speaker: NA
Text: from other countries in Europe-an d here

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer to West Germany in particular-

Speaker: NA
Text: have outlaid a considerable amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: money on transactions which, from all the

Speaker: NA
Text: evidence I can see, were fairly normal; but

Speaker: NA
Text: then there has been a suspicion that dump-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing has been involved, because the process

Speaker: NA
Text: of costing may not have been quite the

Speaker: NA
Text: same as that with which we are familiar,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the importer has been caught. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: he has priced his commodities properly and

Speaker: NA
Text: in some cases has actually sold them on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian market at what he regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: as a genuine price, he has been told that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has to pay a dumping duty because

Speaker: NA
Text: those commodities were held to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: dumped.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have no objection to a provision of

Speaker: NA
Text: this kind, and I have no objection to its

Speaker: NA
Text: being used, but when an importer imports

Speaker: NA
Text: goods in good faith and sells them in good

Speaker: NA
Text: faith at a price which is determined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: import price that he paid, he should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to pay a penalty if it is felt he

Speaker: NA
Text: has acted in good faith. In one case in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of which I have made representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in the last few weeks I find that there

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be a dumping duty-securitie s have

Speaker: NA
Text: had to be taken out-an d the man will have

Speaker: NA
Text: to pay up even though I think good faith

Speaker: NA
Text: was involved all the way through the trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: action. Clause 9 of the Bill provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: there shall be no retrospective application

Speaker: NA
Text: in this respect. That is an excellent

Speaker: NA
Text: principle. I believe that we should protect

Speaker: NA
Text: industry against dumping but I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: think we should do it retrospectively. I

Speaker: NA
Text: approve of the provision in clause 9 but I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that where securities have been held

Speaker: NA
Text: in the past, in effect there has been retro-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of the clauses of the Bill are merely

Speaker: NA
Text: drafting changes embodying no variation in

Speaker: NA
Text: the interpretation or application of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions. Some of the amendments in clause 3

Speaker: NA
Text: are of this nature; those in clause 4 are

Speaker: NA
Text: almost completely so; and clauses 5, 6, 7

Speaker: NA
Text: and 8 are the same. Clause 9 provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments in the Bill are not to be applied

Speaker: NA
Text: retrospectively. The Bill is not therefore one

Speaker: NA
Text: of great substance, although the powers

Speaker: NA
Text: given in clause 3 can have very wide appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation and could be exercised in a very

Speaker: NA
Text: arbitrary way.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not intend to delay the House any

Speaker: NA
Text: longer on this Bill. The Opposition does not

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose it, but we emphasise the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: which clause 3 provides an arbitrary power

Speaker: NA
Text: which could be wrongly used. We emphasise

Speaker: NA
Text: that its application has to be watched very

Speaker: NA
Text: carefully.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: Wakefield) [8.12] -I , too,

Speaker: NA
Text: give the Bill my blessing. I realise that there

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be effective dumping legislation. The

Speaker: NA
Text: need for this legislation has been brought

Speaker: NA
Text: out quite clearly in the Vernon Committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: report, which deals with dumping at some

Speaker: NA
Text: length. In paragraph 14.107 the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: reported-

Speaker: NA
Text: There is need for effective anti-dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, which must be regarded

Speaker: NA
Text: to the normal tariff-making process. The absence

Speaker: NA
Text: of fully effective legislation may be expected to

Speaker: NA
Text: lead, and in Australia has led, to pressure for

Speaker: NA
Text: prohibitive or nearly-prohibitive ordinary tariffs.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is therefore important to review the scope for

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthening the existing law.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is clear that the Vernon Committee try

Speaker: NA
Text: realised that there was a need to alter

Speaker: NA
Text: strengthen our dumping laws, but for one

Speaker: NA
Text: main reason-tha t if dumping can be preton

Speaker: NA
Text: vented it is possible to get duties down

Speaker: NA
Text: a more realistic level. It is the fear that

Speaker: NA
Text: goods may be dumped that has, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, led industries to ask for, and somecretion.

Speaker: NA
Text: times to demand, duties which, but for this,

Speaker: NA
Text: would appear unnecessarily high.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is interesting that this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: the first fruits only, J hope, of the Vernon

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee's tariff recommendations. I can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not help but comment rather sourly that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is the kind of thing that we expect from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Government seems to be

Speaker: NA
Text: more -ready to erect barriers than to take

Speaker: NA
Text: them down. Here the Vernon Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: has recommended that the dumping pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures be altered. There are a lot of things

Speaker: NA
Text: in the tariff chapters of the Vernon Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee's report that I hope the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is looking at with equal enthusiasm. If I

Speaker: may refer to them, Mr SPEAKER
Text: onl y in

Speaker: NA
Text: passing, I assure you-the y include recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendations that the general level of tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: should be no higher than slightly less than

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per cent, unless a higher level can be

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughly justified; that industries that are

Speaker: NA
Text: in existence are not necessarily entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: protection; that references should cease to

Speaker: NA
Text: shuttle backwards and forwards between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Advisory Authority and the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board; and that tariffs should not be used

Speaker: NA
Text: as a method of creating employment. These

Speaker: NA
Text: are the kinds of things that I urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to look at with the same kind

Speaker: NA
Text: of enthusiasm that it brought to bear in

Speaker: NA
Text: considering this comparatively minor recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendation in the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: In an environment which becomes more

Speaker: NA
Text: complicated where the methods of evading

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping laws are becoming more cunning

Speaker: NA
Text: and effective, there is a need for the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to have effective power to deal with

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping, but I am glad that the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Yarra (Dr JF CAIRNS) re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the immense power that is given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Minister for Customs and Excise and

Speaker: NA
Text: his Department, because they can, by a

Speaker: NA
Text: legisstroke of the pen, impose or considerably

Speaker: NA
Text: as a supplement increase a duty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us see what we are doing. Essentially

Speaker: NA
Text: we are trying to stop people from selling

Speaker: NA
Text: things to us cheaply. This is the queer

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of thing that we do these days. We

Speaker: NA
Text: to stop people in other lands from selling

Speaker: NA
Text: and things to us cheaply. Suppose that the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal value of paper overseas is Â£100 a

Speaker: NA
Text: and that the actual price overseas is

Speaker: NA
Text: to found to be Â£90 a ton. Then the duty auto-

Speaker: NA
Text: matically is increased by Â£10-fro m Â£32 to

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£42. This is done at the Minister's dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: This is a considerable power to

Speaker: NA
Text: give to any Minister. I agree with the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member for Yarra that this is the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of power that should be used with

Speaker: NA
Text: very great discretion. I am aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pressures that come from manufacturing

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and I was glad to hear the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Yarra mention these

Speaker: NA
Text: specifically, because industry seems to me

Speaker: NA
Text: rather too readily to take the easy way

Speaker: NA
Text: out. If industries are in difficulties they go

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Department and urge it-no t always

Speaker: NA
Text: successfully-t o take action against dump-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. It seems to me that sometimes we must

Speaker: NA
Text: be rather sceptical of the grounds on which

Speaker: NA
Text: this dumping action is taken. This kind of

Speaker: NA
Text: aclion has peculiar results. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: recently discussed in some detail and elo-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence the restrictive trade practices

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, it is interesting to realise that

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to Scandinavian paper there is what

Speaker: NA
Text: is called a " Scan-Fin " price ring.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I point out that

Speaker: NA
Text: this is a limited measure. We are dealing

Speaker: NA
Text: with freight dumping only.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: Wit h respect, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing only with freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Th e main subject that, too.

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Chair is legislation to counter

Speaker: NA
Text: freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I am sorry, but there is

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which has not yet been moved.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Apparently , the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member is anticipating the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: stage. The amendment is not before

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: Tha t is right. I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been discussing freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I thought the honortioned

Speaker: NA
Text: able member was referring to paper from

Speaker: NA
Text: Scandinavia.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I was referring to dumpin

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, but freight has not been mentioned.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber would be very much in order if he Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned freight.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I n Scandinavia there is

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement whereby a common price

Speaker: NA
Text: fixed for paper. The Attorney-General ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Snedden) would call it a restrictive trade

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. The Scan-Fin price becomes

Speaker: NA
Text: normal value when the Department of Board

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs and Excise looks at it. If some-

Speaker: NA
Text: body starts to break the ring and to sell

Speaker: NA
Text: paper cheaply to Australia, the operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: this dumping procedure puts a stop to that

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. This is a queer kind of way in

Speaker: NA
Text: which we go about things. We are deliber-

Speaker: NA
Text: ately encouraging the operation of price

Speaker: NA
Text: rings overseas and we are bending back-

Speaker: NA
Text: wards to stop them here. The kind of think-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing has peculiar side effects. It is interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: to realise that in many instances, again

Speaker: NA
Text: especially with paper, there is a price for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia which is about Â£3 or Â£4 a ton

Speaker: NA
Text: higher than the price for shipment to other

Speaker: NA
Text: places. This is done to ensure that dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: duties are not attracted. This is the queer

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of world in which we live. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberately setting out to do this. It is being

Speaker: NA
Text: in done with the highest of motives, but one

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot help feeling a little sceptical. The

Speaker: NA
Text: operations of the Government in this regard

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to be devoted to seeing that price rings

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas are given full rein while in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia it is trying to prevent price rings from

Speaker: NA
Text: developing. I wonder whether we are

Speaker: NA
Text: not allowed to discuss freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I began to wonder

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I am asking you, Sir. I

Speaker: NA
Text: trust that I shall be allowed to discuss it

Speaker: NA
Text: an now because, if I am not, I will have to

Speaker: NA
Text: speak again in the Committee stage,

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I t would be more in

Speaker: NA
Text: order for the honorable member to discuss

Speaker: NA
Text: the it in Committee when speaking to the

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment that has been foreshadowed.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I shall devote myself to it

Speaker: NA
Text: at that stage. I want to repeat one point.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Yarra men-

Speaker: NA
Text: this. The Minister is given great

Speaker: NA
Text: power, but it is true that the Bill, as it is

Speaker: NA
Text: at present drawn, places the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: the position of a watchdog. At this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: at least a case has to go to the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: for inquiry. Clause 4 of the Bill provides-

Speaker: NA
Text: If the Minister, after inquiry and report by the

Speaker: NA
Text: I will teU the House of the way that this

Speaker: NA
Text: an procedure has worked in one case, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: is think only one case. The Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at the case in question. I think it

Speaker: NA
Text: dealt with kraft paper; it is in the last re-

Speaker: NA
Text: the port of the Tariff Board on paper. The

Speaker: NA
Text: said that it had been unable to find

Speaker: NA
Text: any evidence of dumping of kraft paper

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place, but the Department of

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs and Excise applied dumping duties.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned this matter in the House on a

Speaker: NA
Text: previous occasion. This action may be legal,

Speaker: NA
Text: but it is not right. We have understood that

Speaker: NA
Text: this action would be taken only after the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board had reported but, in this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance, the Department took the action after

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tariff Board inquiry found that

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping was not taking place. I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that this has happened only

Speaker: NA
Text: once. I realise, of course, that the reports

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Tariff Board are not sacred; they

Speaker: NA
Text: can be departed from. But if they are de-

Speaker: NA
Text: parted from, I think it is proper that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister should make it perfectly plain

Speaker: NA
Text: that the action is being taken despite the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the Tariff Board. I

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat that, as far as I know, this hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pened on only one occasion, but I note

Speaker: NA
Text: with great concern that when it did hap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pen no statement was made by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Customs and Excise.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is another difficulty in this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess. When the Minister, through his De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment, thinks that dumping is taking

Speaker: NA
Text: place, a notice is published in the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Gazette ". This is referred to in the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: The information then becomes public

Speaker: NA
Text: property. The difficulty we face is that, as

Speaker: NA
Text: far as I know, the gazettals are never can-

Speaker: NA
Text: celled. The threat that hangs over the head

Speaker: NA
Text: of the importer is left hanging there. Even

Speaker: NA
Text: if, after inquiry, it is found that dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: is not taking place, the "Gazette" notice

Speaker: NA
Text: still remains in force. I should think that,

Speaker: NA
Text: if after gazettal it is found that dumping

Speaker: NA
Text: is not taking place, the proper action for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department to take is to notify in the

Speaker: NA
Text: " Gazette" that these goods are not now

Speaker: NA
Text: under inquiry. I have discussed this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: with officers of the Department and I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand that they recognise that this

Speaker: NA
Text: is a weakness and they would hope to take

Speaker: NA
Text: this action as soon as the staff position

Speaker: NA
Text: allows them to do so. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, when replying, will give me an

Speaker: NA
Text: assurance that this wiil be done. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: he will admit that it should be done.

Speaker: NA
Text: Every time we deal with tariff matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot help noticing the immense com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plexity of them. The procedure I have out-

Speaker: NA
Text: lined tonight is an example of the difficul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties and complexities that arise. Those of

Speaker: NA
Text: us who remember the size of the new

Speaker: NA
Text: schedule dealt with under the Brussels

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will be appalled at the difficulty

Speaker: NA
Text: of finding a way through it and of under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing this Frankenstein monster that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have created. We created it with the best of

Speaker: NA
Text: intentions, I admit, but I certainly do not

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to understand the monster properly.

Speaker: NA
Text: Even you, Sir, I think would have some

Speaker: NA
Text: hesitation in saying that you understand it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I will recognise freight

Speaker: NA
Text: when the honorable member comes to it.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I admit that the proce-

Speaker: NA
Text: dures we have adopted in this House have

Speaker: NA
Text: helped our discussions on tariff matters,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I pay tribute to the Standing Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee for the assistance they have

Speaker: NA
Text: given. However, the fact remains that we

Speaker: NA
Text: have, for the best possible reasons and with

Speaker: NA
Text: the best intentions, created an animal that

Speaker: NA
Text: none of us really understands. I think we

Speaker: NA
Text: should make deliberate efforts to try to

Speaker: NA
Text: simplify the system whenever we can. With

Speaker: NA
Text: due humility, I suggest we are making the

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures even more difficult. People feel

Speaker: NA
Text: that they must come to Canberra to put

Speaker: NA
Text: their case to the Department. I admit that

Speaker: NA
Text: on many occasions in the past I have been

Speaker: NA
Text: critical of the operations of the officers. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have always thought that they had an inbuilt

Speaker: NA
Text: bias towards erecting barriers rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: taking them down. I am beginning to change

Speaker: NA
Text: my mind. I realise now that they have a

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult job to do. But whichever way they

Speaker: NA
Text: do their job)- I know they have the best

Speaker: NA
Text: of intentions-th e fact remains that this is

Speaker: NA
Text: a complicated machine to work. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: people, particularly small importers, find

Speaker: NA
Text: that they must come to Canberra to put

Speaker: NA
Text: their case to the Department, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: on dumping. It is a complicated and expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive machine to operate. I do not blame

Speaker: NA
Text: also anybody for this; it is the nature of the

Speaker: NA
Text: beast. But let us take every opportunity we

Speaker: NA
Text: can to try to simplify it in some way.

Speaker: NA
Text: Shortly, we will introduce decimal currency.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I think the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member is engaging in a general de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate on every aspect. The subject matter

Speaker: NA
Text: before the Chair is freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: No , Sir, not yet. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: not come to it.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Tha t is the trouble. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am trying to point out to the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman that he is engaging in a general

Text: debate on tariff policy. I suggest he should

Text: relate his remarks to the Bill.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: W e have not come to

Speaker: NA
Text: freight yet. The Minister has not yet moved

Speaker: NA
Text: his amendment about freight dumping.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! I direct the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the honorable member to the

Text: Bill. It deals with freight dumping, and

Speaker: NA
Text: thing that does not relate to that point

Speaker: NA
Text: irrelevant.

Text: Mr Speaker, may 1 take

Speaker: NA
Text: a point of order? With due respect to you,

Text: Sir, I think some of the provisions in the

Text: Bill refer to other aspects of dumping and

Speaker: NA
Text: I would importune the Chair to give the

Text: Order ! I again call the

Text: honorable member for Wakefield.

Text: Sir , I am not canvassing

Speaker: NA
Text: your ruling for one moment, but, when I

Text: say that this is a complicated Bill, I

Speaker: NA
Text: that you will recognise by your ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: was making a plea to have the system simposition

Speaker: NA
Text: plified.

Text: I do not see any refermember

Speaker: NA
Text: ence to decimal currency in the Bill.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: I thought it would be a

Speaker: NA
Text: useful addition to make. All I was going

Text: to say in passing is that it would be useful,

Speaker: NA
Text: view of the fact that next year decimal

Speaker: NA
Text: currency will be introduced, to measure

Text: dumping duties in decimal currency. We

Speaker: NA
Text: could then have the measurement made to that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the duty is worked out in pounds, shillings

Text: and pence. This seems to make things

Speaker: NA
Text: unnecessarily complicated. I can see more

Speaker: NA
Text: virtue, not only in simplicity-whic h I

Speaker: NA
Text: think is always desirable-bu t also in speed,

Text: and cheapness of operation, in having

Text: value worked out to the nearest dollar.

Speaker: NA
Text: In New Zealand the value of the duty is

Speaker: NA
Text: worked out to the nearest pound sterling.

Speaker: NA
Text: To inflict an unnecessary complication

Speaker: NA
Text: the form of a minute money measurement

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to be unnecessary, and I urge the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Supply to pass on to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Customs and Excise in another

Speaker: NA
Text: place an urgent recommendation that

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure I suggest be adopted and the

Speaker: NA
Text: value for dumping duties be worked out

Speaker: NA
Text: to the nearest dollar instead of in pounds,

Speaker: NA
Text: shillings and pence as at present. That, I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure, would simplify the procedure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Having said that, and having offered

Speaker: NA
Text: some criticism of the operation of the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: and the way the machine works, I want to

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat my general willingness to admit that

Speaker: NA
Text: anythere is need for effective dumping legisla-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: These amendments are intended to coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter certain trade practices which have only

Speaker: NA
Text: recently come under notice. These practices

Speaker: NA
Text: will, if they continue unchecked, undermine

Speaker: NA
Text: the tariff protection afforded Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: industries with consequential damage to

Speaker: NA
Text: those industries. One of the most important

Speaker: NA
Text: elements which must be taken into account

Speaker: NA
Text: in determining the prices at which imported

Speaker: NA
Text: goods can be sold on the Australian market

Speaker: NA
Text: in competition with locally produced goods

Speaker: NA
Text: is the overseas freight cost. In assessing the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of tariff necessary to protect efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian industries all elements of cost,

Speaker: NA
Text: including the cost of overseas freight,

Speaker: NA
Text: associated with the imported product are

Speaker: NA
Text: taken into account. Needless to say the level

Speaker: NA
Text: of tariff protection is based on the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: or ruling costs associated with the imported

Speaker: NA
Text: product. Hence, if overseas suppliers are

Speaker: NA
Text: able to negotiate freight rates which are

Speaker: NA
Text: significantly lower than the normal rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: then obviously the competitive position of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian industry is placed in jeopardy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recent experience has shown that, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly for industrial chemicals, the freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rates for certain shipments have been very

Speaker: NA
Text: much lower than the normal rates which

Speaker: NA
Text: would have been taken into account in

Speaker: NA
Text: assessing the level of tariff protection. I has

Speaker: NA
Text: been found that certain chemicals have been

Speaker: NA
Text: carried on charter vessels at rates which are

Speaker: NA
Text: only one third of the ruling rates.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is some doubt as to whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: existing provisions of the Customs Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dumping and Subsidies) Act 1961 embodies

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to counter all forms of freight dumphigh.

Speaker: NA
Text: ing. The amendment which I have just pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed merely restores the provisions which

Speaker: NA
Text: were incorporated for many years in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Tariff (Industries Preservation)

Speaker: NA
Text: which was repealed in 1961 when the

Speaker: NA
Text: sent Act was introduced. The proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments to Australia's anti-dumping law

Speaker: NA
Text: stem from the Government's determination

Speaker: NA
Text: to protect local industry against the invidious

Speaker: NA
Text: practice of dumping in all its varied forms.

Speaker: NA
Text: exThere is no need for me to reiterate here the

Speaker: NA
Text: of kind of damage that dumping can do to Aus-

Text: Australian industry and the Australian economy

Speaker: NA
Text: the as a whole. Honorable members will recall

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Committee of Economic Enquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed concern regarding the effects of

Speaker: NA
Text: predumping and emphasised the necessity for

Speaker: NA
Text: the strengthening the existing law. That we are

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Yarra) [8.47] - Mr .

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman, the Opposition does not oppose

Speaker: NA
Text: what the Minister for Supply ( Mr Fairhall)

Speaker: NA
Text: is proposing by the introduction of these

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments. But I should like to be given

Speaker: NA
Text: a little more objective information about

Speaker: NA
Text: freight dumping than the Minister has

Speaker: NA
Text: given us. He has provided us with a vivid

Speaker: NA
Text: description about what happens but has

Speaker: NA
Text: not said one word about why it happens.

Speaker: NA
Text: He has told us that sometimes exporters

Speaker: NA
Text: are able to negotiate freight rates at less

Speaker: NA
Text: than the normal charge and that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of chemicals the freight rates are some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times very much less than normal-one -

Speaker: NA
Text: third of the ruling rates on charter vessels.

Speaker: NA
Text: This brings to the notice of the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: the contrast between normal freight rates

Speaker: NA
Text: and freight rates that are not normal.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question arises: Are the normal freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rates too high or are these dumping freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rates too low? I am not prepared to accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that the ruling freight rates to and from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia are the ones by which we should

Speaker: NA
Text: be guided in this respect. I think Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: is exploited and has been exploited for

Speaker: NA
Text: years in respect of our freight rates both

Speaker: NA
Text: to and from this country by a shipping ring

Speaker: NA
Text: - a monopoly-tha t has been taking us

Speaker: NA
Text: for suckers for far too long. It might well

Speaker: NA
Text: be that when one compares the freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rate on some charter vessel with the other

Speaker: NA
Text: ruling freight charges one might think

Speaker: NA
Text: the rate for the charter vessel is specially

Speaker: NA
Text: low. I think the evidence tends to suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the ruling freight rates are specially

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government and its advisers ought

Speaker: NA
Text: old to be looking much more closely at this

Speaker: NA
Text: Act matter. The Minister has given a vivid

Speaker: NA
Text: predescription of what happens but he has

Speaker: NA
Text: given us no real reason for believing that

Speaker: NA
Text: he has decided that it is the low rate that

Speaker: NA
Text: is specially wrong. The natural assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: is that the cheapest thing, not the most

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive thing, is the most favorable

Speaker: NA
Text: thing. In this case the Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking the view that the high ruling freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rate is the best freight rate from which the

Speaker: NA
Text: measurement should be made. Perhaps it

Speaker: NA
Text: is the other way round. The Minister spoke

Speaker: NA
Text: about the invidious practice of dumping.

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that dumping sometimes can be

Speaker: NA
Text: invidious. But we know that high priced

Speaker: NA
Text: goods can be indivious, too. The practice

Speaker: NA
Text: of exploiting the market by high prices is,

Speaker: NA
Text: on the whole, much more invidious than

Speaker: NA
Text: the practice of putting goods on a market

Speaker: NA
Text: at a price which is too low.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister referred to the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: of Economic Inquiry, the Vernon Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee. One would be almost inclined to

Speaker: NA
Text: think after the events of the last few days

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Vernon report is being rehabili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tated, and that perhaps it was true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Sir Robert Menzies) was a

Speaker: NA
Text: little hasty in his original judgment. We

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied to give approval to the measure,

Speaker: NA
Text: but I do make a plea to the Minister and

Speaker: NA
Text: his advisers to be a little more informative

Speaker: NA
Text: when putting a case to the Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: Platitudes can be very vivid sometimes, but

Speaker: NA
Text: very little real information has been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to us. I do not think the Minister has told

Speaker: NA
Text: us very much that really justifies this

Speaker: NA
Text: measure but we are prepared to accept it

Speaker: NA
Text: at face value.

Speaker: Mr KELLY
Text: Wakefield) [8.51] - I am

Speaker: NA
Text: just going to ask the Minister to clear my

Speaker: NA
Text: mind on freight dumping. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: from what people have told me and from

Speaker: NA
Text: what I heard during the debate on the Trade

Speaker: NA
Text: Practices Bill-an d I think it is true-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a fairly well controlled conference

Speaker: NA
Text: which fixes freight charges. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: also that some people are undercutting

Speaker: NA
Text: these freight charges. I would like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister to tell me quite clearly i f this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the kind of thing the legislation is designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to prevent.

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: Newcastle) [8.52] -Befor

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister replies to the honorable memtralia

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Wakefield ( Mr Kelly) I would like

Speaker: NA
Text: to make a very brief comment. I direct

Speaker: NA
Text: attention to the Government's decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: accept some of the recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vernon Committee of Economic Inquiry. the

Speaker: NA
Text: The Prime Minister ( Sir Robert Menzies)

Speaker: NA
Text: came into this Parliament some weeks ago

Speaker: NA
Text: and dealt very severely with the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: that Committee. He proceeded to toss it into

Speaker: NA
Text: the waste paper basket. I have not read the

Speaker: NA
Text: report but I have had a fairly close look

Speaker: NA
Text: at it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelly -Readin g it is very different

Speaker: NA
Text: from looking at it.

Speaker: Mr JONES
Text: Wha t I am trying to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vey is that I have not read it word by word.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it took the Cabinet about five months

Speaker: NA
Text: to read it, or allegedly to read it, so I

Speaker: NA
Text: have still a few months left in which to

Speaker: NA
Text: complete my study of it. At least it is pleas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to see that some of the Committee's

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations are being adopted. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that during many years to come various

Speaker: NA
Text: other theories or recommendations of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee will be heeded by this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament.

Speaker: NA
Text: What I mainly wish to speak about is

Speaker: NA
Text: something that we on this side of the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: are liament have been referring to for a con-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderable time, the exploitation of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country's exports and imports by the over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas Conference Line. We know, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts have been brought before the Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on numerous occasions, that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: cheaper to transport steel from the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom and Europe to Japan than from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to Japan. We remember that in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1961-62, when we were in the grip of a

Speaker: NA
Text: credit squeeze, and when I understand a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar situation existed in Japan, the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Darebin ( Mr Courtnay)

Speaker: NA
Text: and 1 told the Parliament that Japan was

Speaker: NA
Text: transporting steel from its own mills to

Speaker: NA
Text: New Zealand- a distance four and half

Speaker: NA
Text: times greater than the distance from Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lia to New Zealand-an d that the freight

Speaker: NA
Text: charges were half those charged by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference Line for transporting steel from

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to New Zealand.

Speaker: NA
Text: What the Minister has said tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: merely confirms what we have been saying

Speaker: NA
Text: for a considerable time. I hope the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will take the next obvious step and

Speaker: NA
Text: e expand the shipbuilding industry in Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: so that we can establish an overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: shipping line. I hope the Government will

Speaker: NA
Text: direct the Australian Coastal Shipping Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to extend its activities into overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: trading. We may then be able to move into

Speaker: NA
Text: field of international shipping on a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: petitive basis and give protection not only

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia's exporters but also to our im-

Speaker: NA
Text: porters. I was pleased to bear the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: bring to our attention the exploitation of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian imports and the consequent effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on Australian industry. Similar protection is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for Australia's exports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me remind the Committee of what

Speaker: NA
Text: happened recently in connection with our

Speaker: NA
Text: meat exports to the United Kingdom. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Conference Line was going to increase the

Speaker: NA
Text: freight rate by 10 per cent, from lst Novem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber and by 17 per cent, from lst January,

Speaker: NA
Text: but because of assistance given to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by an Israeli shipping line the Conference

Speaker: NA
Text: Line abandoned its plans to impose the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase. What the Minister has said tonight

Speaker: NA
Text: bears out our contention that we must have

Speaker: NA
Text: at an early date our own overseas shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: line.

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: Paterson-Ministe r for

Speaker: NA
Text: Supply) [8.56] -Th e honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcasde ( Mr Jones) will be very dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to hear me say that I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact been bringing to light any exploita-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Australia by shipping lines. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendments before us have nothing to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with exploitation. Both the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Newcastle and the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Yarra (Dr JF CAIRNS) have been

Speaker: NA
Text: putting up their own Aunt Sallys and having

Speaker: NA
Text: fun knocking them down. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Yarra raised the question

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the normal freight rates are too

Speaker: NA
Text: high or the dumping rates too low, but the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill does not concern itself with whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the freight rates are too high or too low.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member will no doubt pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: sue this subject at length and at another

Speaker: NA
Text: time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The machinery of tariff making calls

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the Tariff Board to examine all the

Speaker: NA
Text: factors that affects prices of exported com-

Speaker: NA
Text: modities. One factor clearly is freight, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in reaching any viable decision as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: level of protection for Australian industry

Speaker: NA
Text: the Board must consider some normal

Speaker: NA
Text: freight rate. Through a variety of devices

Speaker: NA
Text: running all the way from backloading to

Speaker: NA
Text: special deals with a manufacturer who may

Speaker: NA
Text: also have interests in shipping lines operating

Speaker: NA
Text: to and from Australia, an importer has an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to enjoy an abnormally low

Speaker: NA
Text: freight rate which may have nothing to do

Speaker: NA
Text: with the real cost of freighting the goods

Speaker: NA
Text: to Australia. Clearly, if this were allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: to continue it would upset entirely the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: machinery of tariff making. It is for this

Speaker: NA
Text: reason, and this reason alone, that this

Speaker: NA
Text: power is to be given to the Minister, so

Speaker: NA
Text: that freight rates may be levelled out and

Speaker: NA
Text: the work of the Tariff Board may not be

Speaker: NA
Text: destroyed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Wakefield will

Speaker: NA
Text: be delighted to know that we are not in

Speaker: NA
Text: fact trying to stop a reduction of freight

Speaker: NA
Text: rates. Indeed we would be delighted to see

Speaker: NA
Text: such a reduction take place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelly -Well , tell us what it is that

Speaker: NA
Text: you are doing.

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: I f the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member cannot understand what 1 said a

Speaker: NA
Text: moment ago perhaps we had better talk

Speaker: NA
Text: about it after school. I have described the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. The Tariff Board clearly must have

Speaker: NA
Text: some stable figures as to costs on which to

Speaker: NA
Text: base its assessment of the needs of an Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian industry and to decide on a suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: level of tariff protection.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Yarra) [8.59] -Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister and the rest of us have got on

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty well up to date, but I think he is

Speaker: NA
Text: straining our patience a little too much

Speaker: NA
Text: and imagining that we are a little too naive

Speaker: NA
Text: in the present situation. He has described,

Speaker: NA
Text: again very vividly, the possibility of a

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturer who may have an interest in

Speaker: NA
Text: a shipping line enjoying a freight rate for

Speaker: NA
Text: transporting his goods to Australia which

Speaker: NA
Text: is so low that it enables him to sell those

Speaker: NA
Text: goods in Australia at such a price that he

Speaker: NA
Text: is, in effect, dumping the goods. The Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter ignores altogether the possibility that

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly the reverse might happen; there

Speaker: NA
Text: might be collusion between manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: and a shipping company to bring goods to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia at an excessive freight rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: According to the Minister there is a possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility of this wicked collusion only when

Speaker: NA
Text: it results in what amounts to dumping. He

Speaker: NA
Text: ignores it completely in relation to the other

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of freight rate-th e excessive one that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are talking about. I believe that I appre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciate what is involved. If the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Customs and Excise is to be satisfied

Speaker: NA
Text: about whether goods are dumped it has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to compare freight rates. It has to

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to look at them realistically and

Speaker: NA
Text: be satisfied that they are normal. But when

Speaker: NA
Text: it is doing this it has to take into account

Speaker: NA
Text: two kinds of freight rates-th e alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: dumping one, which is the low one, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: normal one, which is considerably higher. I

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the possibility of collusion

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the parties is just as great in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the normal high rate as it is in respect

Speaker: NA
Text: of the abnormal low rate. I would not object

Speaker: NA
Text: so much to collusion if now and again it

Speaker: NA
Text: produced rates lower than those that it does

Speaker: NA
Text: produce.

Speaker: NA
Text: accept your ruling. It is this kind of

Text: school when he talks to the honorable mem-

Text: Angas) [9.3] - Mr Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, I rise to mention only two points.

Text: The first is the point that was dealt with

Speaker: NA
Text: originally by the honorable member for

Text: Yarra (Dr JF CAIRNS) and in respect of

Text: which he said, if I recall his words, that

Speaker: NA

Text: legislation. I put forward quite seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle ( Mr Jones) an experience that

Speaker: NA
Text: I had as a member of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: Members Food and Agriculture Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: carriage of bauxite from Weipa down the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian coastline to Bell Bay. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort of problem that we face with this

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Kelly -I t will not stop that.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Exactly . I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: answer is that competitive rates,

Speaker: NA
Text: he whether for backloading or not, should

Speaker: NA

Text: problem is to know how much it can afford

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: imports. This is indeed a problem. I am

Text: ruling charge of the measure in this chamber,

Speaker: NA
Text: as is not able to explain to me more clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: and freight and what is not.

Speaker: NA
Text: REFERENDUM (CONSTITUTION

Speaker: NA
Text: ALTERATION) BILL (No. 2) 1965.

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill-b y leave-presente d by Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anthony, and read a first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Richmond-Ministe r

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Interior) [9.8] - Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: move-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of this Bill is to clarify and

Speaker: NA
Text: simplify the manner of voting at future

Speaker: NA
Text: referendums. Under the existing law, a

Speaker: NA
Text: voter at a referendum is required to

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate his vote by writing thefigures" 1 "

Speaker: NA
Text: and " 2 " in the squares printed on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ballot paper. If he approves the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: law, he writes the figure " 1 " in the square

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite the word " Yes" and the figure

Speaker: NA
Text: *' 2 " in the square opposite the wcrd

Speaker: NA
Text: " No ". Conversely, if he does not approve

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed law, he writes the figure " 1 "

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite " N o " and the figure " 2 "

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite " Yes". The use of a cross only,

Speaker: NA
Text: or the figure " 1 " only, in one of the moved forthwith.

Speaker: NA
Text: squares does not render a ballot paper

Speaker: NA
Text: informal provided that the other square third time.

Speaker: NA
Text: is left blank. In that case, the cross is

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed to be equivalent to the figure " 1 ".

Speaker: NA
Text: At a referendum, the voter has to answer

Speaker: NA
Text: a specific question which is set out on the

Speaker: NA
Text: ballot paper in the form-

Speaker: NA
Text: Do you approve of the proposed law for the

Speaker: NA
Text: alteration of the Constitution entitled . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: Then follows the title of the proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, the straight out answer to this

Speaker: NA
Text: direct question is "Yes" or "No"-no t

Speaker: NA
Text: " 1 " and " 2 ". Under the provisions of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill the voter will be required to write

Speaker: NA
Text: simply either "Yes" or " N o " in answer [9.13] - I move-

Speaker: NA
Text: to the question. This is a more positive

Speaker: NA
Text: and, I believe, a more correct form of

Speaker: NA
Text: voting at a referendum. As the arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: in favour and against the proposed law

Speaker: NA
Text: must be forwarded to the Chief Electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: Officer by 30th December, it will be

Speaker: NA
Text: appreciated that any change in the method

Speaker: NA
Text: of voting at a referendum would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be passed this session to be effective at the

Speaker: NA
Text: forthcoming referendum. This is so

Speaker: NA
Text: because the arguments may well contain

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions to the electors as to the manner

Speaker: NA
Text: of voting.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consideration has been given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of possible confusion to voters if

Speaker: NA
Text: this Bill is passed, should some future

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate or House of Representatives election

Speaker: NA
Text: he held at the same time as a referendum.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, the Government believes that

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed form of voting simplifies

Speaker: NA
Text: and clarifies the method of voting and,

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, minimises the risk of confusion to

Speaker: NA
Text: voters. The present provisions which

Speaker: NA
Text: provide that a ballot paper marked only

Speaker: NA
Text: with a cross or marked only with the figure

Speaker: NA
Text: " 1 " constitutes a formal vote will no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer be appropriate. Clause 3 of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: repeals those provisions. I commend the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill to honorable members.

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted for the debate to continue.

Text: Werriwa) [9.11] -Th e

Text: amendment.

Text: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Text: The purpose of these Bills is to provide a

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: SULPHURIC ACID BOUNTY BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 25th November

Speaker: NA
Text: (vide page 3192), on motion by Mr Bury-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr FAIRHALL
Text: Mr Speaker, may I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the indulgence'of the House to raise a point

Speaker: NA
Text: of procedure on this legislation? I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that it may suit the convenience of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House if you would allow the subject matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Pyrites Bounty Bill (No. 2) to be

Speaker: NA
Text: debated coincidentally with the second read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of the Sulphuric Acid Bounty Bill (No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2). The two Bills will, of course, be called

Speaker: NA
Text: on and dealt with separately. I suggest, Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, that you might permit this to be

Speaker: NA
Text: done.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I s it the wish of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House to follow the procedure suggested by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister? There being no objection, that

Speaker: NA
Text: course will be followed.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Yarra) [9.15] -Tbi s

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill, and the associated measure, fhe Pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: Bounty Bill (No. 2), are very important.

Speaker: NA
Text: They will involve between them the prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: able expenditure in the coming year of

Speaker: NA
Text: about Â£\i million of national revenue. They

Speaker: NA
Text: continue an expenditure which has amoun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ted since the measures were first introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1954-55, in the case of the Sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: Acid Bounty Act, and in 1960-61, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: case of the Pyrites Bounty Act, to nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£12 million. This is a considerable amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of money and I think the House would want

Speaker: NA
Text: to know something of what it is doing and

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the consequences.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the provision of this sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidy is to encourage in Australia in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of sulphuric acid the use of Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian produced raw materials. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: raw materials in this case are pyrites pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced from various mining operations in

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia, Tasmania, Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia and Queensland. The two main raw

Speaker: NA
Text: materials from which sulphuric acid is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced are sulphur, or brimstone, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: imported from overseas, and pyrites, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is produced in Australia. In 1963, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: the last year for which I have comparative

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, some 64 or 65 per cent, of all sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid produced in Australia was pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced from these two raw materials, brim-

Speaker: NA
Text: stone and concentrated pyrites. Production

Speaker: NA
Text: of sulphuric acid is important. Sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid production in 1963 amounted to more

Speaker: NA
Text: than 1,300,000 tons of which 430,000 tons

Speaker: NA
Text: had sulphuric content. Sulphuric acid is a

Speaker: NA
Text: most important industrial raw material.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Bills provide for the payment of a

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy on the production of pyrites and

Speaker: NA
Text: on the production of sulphuric acid. The

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of the Bills, as has been the pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: pose of all the other Bills that have been

Speaker: NA
Text: passed over the last 10 years, is to encourage

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian sulphuric acid producers to use

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian produced pyrites as a raw

Speaker: NA
Text: material, it being correctly assumed

Speaker: NA
Text: that if this was not done the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers would turn more readily to imported

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone which is a more economic raw

Speaker: NA
Text: material. So to encourage them to use the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian product a subsidy is paid on the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of the pyrites which reduces, or

Speaker: NA
Text: is expected to reduce, its cost to the proces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sor. A subsidy is paid also on sulphuric acid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Although I must say that I am not com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely sure about this, apparently the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidy applies only to sulphuric acid that is

Speaker: NA
Text: produced from Australian pyrites. I should

Speaker: NA
Text: like the Minister for Supply ( Mr Fairhall),

Speaker: NA
Text: who is in charge of the Bill, to tell me some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about that so that we can be more

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfied with it. As I say, I am not sure

Speaker: NA
Text: whether this is so.

Speaker: NA
Text: The subsidy is paid to thefiveAustralian

Speaker: NA
Text: producers of pyrites at the source, and I

Speaker: NA
Text: shall refer tofiguresin this connection for

Speaker: NA
Text: the years 1964 and 1965. The total amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of the subsidy paid in the 12 months ended

Speaker: NA
Text: 30th June 1964 was Â£644,000; to 30th

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1965 it was Â£583,000; and for the first

Speaker: NA
Text: nine months of the incomplete year it was

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£456,000. The producers to whom this

Speaker: NA
Text: money is paid are Goldmines of Kalgoorlie

Speaker: NA
Text: (Aust.) Ltd., which, in 1964, received

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£48,539; Mount Lyell Mining and Railway

Speaker: NA
Text: Co. Ltd., which, in 1964, received Â£177,463;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Morgan Ltd., which, in 1964, re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceived Â£109,707; Nairne Pyrites Ltd.,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in 1964, received Â£207,973; and

Speaker: NA
Text: Norseman Gold Mines No Liability,

Speaker: NA
Text: which, in the same year, received Â£100,593.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total paid out in 1964 was Â£644,275.

Speaker: NA
Text: That gives the House some indication of

Speaker: NA
Text: where the money paid by way of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites bounty goes.

Speaker: NA
Text: As to sulphuric acid, there were seven

Speaker: NA
Text: producers who received bounties in 1964.

Speaker: NA
Text: They were A.C.F. and Shirleys Fertilisers

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd., which received Â£50,525; Broken Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: Associated Smelters Pty. Ltd., which

Speaker: NA
Text: received Â£147,045; Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Fertilisers and Chemicals Ltd., which

Speaker: NA
Text: received Â£279,294; Cresco Fertilizers (W.A.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd., which received Â£78,804; C.S.B.P. and

Speaker: NA
Text: Farmers Ltd., which received Â£154,989;

Speaker: NA
Text: Sulphide Corporation Pty. Ltd., which

Speaker: NA
Text: received Â£97,101; and Sulphuric Acid Ltd.,

Speaker: NA
Text: which received Â£304,743. The total paid out

Speaker: NA
Text: to the producers of sulphuric acid in that

Speaker: NA
Text: year was Â£1,106,501. These are substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: sums from the public's point of view. It

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to me that, considering the scope of

Speaker: NA
Text: their general operations, some of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers of sulphuric acid might have been

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to carry the production of sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid to the extent of the bounties that were

Speaker: NA
Text: paid to them. On many occasions when

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been considering in this House

Speaker: NA
Text: industries like the chemical industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: thc aspect to which we have been giving

Speaker: NA
Text: special attention is an ancillary one, or one

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to a by-product, we have found that

Speaker: NA
Text: the company under consideration is making

Speaker: NA
Text: extremely large profits, running into many

Speaker: NA
Text: millions of pounds. I think that in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases the companies could afford to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the lines of production being con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's attitude to the pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of these bounties has not been un-

Speaker: NA
Text: changed. We find from the report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board dated 30th June 1965, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: which this legislation is mainly based, that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Board went to work having regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: certain indications that the Government had

Speaker: NA
Text: given to it. The Board says-

Speaker: NA
Text: Having regard to the Government's conclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: that in existing circumstances, it is inappropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: to pursue the former policy of encouraging the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of sulphur-bearing materials of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: origin for the production of sulphuric acid. . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: I know that some of the producers of pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: are concerned about the present situation,

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think it is well for them to note that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government laid down as a guide to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board on this matter the consideration

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have just read, namely-

Speaker: NA
Text: that in existing circumstances it is inappropriate to

Speaker: NA
Text: pursue the former policy of encouraging the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of sulphur bearing materials of Australian origin

Speaker: NA
Text: for the production of sulphuric acid.

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not know whether that is a notice to

Speaker: NA
Text: the producers of Australian sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: materials that they have to regard this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation as a short term measure. The bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: that is proposed under this legislation is

Speaker: NA
Text: payable until 1965. But is this the writing

Speaker: NA
Text: on the wall? I think the one fault in the

Speaker: NA
Text: way this matter has been handled over

Speaker: NA
Text: recent years is that there has been some

Speaker: NA
Text: uncertainty by the Government about what

Speaker: NA
Text: it intends to do in the future. This uncer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainty must have had its effect on industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: organisation and on the attitude of the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies concerned. The Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: went on to say that it had regard to another

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. It was-

Speaker: NA
Text: The desire of the Government to ensure neverthe-

Speaker: NA
Text: less that the change of policy referred to in

Speaker: NA
Text: We should emphasise that it is a change of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy-

Speaker: NA
Text: above does not operate to avoid the obligations

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Government recognises it has to those

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises which have co-operated, or made plans

Speaker: NA
Text: on or before lst December 1960, to co-operate, in

Speaker: NA
Text: giving effect to the past policy of reducing Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's dependence on imported sulphur-bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: materials for the production of sulphuric acid.

Speaker: NA
Text: Putting those two things together, there can

Speaker: NA
Text: be no doubt that there is a change of policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government does not intend to pursue

Speaker: NA
Text: the former policy of encouraging the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian sulphur bearing materials. Is this

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance being given only for the purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of allowing the producers to make new

Speaker: NA
Text: plans? Is it to allow them to prepare to

Speaker: NA
Text: transfer from production of this kind that

Speaker: NA
Text: these payments are to be made? Perhaps

Speaker: NA
Text: they are being made to enable the producers

Speaker: NA
Text: more readily to amortise their plants. We

Speaker: NA
Text: know that a considerable amount of this has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done already. Is this what the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's attitude means? And is this what the

Speaker: NA
Text: producers understand it to mean?

Speaker: NA
Text: I think an examination of the circumof

Speaker: NA
Text: stances shows that there is no certainty

Speaker: NA
Text: all that the operation of these bounties from

Speaker: NA
Text: the beginning some 10 or 11 years ago has

Speaker: NA
Text: been effective. Certainly it has by no means

Speaker: NA
Text: been an outstanding success. It is important

Speaker: NA
Text: for us to try to visualise the degree of sucthere

Speaker: NA
Text: cess that this policy of paying bounties

Speaker: NA
Text: might have achieved, because it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: costly one. I pointed out at the beginning

Speaker: NA
Text: of my remarks that almost Â£12 million

Speaker: NA
Text: been paid out in subsidies. We cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that this has been a successful exer-

Speaker: NA
Text: cise at all. This year we are involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of Â£ l i million, and these there

Speaker: NA
Text: bounties are to continue until 1969. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is a lot of money to spend on a proposition

Speaker: NA
Text: about which we may not be at all certain.

Speaker: NA
Text: The reason for my uncertainty is

Speaker: NA
Text: found in the figures given on page 6 of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board report to which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred. In some ways, there is competition

Speaker: NA
Text: between pyrites and other types of sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing material. The table at page 6 of

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board's report discloses that from

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957 to 1963 there has been a quite signicrease

Speaker: NA
Text: ficant and constant fall in the proportion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the sulphur content of sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: is attributable to pyrites. In 1957, 31.5

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, of the sulphur content of sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid came from pyrites. In 1963, the

Speaker: NA
Text: portion was 25.3 per cent., which represents

Speaker: NA
Text: a fall of 6.2 per cent. That fall has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a continuing one right up to the present

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and it will probably continue from

Speaker: NA
Text: now on at an increasing rate. On the other

Speaker: NA
Text: hand, the proportion that has come from

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone or imported sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: material has remained fairly constant.

Speaker: NA
Text: was 49.2 per cent., or almost one-half,

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957 and in 1963 it was 49.3 per cent. The

Speaker: NA
Text: load carried by imported brimstone, the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of thing that we were trying to reduce,

Speaker: NA
Text: has remained constant, while the load carpetroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: ried by Australian produced pyrites, the the field.

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of thing we were trying to increase,

Speaker: NA
Text: has fallen by 6.2 per cent, over the period

Speaker: NA
Text: in question. Whilst brimstone has not

Speaker: NA
Text: creased its share-i t has still about half-

Speaker: NA
Text: what then has increased? The answer is

Speaker: NA
Text: zinc concentrates. The production of sulpyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid from zinc concentrates Has

Speaker: NA
Text: from 11 per cent, in 1957-th e year I years

Speaker: NA
Text: choose because it is fairly representative for

Speaker: NA
Text: other comparisons-t o 16.8 per cent, in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1963, an increase of 5.8 per cent. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been a slight change in relation to some

Speaker: NA
Text: the other basic materials, but it is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: at clear that brimstone has retained a fairly

Speaker: NA
Text: constant proportion, pyrites has fallen by

Speaker: NA
Text: about 6 per cent, and zinc concentrates has

Speaker: NA
Text: risen by about 6 per cent. Of course, zinc

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrates are Australian produced and

Speaker: NA
Text: is no subsidy on them. It might there-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore be better for the Australian economy

Speaker: NA
Text: as a whole to see this trend continue and

Speaker: NA
Text: a raw material which does not need a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: has sidy compete with imported brimstone.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no certainty that this system of

Speaker: NA
Text: using a bounty has been a success, because

Speaker: NA
Text: is no certainty that it has produced the

Speaker: NA
Text: kind of result that it was assumed was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary. Why is this so? The answer is, I

Speaker: NA
Text: think, first that the cost of brimstone has

Speaker: NA
Text: been particularly low compared to its nor-

Speaker: NA
Text: to be mal cost on the world market and,

Speaker: NA
Text: the secondly, in comparison with pyrites. A l

Speaker: NA
Text: re30th September 1964 imported brimstone

Speaker: NA
Text: cost Â£12 18s. 7d. a ton, at 31st March

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965, Â£13 14s. 4d. and at 30th September

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1965, Â£16 a ton. The advantage that brim-

Speaker: NA
Text: stone has had, which has led to a vast in-

Speaker: NA
Text: in the quantity imported by Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: is perhaps diminishing. In 1960 imports

Speaker: NA
Text: that were 221,778 tons and in 1964, 376,639

Speaker: NA
Text: per tons. There has been quite a dramatic in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease in the quantity of brimstone im-

Speaker: NA
Text: proported into Australia and this has been

Speaker: NA
Text: pardy the function of the relatively low

Speaker: NA
Text: price. However, if the price is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: behave as the 30th September 1965 price

Speaker: NA
Text: indicates-whe n it was Â£16 a ton-th e com-

Speaker: NA
Text: parative advantage that brimstone has will

Speaker: NA
Text: be diminished. There would need to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: reduction in the advantage for the apparent

Speaker: NA
Text: It purpose of the payment of this subsidy to

Speaker: NA
Text: in be significantly achieved. It seems to me

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a possibility of another competitor

Speaker: NA
Text: coming into the field very soon. Industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australia seems to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: byproducts might also come into

Speaker: NA
Text: Unless the brimstone prices rise the

Speaker: NA
Text: inbounty will not offset the trend that is

Speaker: NA
Text: apparent in thefiguresI have quoted from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tariff Board's report. The share of

Speaker: NA
Text: in the total raw material used in

Speaker: NA
Text: risen Australia has been downwards for seven

Speaker: NA
Text: and that trend is certain to continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: Is that what the Government wants? I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think that there can be any doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: the answer is yes. If it were not yes I do

Speaker: NA
Text: not think the Government would have

Speaker: NA
Text: given the Tariff Board to understand what

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tariff Board says it does understand,

Speaker: NA
Text: namely, that there has been a change of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy of encouraging the use of sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing materials of Australian origin for

Speaker: NA
Text: the production of sulphuric acid. I am sure

Speaker: NA
Text: the evidence shows that It is the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's intention that the trend in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites should continue. I think this needs

Speaker: NA
Text: emphasising to all those people in the vari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous parts of Australia-Wester n Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: -wh o are interested in the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites. Perhaps in some ways it is unfor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunate that after 10 or 11 years of a policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of paying almost Â£12 million in subsidies

Speaker: NA
Text: this is the stage we have reached in 1965.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is not a very convincing illustration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the intelligent use of a subsidy for the main-

Speaker: NA
Text: tenance and development of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: production.

Speaker: NA
Text: The five pyrites producers that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in stating the amounts paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: them in subsidies in 1964 employ, the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's report tells us, 3,800 persons, of

Speaker: NA
Text: whom at least 350 are directly engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: mining pyrites. Is there some sleight of hand

Speaker: NA
Text: in this section of the Tariff Board's report?

Speaker: NA
Text: How many are actually engaged in the

Speaker: NA
Text: mining of pyrites? Is it only 350 and, if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: why has there been mention of the 3,800

Speaker: NA
Text: persons employed by these five companies?

Speaker: NA
Text: We know that these companies do not pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce only pyrites. They produce other

Speaker: NA
Text: materials from their mines, but the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board has tended to suggest that 3,800 per-

Speaker: NA
Text: sons are involved in pyrites mining when

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps there are only 350. There is some

Speaker: NA
Text: vagueness here that I think may be

Speaker: NA
Text: deliberate. How many are actually con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned? Then the implication is taken a little

Text: further. The report says that 35,000 people
