Text: living in the towns concerned are directly

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent upon the mines. Are they directly

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent upon pyrites? Obviously not.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no suggestion that the mines at

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie, Mount Morgan and Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Lyell are dependent on pyrites. If they had

Speaker: NA
Text: to stop producing pyrites-an d it seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: be the Government's intention that sooner

Speaker: NA
Text: or later they should stop such production-

Text: might be a little less profitable, they might

Text: them all they might put off 350 men, but

Speaker: NA
Text: certainly not 3,800. Between them all, some

Speaker: NA
Text: few of the 35,000 people who live in the

Speaker: NA
Text: towns might be adversely affected. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tariff Board's report seems to indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: tbat if this bounty were not paid it might

Speaker: NA
Text: well be that 3,800 men would suddenly lose

Text: dependent upon the mines might have to

Speaker: NA
Text: move elsewhere. I do not think this is fair

Speaker: NA
Text: reckoning. I do not think the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: has been quite straightforward on this. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think at best there has been some vagueness

Speaker: NA
Text: that should not exist.

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like now to discuss sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: and its production. The payment of a bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: on sulphuric acid has been going on for

Speaker: NA
Text: much longer than that on pyrites. Although

Speaker: NA
Text: I have laid some stress on pyrites, it is far

Speaker: NA
Text: less important than sulphuric acid. Up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 1964 an amount of Â£1,794,000 has been

Speaker: NA
Text: paid on pyrites but Â£10,084,000 on sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid, so sulphuric acid is the much more

Speaker: NA
Text: costly substance that we are subsidising. The

Speaker: NA
Text: seven companies that produce sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: are much bigger and far more significant

Speaker: NA
Text: than the companies producing pyrites and

Speaker: NA
Text: most are thoroughly interlocked. My friend

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member for Lalor ( Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pollard) has their interlocking at his finger-

Speaker: NA
Text: tips and during the course of his speech a

Speaker: NA
Text: little later tonight he will demonstrate this.

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems to me that a handout of about Â£1

Speaker: NA
Text: million a year to these large interlocked

Speaker: NA
Text: enterprises is a considerable amount to ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the public of Australia to pay in these

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: Also, I raise the question which I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned to the Minister: Is the bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: on sulphuric acid paid only on sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid that is made from pyrites or is it paid

Speaker: NA
Text: on sulphuric acid made from other

Speaker: NA
Text: materials? If it is, it is a particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: unjustifiable procedure. If it is possible for

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers to get a bounty on sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid produced from imported brimstone it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be utter stupidity. If it is possible

Speaker: NA
Text: for them to get a bounty on sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: produced from zinc concentrates it would

Speaker: NA
Text: probably be unjustified.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: that case.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr J. F. CABINS -I f the bounty is

Speaker: NA
Text: lower there may be something to justify it

Speaker: NA
Text: but certainly the comparative costs of zinc

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrates, pyrites and even brimstone

Speaker: NA
Text: would not justify the payment of a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantial bounty. Perhaps information on

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter is available somewhere. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: not read every word of the Tariff Board's

Speaker: NA
Text: report for a week or 10 days, but as far

Speaker: NA
Text: as I know there is no clarity on this matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would like the Minister to clarify the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The question 1 posed was: If the bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: was not paid what difference would it make

Speaker: NA
Text: to the seven companies which, in some

Speaker: NA
Text: cases, are very closely interlocked whose

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid production is only a relatively

Speaker: NA
Text: small part of their total operations? As the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty is substantially paid in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of pyrites and as most producers

Speaker: NA
Text: are already preparing to shift out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of sulphuric acid from pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: to other things, the non-payment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty is not likely significantly to interfere

Speaker: NA
Text: with their operations. One has the feeling

Speaker: NA
Text: that this bounty is a kind of hand out at

Speaker: NA
Text: the end of the road to allow these com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies, perhaps, to write off some of the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital they have invested, which they can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not otherwise do. The Government is, in a

Speaker: NA
Text: sense, giving them notice that there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: change of policy; that it will continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage the production of sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: from Australian sulphur bearing materials;

Speaker: NA
Text: that it will pay the bounty until 1969 and

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore the companies may clean up what

Speaker: NA
Text: is left over. Is that the position? It seems

Speaker: NA
Text: pretty clear that it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition is not opposing the

Speaker: NA
Text: measure but we consider that there should

Speaker: NA
Text: be a much closer and more detailed in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry. It may be that the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy is wrong. It may be that the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: position that I quoted from page 3 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's report, which is the basic proposi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion in the whole business- a change of

Speaker: NA
Text: policy from the encouragement of the use

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian produced sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: materials-i s wrong. It may be essential

Speaker: NA
Text: for purposes of national development to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue the policy which the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: is now changing. It may be desirable to

Speaker: NA
Text: exclude the importation altogether of brim-

Speaker: NA
Text: stone. This is a distinct possibility. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that anything the Tariff Board has

Speaker: NA
Text: done so far would justify us in believing

Speaker: NA
Text: that this may be the case. I direct the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the Minister particularly to a

Speaker: NA
Text: statement in the Tariff Board's report. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is an astonishing statement to find at this

Speaker: NA
Text: stage in the business. I do not think the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board is to blame for this. I think that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board has been put in its present position

Speaker: NA
Text: as a result of the situation that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has defined in respect to it. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Board states-

Speaker: NA
Text: No other or additional forms of discharging

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's obligations have been considered

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Board in what has been essentially a

Speaker: NA
Text: cursory examination of alternatives, undertaken

Speaker: NA
Text: merely to assist the Government should it wish

Speaker: NA
Text: to reconsider the question.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite astonishing to me that the Board

Speaker: NA
Text: at this late stage should say that. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's first inquiry was made in 1954. It

Speaker: NA
Text: held another inquiry in 1958, another in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1960 and, I believe, another in 1962. It

Speaker: NA
Text: began this cursory inquiry, as the Board

Speaker: NA
Text: calls it, on 8th June 1964 and made its

Speaker: NA
Text: report on 30th June 1965-jus t over one

Speaker: NA
Text: year later although it was a cursory inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: This leads one to wonder how long the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tariff Board would take if it wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a thorough and detailed inquiry. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkable that the Government should bs

Speaker: NA
Text: changing its policy on the basis of a cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: sory inquiry that has taken a little over a

Speaker: NA
Text: year to carry out and in respect of which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Board has reported-

Speaker: NA
Text: No other or additional forms of discharging the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's obligations . . . in what has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a cursory examination of alternatives . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: The crux of the matter is the alternatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: What other alternatives are available? It is

Speaker: NA
Text: a matter of technical priorities. What are

Speaker: NA
Text: the possibilities in the future? Yet the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board makes a cursory examination of

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives, on which the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: position is defined.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition will not oppose this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. The bounty will be paid until 1969.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nobody will be put out of business, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not accept the situation. We believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: a closer and more detailed inquiry is needed.

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that the crux of that inquiry

Speaker: NA
Text: should be a consideration of the technical

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives. What is the future of pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: production in Australia? Is the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: serving notice that, as far as this bounty is

Speaker: NA
Text: concerned, the Government will wind it up

Speaker: NA
Text: do not in about 1969? Does the Government know

Speaker: NA
Text: anything about the possibilities of this

Speaker: NA
Text: apparently new development. Between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1957 and 1963 the use of zinc concentrates

Speaker: NA
Text: as the basic raw material in the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of sulphuric acid increased by almost 6

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent, while the use of pyrites for the

Speaker: NA
Text: same purpose decreased by about 6 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. What is the future of the develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of zinc concentrates? Clearly these are

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives which the Tariff Board should

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken into account. What is the possi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility in the future of raw materials coming

Speaker: NA
Text: from the petroleum industry as by-products?

Speaker: NA
Text: This appears to be a developing field.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: - Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Wha t are the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibilities in the future of production from

Speaker: NA
Text: gases, as the honorable member for Lalor

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned? All of these things have been

Speaker: NA
Text: given a cursory examination on which the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is asked to approve an expenditure of

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£14 million this year and to continue an

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure at something like that rate each

Speaker: NA
Text: year until 1969. This is not good enough for

Speaker: NA
Text: any government or any party in opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: to accept. We will not oppose the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: because wc do not want to take action which

Speaker: NA
Text: might dislocate the already existing industry

Speaker: NA
Text: or upset it even worse than the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's uncertainty over the last five or six

Speaker: NA
Text: years has upset it. We do not wish to upset

Speaker: NA
Text: the industry as much as the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: indiiference and change of policy un-

Speaker: NA
Text: doubtedly will upset it. But at the same time

Speaker: NA
Text: as we refrain from standing in the way of

Speaker: NA
Text: the payment of this bounty, we believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: there should be a closer and more detailed

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiry before any final decisions about the

Speaker: NA
Text: future of policy are made. I put this to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in the hope that he will take it

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously, because this is the considered

Speaker: NA
Text: position of the Opposition.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition anticipated that this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: might have been debated last week. We

Speaker: NA
Text: took special steps to avoid that so that we

Speaker: NA
Text: could use the time in order to make a closer

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of the industry. This we have

Speaker: NA
Text: done and our considered position is that we

Speaker: NA
Text: do not intend to take any action which

Speaker: NA
Text: would add to the uncertainty or confusion

Speaker: NA
Text: that must exist in the minds of the indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try as a result of the Government's attitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, we believe that a much

Speaker: NA
Text: more detailed and close inquiry should be

Speaker: NA
Text: made, particularly in respect of the alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives for the future, before any final policy

Speaker: NA
Text: is decided by the Government. We are

Speaker: NA
Text: refraining from moving any amendment,

Speaker: NA
Text: which we considered at length doing,

Speaker: NA
Text: because we believe that the position warrants

Speaker: NA
Text: the full force of examination. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition has refrained from taking positive

Speaker: NA
Text: action which may affect the industry. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: same time, we require the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: take our position seriously and to give it

Speaker: NA
Text: the consideration that I am sure the industry

Speaker: NA
Text: and the people of Australia believe it

Speaker: NA
Text: deserves.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: Angas) [9.50] - I was

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the views of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Yarra (Dr JF CAIRNS). I am

Speaker: NA
Text: grateful that he has prompted my memory

Speaker: NA
Text: on a passage at page 10 of the Tariff Board's

Speaker: NA
Text: report. I think that many people probably

Speaker: NA
Text: agree with the thinking of the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Yarra on the future of the

Speaker: NA
Text: production of acid from pyrites. I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: say for a moment that I agree with him,

Speaker: NA
Text: but perhaps my opinion is coloured by the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that Brokunga, which is the source of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites used by Nairne Pyrites Pty. Ltd., is

Speaker: NA
Text: in the electorate of Angas. This is a pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: and well established town. The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member of Yarra said that a pas-

Speaker: NA
Text: sage in the Tariff Board's report was incor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect, because it did allow for the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued existence of these towns if pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: did not remain as the source material of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid. This would not be so with

Speaker: NA
Text: the pyrites used by the Nairne company,

Speaker: NA
Text: and it would not be so with Sulphuric Acid

Speaker: NA
Text: Pty. Ltd., which uses the acid. It would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be so with Norseman Gold Mines, either.

Speaker: NA
Text: These sources do not process a raw mate-

Speaker: NA
Text: rial and finish with pyrites as a by-product.

Speaker: NA
Text: They mine for pyrites and the existence of

Speaker: NA
Text: the town depends on whether pyrites is

Speaker: NA
Text: to be the source of sulphuric acid.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Yarra ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned whether the Board's inquiry or in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiries had been cursory. I think it is appo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site to look at the terms of reference, which

Speaker: NA
Text: are included in the last report of the Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: The terms of reference are laid down by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister. On page 3 of its report, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the Board states-

Speaker: NA
Text: In pursuance of the Minister's reference the

Speaker: NA
Text: Board has made the necessary inquiry and submits

Speaker: NA
Text: the following report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that possibly that is all the Board can

Speaker: NA
Text: be expected to do.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: I said that.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: I am sorry; I did not hear

Speaker: NA
Text: the honorable member say that. I thought

Speaker: NA
Text: he was trying to convey the impression

Speaker: NA
Text: that, in its inquiries, the Board should have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a look at the full problem involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: the production of acid from the various

Speaker: NA
Text: sources. We should appreciate that the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiries of the Tariff Board are limited to

Speaker: NA
Text: the terms of reference. The suggestion has

Speaker: NA
Text: been made before that a fully inquiry be

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted into many aspects of the indusiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Without boring the House by reading them,

Speaker: NA
Text: I point out that many of these aspects are

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the report of the Tariff Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, a full inquiry could be a worth-

Speaker: NA
Text: while exercise either by the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: or by some select committee.

Speaker: NA
Text: I pass on to the subsidy. The question has

Speaker: NA
Text: been raised whether the subsidy applies more

Speaker: NA
Text: generally than merely to acid that is ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: tained from pyrites. My understanding is

Speaker: NA
Text: that a sliding scale applies from the point

Speaker: NA
Text: of production of pyrites to the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid from pyrites. In South Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia, this is manufactured by Sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: Acid Pty. Ltd. A sliding scale subsidy also

Speaker: NA
Text: applies to sinter gas, which is produced by

Speaker: NA
Text: Broken Hill Associated Smelters Pty. Ltd. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the honorable member for Yarra men-

Speaker: NA
Text: tioned this out of context. Thirdly, then a

Speaker: NA
Text: flat rate bounty applies to the production

Speaker: NA
Text: of sulphuric acid. It is primarily to this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter that I want to direct my attention as

Speaker: NA
Text: I go along.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before I do so, I would like to take up

Speaker: NA
Text: one or two points at this stage of the debate.

Speaker: NA
Text: The first is the rather interesting trend of

Speaker: NA
Text: the increasing percentage of production of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid from zinc concentrates. This

Speaker: NA
Text: also was mentioned by the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Yarra. The percentages are 10.4 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, in 1955, and then 10.6 per cent., 11

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent., 11.7 per cent., 12.2 per cent.,

Speaker: NA
Text: 11.8 per cent., 14.1 per cent., 16.2 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: to 16.8 per cent. My understanding- I may

Speaker: NA
Text: be wrong-i s that the capacity for the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of acid from this source is limited.

Speaker: NA
Text: This must be a very slow and long term

Speaker: NA
Text: process, if it is to be of any assistance in

Speaker: NA
Text: the production of sulphuric acid and sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sequently of superphosphate. I would suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: that the increase in the use of zinc con-

Speaker: NA
Text: centrates would barely keep up with the

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing use of superphosphate and sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid as an ingredient of it. As has

Speaker: NA
Text: been said, this is an interesting trend, but

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not think we can afford to minimise

Speaker: NA
Text: the importance of pyrites as a source of sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid, because of this trend.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member for Yarra, I think

Speaker: NA
Text: rightly, made the point-a t one stage I

Speaker: NA
Text: wondered whether he would get there-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of brimstone is entirely responsible

Speaker: NA
Text: for the percentage figures he quoted from

Speaker: NA
Text: the chart that is proffered in the Tarifl

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's report. It is not hard to imagine a

Speaker: NA
Text: situation in which the swing would start

Speaker: NA
Text: back the other way. In 1962, the sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: content of sulphuric acid attributable to

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone represented 50.4 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: total supplies used in Australia. The percen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tage was down to 49.3 in 1963. My infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation is that the price of brimstone can be

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to rise a little in the years to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a matter now of deciding who is expert

Speaker: NA
Text: in this field. Someone must be able to do a

Speaker: NA
Text: projection of sorts, based on supplies of this

Speaker: NA
Text: material and shipping rates, and rationalise

Speaker: NA
Text: this with the value to Australia of a home

Speaker: NA
Text: produced article.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: D o not mention the

Speaker: NA
Text: word " projection ".

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: I know it is a dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: word to use. Perhaps I could dig up some

Speaker: NA
Text: other form of projection. The point at issue

Speaker: NA
Text: is that this must be looked at. On the evi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence before me at this stage, I doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is rational or reasonable to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that in 1969 the overall production of acid

Speaker: NA
Text: from the source of pyrites should come to

Speaker: NA
Text: a halt. It may be as well at this stage for

Speaker: NA
Text: me to read from a letter I have received

Speaker: NA
Text: from Sulphuric Acid Pty. Ltd. in South

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. It states-

Speaker: NA
Text: We are very concerned to learn of the proposal

Speaker: NA
Text: to reduce the subsidy on sulphuric acid produced

Speaker: NA
Text: from pyrites from Â£3 to Â£2 10s. per ton, a figure

Speaker: NA
Text: which we suggest is not supported by the costs

Speaker: NA
Text: disclosed in this company's operations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have had access to the company's figures

Speaker: NA
Text: and I think that this is a reasonable state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The letter continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: The operation of price control in this State

Speaker: NA
Text: has unfortunately left us with little margin, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in a 10-year period we have accumulated only a

Speaker: NA
Text: comparatively small sum to augment our liquid

Speaker: NA
Text: funds.

Speaker: NA
Text: This again is a matter with which I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had a nodding acquaintance, having be-

Speaker: NA
Text: longed, may I say, to the left wing of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Playford Government in the Legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: Council of South Australia. For some years

Speaker: NA
Text: we debated price control and I voted in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of it each year. I hasten to add that

Speaker: NA
Text: I always took the view that in the area of

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture this was a far more dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: principle than it was in trade and com-

Speaker: NA
Text: merce, such as in the selling of shoes.

Speaker: NA
Text: is because the following argument imanother

Speaker: NA
Text: mediately comes to mind: The problem has

Speaker: NA
Text: always been, under this form of restrictive

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation, that firms attempting to do an

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient job may not be able to do so due It continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: to lack of sufficient profits. They may not

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to put down enough of their bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: depreciation allowance, or enough other to Japan-

Speaker: NA
Text: funds into reserve to keep their plant

Speaker: NA
Text: modern. I think that Sulphuric Acid Pty.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd. in South Australia in many ways has

Speaker: NA
Text: received the worst of two worlds. It has price.

Speaker: NA
Text: been restricted on the one hand by State

Speaker: NA
Text: laws and, on the other hand, having

Speaker: NA
Text: output of 97,000 tons out of an Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: total of 108,692 tons of acid produced

Speaker: NA
Text: from pyrites-thos e figures are from memspeaks-whic

Speaker: NA
Text: ory-now , because of this 10s. drop in

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty, it will receive the squeeze from

Speaker: NA
Text: other end. The letter continues-

Speaker: NA
Text: To illustrate our point we attach a statement

Speaker: NA
Text: showing cost, prices fixed and cash retention

Speaker: NA
Text: a 10-year period. It will be noted from this

Speaker: NA
Text: the total accumulated margin over the ten

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts to only Â£90,000. A considerable sum in

Speaker: NA
Text: excess of this has of necessity been spent

Speaker: NA
Text: plant extension and renewals (out of original

Speaker: NA
Text: capital) to enable production to be maintained

Speaker: NA
Text: and extended. The plant has now reached

Speaker: NA
Text: stage when major renewals are necessary,

Speaker: NA
Text: no liquid funds are available to meet these.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Company has an obligation to repay

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£200,000 per annum to the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Development Bank and this must be recovered

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of acid. The Company is also permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Taxation Department-

Speaker: NA
Text: I have to admire their language-

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide Â£189,000 per annum for depreciation

Speaker: NA
Text: which must also be recovered in the price of firm-it

Speaker: NA
Text: acid. The price fixed has consistently allowed

Speaker: NA
Text: only the Â£200,000 to be recovered, consequently

Speaker: NA
Text: no plant replacement reserve has been accumulated.

Speaker: NA
Text: This leads automatically to the point

Speaker: NA
Text: made towards the end of the paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: the report referred to by the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Yarra. I t makes one wonder

Speaker: NA
Text: exactly where we are going and what is

Text: cent, without additional costs, particularly

Text: the same proportion of 50 per cent, of

Text: sulphur, this production would yield another

Speaker: NA
Text: cent, without increasing current capacity.

Text: a production of 1,500 tons of pyrites every

Text: day at Renison and it is a pity to think that

Text: this may be washed down one of the streams

Text: or simply stockpiled somewhere so that it

Text: will be out of the way, while we are forced

Text: tities of imported brimstone.

Speaker: NA
Text: report-

Text: The five pyrites producers employ about 3,800

Speaker: NA

Text: ployment if Australia went over entirely to

Text: from mining operations. Some of these

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a small profit.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think the answer to the question asked

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honorable member for Yarra is this:

Speaker: NA
Text: If it were not for this little amount that

Speaker: NA
Text: company gets from its by-products, it would

Text: the lines: " We will close down our

Text: production "; it is more a question of look-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing at the whole overall financial operations

Text: of the company for a year, and when that

Text: is done the money derived from the bounty

Text: on by-products like pyrites becomes increastheir

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly important. It is with this in view that

Text: come.
