Text: viewing managers and directors and prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tically begging them to do everything pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sible to use pyrites for the production

Speaker: NA
Text: acid. One can readily imagine how shipping

Speaker: NA
Text: was being subjected to enemy attack at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time, and we can understand why the Gosuggested

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment wanted to retain a process for the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of acid from a locally proelemental

Speaker: NA
Text: duced material. If we are forced into a

Speaker: NA
Text: position in which we are entirely dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: upon imported brimstone it will be a sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: situation indeed, particularly if we disregard,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the meantime, all our supplies of pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: and all our pyrites machinery.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government encouraged companies

Speaker: NA
Text: at that time to continue their production

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites because of the tremendous import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of sulphuric acid. It is the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacture of superphosphate, and we

Speaker: NA
Text: know of the tremendous value of that

Speaker: NA
Text: material to primary industry, which is our

Speaker: NA
Text: major export income earner. Every indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trial concern of any note uses sulphuric acid

Speaker: NA
Text: at some time in its operations. There would

Speaker: NA
Text: a be hardly an article in this chamber, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, that has not come into contact with

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid at some time during the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess of manufacture. These mining organisa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions were encouraged during the Second

Speaker: NA
Text: World War to expand their pyrites opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions so that we would not be entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites dependent on overseas supplies.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1950 there was a very grave world

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of sulphur, and again the Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian Government asked producers to expand

Speaker: NA
Text: operations, using local pyrites. The

Speaker: NA
Text: process in which pyrites is used is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: costly operation compared with the one in

Speaker: NA
Text: which imported brimstone is used. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for Angas has pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out one or two of the disadvantages of using

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites. There is, of course, a very heavy

Speaker: NA
Text: to freight charge, because 50 per cent, of the

Speaker: NA
Text: product is of no value. In Tasmania the

Speaker: NA
Text: material has to be taken from the mine,

Speaker: NA
Text: hisseparated in the concentrate process and

Speaker: NA
Text: then taken 26 miles by truck to Strahan. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is shipped from the west coast of Tasmania

Speaker: NA
Text: to Melbourne. Here we are taking a product

Speaker: NA
Text: in bulk and 50 per cent, of it is of no value.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the acid plant the iron oxide has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: separated from the elemental sulphur. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: have said, we are transporting 50 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: iron oxide that is of no value at all. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: to the elemental surphur that we have to

Speaker: NA
Text: I was very interested to hear the views

Speaker: NA
Text: of of Professor Hunter of the University of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney who, before the Tariff Board,

Speaker: NA
Text: directed attention to this very feature. He

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government should in-

Speaker: NA
Text: vestigate ways and means of separating the

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur from the iron oxide at the

Speaker: NA
Text: place of production of the pyrites. If this

Speaker: NA
Text: separation could take place at the scene

Speaker: NA
Text: of mining operations we would save a tre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendous amount in freight costs. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would be all to the good. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, through the Bureau of Mineral

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources and the various other agencies

Speaker: NA
Text: that it has at its command, will take action

Speaker: NA
Text: of on the submission made by Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter and conduct investigations into the

Speaker: NA
Text: possibility of breaking up the iron sulphide,

Speaker: NA
Text: or pyrites, as we know it, into the two

Speaker: NA
Text: components-iro n oxide and elemental

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur-a t the site of the mine.

Speaker: NA
Text: In asking the producers to expand their

Speaker: NA
Text: production of pyrites, we must bear in

Speaker: NA
Text: mind that acid producers will require larger

Speaker: NA
Text: plants than are required for the manufac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture of sulphuric acid from brimstone. Time

Speaker: NA
Text: will not permit me to go into the process in

Speaker: NA
Text: detail, Mr Deputy Speaker. With a larger

Speaker: NA
Text: plant a great deal of extra maintenance is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed on the plant itself. Furthermore, gas

Speaker: NA
Text: obtained from iron pyrites has to be cleaned

Speaker: NA
Text: to a much greater extent than gas obtained

Speaker: NA
Text: from a brimstone burning plant. When

Speaker: NA
Text: H.SO4, or sulphuric acid, is produced from

Speaker: NA
Text: elemental sulphur obtained from pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a certain amount of sludge in it

Speaker: NA
Text: and this has to be cleaned out, whereas the

Speaker: NA
Text: acid produced from imported brimstone is

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly clean. All these additional costs make

Speaker: NA
Text: it much more expensive to manufacture

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid from pyrites.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government recognised all this in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1930 as it had been recognised during the

Speaker: NA
Text: Second World War. When there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: shortage of sulphur in 1950, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment saw the purpose of using the local

Speaker: NA
Text: product, despite all the disadvantages. It

Speaker: NA
Text: appealed to producers of sulphuric acid to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase their use of the local pyrites and

Speaker: NA
Text: gave an undertaking to help them. It pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: mised this assistance by way of bounty and

Speaker: NA
Text: the sulphuric acid bounty came into opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion for the first time in 1954 under the

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of the Sulphuric Acid Bounty Act of

Speaker: NA
Text: that year. A change came over the scene

Speaker: NA
Text: during the 1950's because more deposits of

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone were found overseas and the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of the imported commodity fell. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in the import figures, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker. The Statistical Service of the

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Library has kindly prepared for me

Speaker: NA
Text: statistics showing the total value of imports

Speaker: NA
Text: of sulphur into Australia in recent years.

Speaker: NA
Text: These indicate a tremendous rise in imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Service has also kindly prepared figures

Speaker: NA
Text: showing imports of sulphur by weight from

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States of America, Mexico and

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada, With the concurrence of honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: members, I incorporate the two tables in

Speaker: NA
Text: " Hansard ".

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA-VALU E OF TOTAL IMPORTS

Speaker: NA
Text: OF SULPHUR FROM 1949-50 TO 1964-65.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Â£A. f.o.b. port of shipment)

Speaker: NA
Text: Year Value of Sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: Imported

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA-IMPORT S OF SULPHUR.

Speaker: NA
Text: From

Speaker: NA
Text: Total United From From

Speaker: NA
Text: States of Mexico Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: America

Speaker: NA
Text: Tons Tons Tons Tons

Speaker: NA
Text: The figures show that a very interesting

Speaker: NA
Text: development has taken place. We have no

Speaker: NA
Text: figures for imports from Canada until 1961-

Speaker: NA
Text: 62, when we imported 1,502 tons of sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: from that country. Imports from Canada

Speaker: NA
Text: rose dramatically from 21,218 tons in 1962-

Speaker: NA
Text: 63, to 47,523 tons in 1963-64 and to

Speaker: NA
Text: 175,754 tons in 1964-65. We also import

Speaker: NA
Text: a considerable volume from Mexico and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. In 1964-65 we imported

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliasulphur to a total value of Â£3,239,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: These imports represent a drain on our

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas reserves.

Speaker: NA
Text: The high price of Australian production

Speaker: NA
Text: based on local pyrites brought about a

Speaker: NA
Text: change in the Government's policy and it is

Speaker: NA
Text: now of the opinion that we should use im-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported brimstone. The Tariff Board, in its

Speaker: NA
Text: report, admits that there is an obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: to local manufacturers who, during the

Speaker: NA
Text: Second World War and in the early 1950s

Speaker: NA
Text: when there was a shortage of sulphur went

Speaker: NA
Text: to a great deal of expense in installing

Speaker: NA
Text: plant and undertaking work in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: carry out the Government's wishes and

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that we would have adequate sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: plies of sulphuric acid in Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: event of any international disturbance. The

Speaker: NA
Text: local producers changed over to imported

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone. A.C.F. and Shirleys Fertilisers

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd. in Queensland, as I indicated earlier,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be using imported brimstone entirely

Speaker: NA
Text: after June of this year. Imperial Chemical

Speaker: NA
Text: Industries of Australia and New Zealand

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd. in 1964 undertook tremendous expan-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion of its plant, based on the use of im-

Speaker: NA
Text: ported brimstone. Today we have only five

Speaker: NA
Text: pyritic acid plants in Australia apart from

Speaker: NA
Text: the I.CLA.N.Z. factory in Victoria that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have mentioned. The operators of these

Speaker: NA
Text: plants have stated that they can change them

Speaker: NA
Text: to brimstone plants at a small cost of some

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£20,000. As the Tariff Board declared, it

Speaker: NA
Text: is up to these manufacturers to say whether

Speaker: NA
Text: they propose to change from the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites to the use of brimstone.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that the policy that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted by the Government is wrong. Recompany's

Speaker: NA
Text: ports from producers of elemental sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas have indicated in recent weeks that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is concern about the extent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: deposits available to them, although no people

Speaker: NA
Text: definite information is at hand yet. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: the huge imports of sulphur from overseas,

Speaker: NA
Text: in recent weeks there have been suggestions

Speaker: NA
Text: that deposits of elemental sulphur available

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas may not be sufficient to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian imports of this magnitude. So

Speaker: NA
Text: consider that the Government and the Tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: Board, and particularly the manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are changing so rapidly to the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: imported brimstone, should consider

Speaker: NA
Text: matter again as quickly as possible.

Speaker: NA
Text: be a terrible thing for Australia if we found

Speaker: NA
Text: that our supplies of sulphur were cut off

Speaker: NA
Text: by some international disturbance and we

Speaker: NA
Text: had to revert to using pyrites. We would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to make the change at short control

Speaker: NA
Text: notice and the Government should never to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow us to get into such a situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The danger to tbe sulphuric acid industry

Speaker: NA
Text: was taken into account by the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: in conjunction with evidence submitted

Speaker: NA
Text: the five mining companies and the acid

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers at the Board's last inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: Evidence was given concerning the various

Speaker: NA
Text: problems that are foreseen, particularly if

Speaker: NA
Text: imported sulphur should be used entirely.

Speaker: NA
Text: The mining companies submitted four main

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons for the continued use of local

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites. It was agreed that sulphur is a

Speaker: NA
Text: mineral of strategic importance and of great

Speaker: NA
Text: value, particularly in time of emergency

Speaker: NA
Text: when overseas supplies may be cut off. As

Speaker: NA
Text: I have stated, if this were to happen wc

Speaker: NA
Text: could not revert at short notice to the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of sulphuric acid from pyrites, ft

Speaker: NA
Text: is important, even if for no reason other

Speaker: NA
Text: than defence needs, that we maintain our

Speaker: NA
Text: local industry. The local manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: also directed attention to the considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: savings in foreign exchange that could be

Speaker: NA
Text: effected by the use of sulphur from indige-

Speaker: NA
Text: nous sources. As I have stated, we are

Speaker: NA
Text: importing annually sulphur worth

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£3,239,000 at a time when there is no

Speaker: NA
Text: need for such a large volume of imports of

Speaker: NA
Text: this commodity.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I am especially

Speaker: NA
Text: interested in the position of the Mount Lyell

Speaker: NA
Text: Mining and Railway Co. Ltd. at Mount

Speaker: NA
Text: Lyell on the west coast of Tasmania. This

Speaker: NA
Text: mine has been in operation for

Speaker: NA
Text: 70 years. It operates on the lowest grade

Speaker: NA
Text: ore in the world. It. is an extremely efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: mine. This has been recognised by mining

Speaker: NA
Text: experts all over the world. Some 7,000

Speaker: NA
Text: are directly or indirectly concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: or connected with the mine and interested

Speaker: NA
Text: economically in its well-being. Back in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1905, to find an outlet for pyrites, it started

Speaker: NA
Text: a chemical works in Victoria for the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of fertiliser. During the next 30

Speaker: NA
Text: I years we sent about 150,000 tons to that

Speaker: NA
Text: works and in 1934 we changed from pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: to pyritic concentrate. This was a by-pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct of the concentration plant. In the last

Speaker: NA
Text: the 30 years we have shipped to Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: It would 1,400,000 tons for processing.

Speaker: NA
Text: This connection of Mount Lyell with

Speaker: NA
Text: chemical works no longer exists, due to a

Speaker: NA
Text: series of take-overs. Now the people who

Speaker: NA
Text: the fertiliser works are in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: dictate the quantities they will take from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Lyell. The quantities they take de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pend almost entirely on whether the bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: is to be continued. It is for that reason that

Speaker: NA
Text: I strongly support the continuation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: by bounty. Over the past 70 years some great

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidiaries have been built up. There were

Speaker: NA
Text: the chemical works and metal industries

Speaker: NA
Text: and then, a few years ago, the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: operations of the company were split into

Speaker: NA
Text: two groups. We had the mining operation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Mount Lyell Mining and Railway Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany and also Mount Lyell Investments.

Speaker: NA
Text: This breaking up, I feel, weakened the posi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the company and made it easier

Speaker: NA
Text: for take-overs. In came Patino and offered

Speaker: NA
Text: to take over. That company was unsuccess-

Speaker: NA
Text: ful because Boral outbid it. Later, Consoli-

Speaker: NA
Text: dated Gold Fields (Aust.) Pty. Ltd. took

Speaker: NA
Text: over from Boral. Because of the separation

Speaker: NA
Text: into two groups and because the mining

Speaker: NA
Text: operations were set out on their own, it

Speaker: NA
Text: became increasingly important to look for

Speaker: NA
Text: all sorts of means to obtain additional

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue to incorporate in the financial

Speaker: NA
Text: balance sheet of the company. So pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: has often helped us over difficult times when

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of copper has not been as high

Speaker: NA
Text: as it is today. Pyrites has often helped us

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep open the mine and to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: employment.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said earlier, I will be very pleased

Speaker: NA
Text: if the bounty is continued for many years

Speaker: NA
Text: to come because the life of the open cut

Speaker: NA
Text: mine is expected to be another eight or

Speaker: NA
Text: nine years. It has been proved that under

Speaker: NA
Text: the open cut there is about 40 million tons

Speaker: NA
Text: of ore. Tf this deposit is to be operated it

Speaker: NA
Text: must be done economically. It will be a far

Speaker: NA
Text: more expensive operation than open cut

Speaker: NA
Text: mining and it will become more important

Speaker: NA
Text: that the bounty continue because this will

Speaker: NA
Text: add to the returns from the mining opera-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions and enable us to keep afloat. Why

Speaker: NA
Text: should we not use tbe local indigenous pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duct and so assist our overseas balance of

Speaker: NA
Text: payments position and guard against any

Speaker: NA
Text: disruption to our supplies in case of war.

Speaker: NA
Text: As T have already indicated, we are capable

Speaker: NA
Text: of producing 100,000 tons a year and

Speaker: NA
Text: Renison Bell is capable of producing any-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing up to 750 tons of sulphur a day, which

Speaker: NA
Text: would provide a saving of Â£3 million a

Speaker: NA
Text: year to this country.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr COLLARD
Text: Kalgoorlie) [10.43] -

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of one of the Bills before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is to amend the Pyrites Bounty Act

Speaker: NA
Text: 1960, which was amended earlier this year

Speaker: NA
Text: by Act No. 37 of 1965. The 1960 Act

Speaker: NA
Text: provided a bounty period commencing on

Speaker: NA
Text: lst January 1961 and expiring on the last

Speaker: NA
Text: day of June this year. The Government

Speaker: NA
Text: therefore brought down a small amending

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill prior to that date. The Bill, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: passed by the Parliament, extended the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty period for six months from the first

Speaker: NA
Text: day of July until the last day of December

Speaker: NA
Text: this year. The Bill with which we are now

Speaker: NA
Text: dealing will amend the Act further by

Speaker: NA
Text: extending the bounty period to the last

Speaker: NA
Text: day of June 1969, that is, for a period of

Speaker: NA
Text: three and a half years. This period is the

Speaker: NA
Text: term recommended by the Tariff Board. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the period can be extended if there

Speaker: NA
Text: is need to do so when it expires. If

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary the action could be taken well

Speaker: NA
Text: before then, if the demand for the sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing material is still there. To my mind,

Speaker: NA
Text: the three and a half years term is not

Speaker: NA
Text: excessive. I believe that it certainly should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be any less than that if it is to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the requirements of the mining companies

Speaker: NA
Text: which are producing sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: material. I shall say a few more words on

Speaker: NA
Text: that score a little later.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must keep in mind that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Australia is under some obligation

Speaker: NA
Text: to certain producers of sulphuric acid and

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur bearing material for the part that

Speaker: NA
Text: they played in that production when

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies of brimstone were difficult to obtain

Speaker: NA
Text: from overseas. We cannot be sure that a

Speaker: NA
Text: similar position will not come about at some

Speaker: NA
Text: time in the not too distant future. For that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason alone I feel that we should, while

Speaker: NA
Text: it is possible to do so, and within reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, ensure that the sulphur acid

Speaker: NA
Text: production plants and the sulphur material

Speaker: NA
Text: production mines are kept in operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: From 1958 up to and including June 1964

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 1,300,000 tons of sulphur was

Speaker: NA
Text: imported by Australia, mainly from

Speaker: NA
Text: Mexico and the United States of America.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since 1958 the largest amount was imported

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1963-64 when more than 304,000

Speaker: NA
Text: tons was brought in. In that same year we

Speaker: NA
Text: produced in Australia about 109,000 tons

Speaker: NA
Text: of pyrites. That met only about a quarter of

Speaker: NA
Text: our requirements. However, I suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: the amount we are producing at this stage

Speaker: NA
Text: is not the all important factor. What is

Speaker: NA
Text: important is that we have the sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing material available in case our over-

Speaker: NA
Text: seas sources fail or become in short supply

Speaker: NA
Text: while there is still an urgent demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1950, as the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Braddon ( Mr Davies) has said, there was a

Speaker: NA
Text: world shortage of sulphur which would have

Speaker: NA
Text: meant a shortage of sulphuric acid in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country and, in turn, a serious shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate for our primary industries.

Speaker: NA
Text: This position caused the Government of

Speaker: NA
Text: the time some serious concern. In primary

Speaker: NA
Text: industry, as honorable members are aware,

Speaker: NA
Text: the prime purpose of the use of sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid is to break down phosphate .rock into

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate. Any shortage of super-

Speaker: NA
Text: phosphate, because of a shortage of sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid, would mean a serious retarda-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of our primary production. Because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the great value of our primary industries in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to overseas earnings the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment at that time thought it wise and

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to encourage the mining of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think I am correct in saying that it

Speaker: NA
Text: was during the life of the Chifley Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that negotiations took place between

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government and companies which were

Speaker: NA
Text: producing or could produce sulphuric

Speaker: NA
Text: acid from the pyrites and also the

Speaker: NA
Text: companies which at the time were produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing pyrites. The purpose of the negotiations

Speaker: NA
Text: was to arrive at an arrangement whereby

Speaker: NA
Text: the companies could be assisted to extract

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur or produce pyrites, as the case may

Speaker: NA
Text: be, and also to ensure their protection

Speaker: NA
Text: against overseas companies or interests

Speaker: NA
Text: which could, when supplies became more

Speaker: NA
Text: freely available, supply the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements more cheaply than could be

Speaker: NA
Text: done with the materials produced and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cessed in Australia. The principle behind

Speaker: NA
Text: the idea was that the people who were

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to install plants to extract

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur from pyrites or to develop mines

Speaker: NA
Text: to produce the material when the supply

Speaker: NA
Text: was short and the demand was urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: should not be cast aside and forgotten if

Speaker: NA
Text: there should subsequently be a plentiful

Speaker: NA
Text: supply from elsewhere of the sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: bearing material and the acid. There was

Speaker: NA
Text: a fair enough proposition, and the present

Speaker: NA
Text: Government continued that policy after it

Speaker: NA
Text: came into office. The bounty is still paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: acid producers as an encouragement to use

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian produced pyrites. The Bill to

Speaker: NA
Text: which I wish to refer relates mainly to assistgamble

Speaker: NA
Text: ance given to the industry which is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing pyrites, or sulphur-bearing material.

Speaker: NA
Text: It must be borne in mind that the mines

Speaker: NA
Text: from which pyrites is obtained cannot be

Speaker: NA
Text: turned on and off like a tap. Ji they are

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to close, most of them will remain

Speaker: NA
Text: closed. In most cases, it would cost more

Speaker: NA
Text: to re-open them when the demand for their

Speaker: NA
Text: product is once again with us than it would

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to continue paying the bounty for

Speaker: NA
Text: several years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The total amount paid out in bounties

Speaker: NA
Text: during the year ended June 1964 was

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£644,275. This was divided amongst five

Speaker: NA
Text: producing companies. Gold Mines of Kal-

Speaker: NA
Text: goorlie (Aust.) Ltd -which , incidentally,

Speaker: NA
Text: produces gold mainly and pyrites only as a

Speaker: NA
Text: sideline-receive d a bounty of Â£48,539. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Mount Lyell Mining and Railway Co. Ltd.,

Speaker: NA
Text: which produces copper mainly, received

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£177,463. Nairne Pyrites Pty. Ltd., which

Speaker: NA
Text: produces pyrites exclusively, received

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£207,973. Mount Morgan Ltd., which is

Speaker: NA
Text: also mainly a copper producer, received

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£109,707, and Norseman Gold Mines No

Speaker: NA
Text: Liability, which is exclusively a pyrites pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducer, received Â£100,593. Even with the

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid bounty added, the total

Speaker: NA
Text: amount estimated to be payable in the

Speaker: NA
Text: year 1965-66 is only Â£1,566,000, which is a

Speaker: NA
Text: very small sum compared with the total

Speaker: NA
Text: of Â£56,108,000 which is paid out in bounties

Speaker: NA
Text: and subsidies generally in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I said earlier, the recommendation of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tariff Board that the payment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty be extended for a further three and a

Speaker: NA
Text: half years could not be considered exces-

Speaker: NA
Text: sive or beyond what is necessary when the

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances relating to the mining of

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites are appreciated. In fact, a mining

Speaker: NA
Text: company which is able to continue only

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the bounty it receives is restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: to quite some extent if it can be sure of only

Speaker: NA
Text: a further three and a half or four years of

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty period. However, generally speaking,

Speaker: NA
Text: a definite term of at least three and a half

Speaker: NA
Text: years will allow a mining company, under

Speaker: NA
Text: normal circumstances of mining, to carry

Speaker: NA
Text: out development work to open up further

Speaker: NA
Text: ore bodies of pyrites. This would not be

Speaker: NA
Text: possible, or at least would be a terrific

Speaker: NA
Text: gamble, if the term of the bounty was for

Speaker: NA
Text: some snorter period. It would certainly be a

Speaker: NA
Text: if there was no certainty of continua-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of bounty beyond the three and a half

Speaker: NA
Text: years. I am sure that some mining com-

Speaker: NA
Text: panies would not be prepared to take the

Speaker: NA
Text: gamble and would be more inclined to mine

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever ore was readily available, or

Speaker: NA
Text: simply to carry out only that amount of

Speaker: NA
Text: development work which would be sufficient

Speaker: NA
Text: to keep the mine going until the expiry date

Speaker: NA
Text: for payment of bounties.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that it must be remembered that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to ensure the life of a mine,

Speaker: NA
Text: development work must be kept well ahead

Speaker: NA
Text: of the stoping or ore breaking work, and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is such development work as winzing, rising,

Speaker: NA
Text: cross-cutting and driving which is the most

Speaker: NA
Text: costly part of mining operations. A lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: work has to be done from which no revenue,

Speaker: NA
Text: or very little, is derived. Development work

Speaker: NA
Text: is usually carried out in mullock, and not

Speaker: NA
Text: in the sulphur bearing material. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: in the case of a pyrites mine, not one penny

Speaker: NA
Text: is recovered from the development work to

Speaker: NA
Text: offset its cost.

Speaker: NA
Text: To open up a new ore body and to get it

Speaker: NA
Text: ready for stoping and the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur bearing material may take six

Speaker: NA
Text: months or even longer, and this is all dead

Speaker: NA
Text: work for which no remuneration is received.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is quite obvious, therefore, that if a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany is working on only a small profit it

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot take the odds as to whether the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty will continue, particularly if the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty presently being paid is. to continue

Speaker: NA
Text: for only a short period. Companies must be

Speaker: NA
Text: positive that when the development work is

Speaker: NA
Text: completed, and they reach the stage where

Speaker: NA
Text: they can start producing sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: material, the bounty will continue to apply

Speaker: NA
Text: while they are actually bringing out the ore.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further, we should not be concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with the mining companies. Very serious

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration must also be given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare of the people who are dependent

Speaker: NA
Text: both directly and indirectly upon the mines.

Speaker: NA
Text: The closure of a mine, even a small one,

Speaker: NA
Text: can have a very serious effect on a whole

Speaker: NA
Text: town. Take as an example a mine employing

Speaker: NA
Text: about 100 men. If it ceases to function,

Speaker: NA
Text: those men are out of work, and all the

Speaker: NA
Text: members of their families, who might

Speaker: NA
Text: ber perhaps 150 or 200, are also seriously

Speaker: NA
Text: affected. One such mine would be Norseman

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Mines No Liability, which produces

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites exclusively. Therefore, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: to see that on this occasion the bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: period is to be at least the same as applied

Speaker: NA
Text: from 1960.

Speaker: NA
Text: There seems no reason why there should

Speaker: NA
Text: not be a similar extension in 1969. As

Speaker: NA
Text: things are at present, if there is any sugges-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that the bounty will cease, it is possible

Speaker: NA
Text: that mining companies will concentrate only

Speaker: NA
Text: on rich or readily available ore. This in turn

Speaker: NA
Text: could result in the employees looking else-

Speaker: NA
Text: where for security of employment and even-

Speaker: NA
Text: tually the mines could face the further

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty of lack of labour. But as this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for the payment of the bounty for

Speaker: NA
Text: a further 3 i years that position should not

Speaker: NA
Text: arise.

Speaker: NA
Text: It might be appropriate at this stage to

Speaker: NA
Text: draw attention to the sulphur content of the

Speaker: NA
Text: pyrites being mined in Australia. If, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: not too distant future, we return to a position

Speaker: NA
Text: where there is a shortage of supplies of

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone from overseas, it will be these

Speaker: NA
Text: mines which will be called upon to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: their production substantially so that suf-

Speaker: NA
Text: ficient supplies of sulphur will be available

Speaker: NA
Text: for our primary industries. For . the year

Speaker: NA
Text: ended 30th June 1964, Norseman Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Mines No Liability showed a 48.2 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: extraction. Mount Morgan Ltd. achieved an

Speaker: NA
Text: extraction of 50.8 per cent., the highest of

Speaker: NA
Text: the five companies producing pyrites. Nairne

Speaker: NA
Text: Pyrites Ltd. had an extraction of 40.7 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. Mount Lyell Mining and Railway Co.

Speaker: NA
Text: Ltd. achieved an extraction of 46.8 per cent,

Speaker: NA
Text: and Gold Mines of Kalgoorlie (Aust.) Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: had an extraction rate of 31.6 per cent. As

Speaker: NA
Text: I stated earlier, the production of sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrates is only a sideline with Gold

Speaker: NA
Text: Mines of Kalgoorlie. It obtains the sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: concentrates from its gold extraction pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess. It produced only 7,938 tons of sulphur.

Speaker: NA
Text: The average extraction from the total pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: only duction of 247,828 tons of pyrites by the

Speaker: NA
Text: five companies was 43.9 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Anyone who has had any experience of

Speaker: NA
Text: mining pyrites will agree that those are very

Speaker: NA
Text: good extraction figures and that they indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cate how very valuable these producers will

Speaker: NA
Text: be if, at some later stage, there should be

Speaker: NA
Text: all a shortage of supplies from overseas. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: might suggest that the mines to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: numhave referred should cease operations at

Speaker: NA
Text: times when there are plentiful supplies of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphur-bearing material available so that

Speaker: NA
Text: much more of the local product will be

Speaker: NA
Text: pleased available in times of shortage.

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ful suggestion.

Speaker: Mr COLLARD
Text: Someon e may suggest

Speaker: NA
Text: it, so I am supplying the answer before-

Speaker: NA
Text: hand. While such a suggestion may sound

Speaker: NA
Text: all right, unfortunately one cannot turn the

Speaker: NA
Text: mines on and off at will. If they were to

Speaker: NA
Text: cease production they would soon become

Speaker: NA
Text: unsafe and unworkable. Consequently when

Speaker: NA
Text: local supplies were desperately needed it

Speaker: NA
Text: would not be possible to bring the mines

Speaker: NA
Text: back to their stage of production at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: they ceased operations and therefore the

Speaker: NA
Text: additional material would be lost. For that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason it is wise to keep them operating

Speaker: NA
Text: while it is possible to do so. It would be

Speaker: NA
Text: most unwise to adopt a different attitude.

Speaker: NA
Text: We must also have regard to the treatment!

Speaker: NA
Text: plants which would not last any time at

Speaker: NA
Text: all once they ceased operating. The cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: rosive effect would soon ruin these plants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because we could at some time be faced

Speaker: NA
Text: with a shortage from overseas the users of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid should be obliged to use a

Speaker: NA
Text: percentage of the local product to ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: that the producers of pyrites can continue

Speaker: NA
Text: to operate. There is some obligation on the

Speaker: NA
Text: superphosphate companies, just as there is

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Government, to keep pyrites pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers in business. It has been suggested

Speaker: NA
Text: that at some future time neither brimstone

Speaker: NA
Text: nor pyrites will be required and that sul-

Speaker: NA
Text: phuric acid may be displaced by something

Speaker: NA
Text: equally as good and more readily available.

Speaker: NA
Text: If and when that happens we will be in a

Speaker: NA
Text: completely different position. We will not

Speaker: NA
Text: have worries about a possible shortage of

Speaker: NA
Text: brimstone or other sulphur bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: materials, but until it does happen, and

Speaker: NA
Text: until we can be quite certain that sulphur

Speaker: NA
Text: or sulphur bearing material is not required,

Speaker: NA
Text: we must ensure that the existing avenues

Speaker: NA
Text: for obtaining sulphur are kept open, and

Speaker: NA
Text: those producing pyrites should be assisted

Speaker: NA
Text: by the payment of the bounty.

Speaker: NA
Text: It may be thought that the average receipt

Speaker: NA
Text: of something less than Â£129,000 annually

Speaker: NA
Text: by the pyrites producing companies does

Speaker: NA
Text: not play a big part in keeping the mines in

Speaker: NA
Text: production, but it would be wrong to arrive

Speaker: NA
Text: at such a conclusion, because that bounty

Speaker: NA
Text: is of considerable benefit. During 1963-64

Speaker: NA
Text: the five companies concerned received

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£644,275 paid on 247,828 tons of pyrites

Speaker: NA
Text: from which 108,932 tons of sulphur was

Speaker: NA
Text: extracted. This means that they received

Speaker: NA
Text: about Â£2 12s. a ton of pyrites produced-

Speaker: NA
Text: not on every ton of ore produced, but on

Speaker: NA
Text: every ton of pyrites after the milling pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cess. This has been of considerable assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. It could easily mean the difference

Speaker: NA
Text: between a mine continuing to operate and

Speaker: NA
Text: its closing down. Both Norseman and

Speaker: NA
Text: Nairne are dependent entirely on the proadopted

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of pyrites and, as the Tariff Board

Speaker: NA
Text: report points out, there is litde if any

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative employment in those places if

Speaker: NA
Text: the mines should cease production. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: an important factor. The removal of the

Speaker: NA
Text: bounty would result in an increase in costs

Speaker: NA
Text: to those companies mining gold or copper

Speaker: NA
Text: with pyrites as a sideline. This, in turn,

Speaker: NA
Text: would affect employment, particularly of

Speaker: NA
Text: those engaged on the pyrites production side

Speaker: NA
Text: of the operations. About 4,000 men are

Speaker: NA
Text: directly involved and many more are in-

Speaker: NA
Text: directly concerned. This factor must surely

Speaker: NA
Text: be considered. Just because a mine is pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing pyrites as a side issue it should not be

Speaker: NA
Text: overlooked that sulphur concentrates can

Speaker: NA
Text: bring in some revenue whereby the overall

Speaker: NA
Text: production costs of the mine are reduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Gold Mines of Kalgoorlie receives consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: able' assistance under the Gold-Mining

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry Assistance Act. Its production costs

Speaker: NA
Text: are above Â£13 10s. an ounce of gold re-

Speaker: NA
Text: covered and gold is bringing only Â£15

Speaker: NA
Text: 12s. 6d. an ounce. By selling sulphur con-

Speaker: NA
Text: centrates the company can recover about

Speaker: NA
Text: Â£50,000 per annum and this may be suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient to enable the mine to keep operating

Speaker: NA
Text: and show some reasonable profit.

Speaker: NA
Text: We hear a lot about decentralisation and

Speaker: NA
Text: about setting up industries outside metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan areas. Mining is a ready-made indus-

Speaker: NA
Text: try for decentralisation. In almost every

Speaker: NA
Text: instance mines are located in outback areas

Speaker: NA
Text: and they attract employees. If mines are

Speaker: NA
Text: closed down and there are no other local

Speaker: NA
Text: employment avenues the mining towns

Speaker: NA
Text: become ghost towns. On the score of decen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralisation alone-th e need to extend our

Speaker: NA
Text: population beyond the boundaries of cities-

Speaker: NA
Text: the expenditure of Â£500,000 a year, much

Speaker: NA
Text: of which is returned to the Treasury in

Speaker: NA
Text: taxes, is not much to pay to help achieve

Speaker: NA
Text: an objective about which so many talk but

Speaker: NA
Text: upon which so few take any action. If there

Speaker: NA
Text: were no use for pyrites or sulphur the

Speaker: NA
Text: position would be entirely different but at

Speaker: NA
Text: present, and for some time to come, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure there will be a heavy demand for these

Speaker: NA
Text: materials, and where we can recover the

Speaker: NA
Text: local product at a reasonable price we

Speaker: NA
Text: should continue to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: I notice in the Tariff Board's report a

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation that the bounties be

Speaker: NA
Text: reviewed at least 12 months prior to their

Speaker: NA
Text: expiration. I hope this recommendation is

Speaker: NA
Text: so that mining companies and their

Speaker: NA
Text: employees will have ample warning should

Speaker: NA
Text: it ever be found no longer necessary to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinue the production of pyrites or the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: sulphuric acid. I support the Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Gray)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: ADJOURNMENT.

Speaker: NA
Text: Afforestation-Vietnam .

Speaker: NA
Text: Motion (by Mr Fairhall) proposed-

Speaker: NA
Text: That the House do now adjourn.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Oxley) [11.9] -Tonigh t

Speaker: NA
Text: I am moved to speak about the attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: towards forestry projects in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Specifically, of course, I apply my attention

Speaker: NA
Text: to the attitude to forestry projects in my

Speaker: NA
Text: home State of Queensland. Forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: mendously important subject for this Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth. For a long time forest planta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions operated by State Governments have

Speaker: NA
Text: been regarded as an avenue into which

Speaker: NA
Text: money has been put in times of economic

Speaker: NA
Text: fall off when there has been a need

Speaker: NA
Text: resuscitate the economy. This is one

Speaker: NA
Text: the fields in which the Commonwealtb

Speaker: NA
Text: Government invests public money in

Speaker: NA
Text: endeavour to pick up the growth of the

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. There was really no serious

Speaker: NA
Text: national application to the development

Speaker: NA
Text: a planned afforestation or reafforestation

Speaker: NA
Text: policy to serve the future needs of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: It would seem that for many years there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no appreciation of how serious Auswas

Speaker: NA
Text: tralia's plight would be in the future

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of provision of afforestation projects

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the Commonwealth, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly in the provision of softwoods.

Speaker: NA
Text: represents a serious shortcoming on the part

Speaker: NA
Text: of the State and Commonwealth Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments.

Speaker: NA
Text: In forestry we must realise the need

Speaker: NA
Text: project our thoughts a long way ahead.

Speaker: NA
Text: About 20 years must elapse from the time

Speaker: NA
Text: the plant is placed in the ground until

Speaker: NA
Text: has matured sufficiently for felling

Speaker: NA
Text: cessing. In talking of Australia's forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: needs we must not think in the short term

Speaker: NA
Text: of what we will need next year. We must

Speaker: NA
Text: take action to equip ourselves for the

Speaker: NA
Text: changes that will confront us in 20 years

Speaker: NA
Text: time. It appears that there has been some

Speaker: NA
Text: realisation in the Commonwealth of how

Speaker: NA
Text: seriously we are placed in relation to soft

Speaker: NA
Text: woods and of the demand that will exist

Speaker: NA
Text: the next 20 years. The point I make

Speaker: NA
Text: suddenly we have transposed ourselves from

Speaker: NA
Text: regarding forestry as an avenue of expendi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture to absorb slackness in a depressed state

Speaker: NA
Text: in the economy to realising that this is a

Speaker: NA
Text: field that is extremely important to Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and one in which we must invest money for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's future.

Speaker: NA
Text: In this country we can successfully grow

Speaker: NA
Text: softwoods to meet our future requirements

Speaker: NA
Text: -t o meet the increased demand that is now

Speaker: NA
Text: being met by imports. Anticipating how

Speaker: NA
Text: these imports will increase as demand in-

Speaker: NA
Text: creases, we can see the urgency of prevent-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing this heavy demand from becoming a

Speaker: NA
Text: drain on our overseas balances.

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Text: Wha t did a Labour govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: is a trement do about this?

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Tha t is a sensible

Speaker: NA
Text: question-somethin g that we do not often

Speaker: NA
Text: get from the honorable member for Gipps-

Speaker: NA
Text: land-s o I think I am justified in spending

Speaker: NA
Text: to some time on answering it. When Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: of was in power in Queensland a lot of

Speaker: NA
Text: money was spent on forestry. The Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: an land Labour Government was concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: about the welfare of unskilled labourers

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in the industry. The Labour Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: of vernment in Queensland had the most

Speaker: NA
Text: successful record of any State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in the field of decentralisation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Forestry was one avenue in which money

Speaker: NA
Text: invested fo achieve this success. The

Speaker: NA
Text: through honorable member would obtain some

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit if he were to read the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: "Year Book" and some of the economic

Speaker: NA
Text: This reports on this subject.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of forestry planta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions in the electorate of Oxley. Quite a

Speaker: NA
Text: to number of people-government ' employees

Speaker: NA
Text: and unskilled labourers-ar e engaged in

Speaker: NA
Text: this work. Several towns in the electorate-

Speaker: NA
Text: it some quite large-ar e dependent on the

Speaker: NA
Text: and probuoyancy of employment in forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: works for the circulation of money and

Speaker: NA
Text: the standard of prosperity of the people in

Speaker: NA
Text: the town. So when there is a cut back in

Speaker: NA
Text: forestry employment, the people in the

Speaker: NA
Text: town feel it and the standard of welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: of the town is placed in jeopardy. Recently

Speaker: NA
Text: there have been retrenchments of forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: employees in the Brisbane Valley, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: in in my electorate. Some of those employees

Speaker: NA
Text: is that had many years of service. Some bad

Speaker: NA
Text: served for a decade in the Forestry Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Arbitrarily, their services were dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: pensed with. Many of them had purchased

Speaker: NA
Text: homes in country towns. They found that

Speaker: NA
Text: they could not readily realise on their

Speaker: NA
Text: investment. This is often the case in

Speaker: NA
Text: country towns, where there is a limit to

Speaker: NA
Text: realisations of this kind. Additionally,

Speaker: NA
Text: these people had invested their futures and

Speaker: NA
Text: those of their young families in the country

Speaker: NA
Text: towns. I immediately contacted the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land Minister for Local Government and

Speaker: NA
Text: Conservation, Mr Richter, who advised me

Speaker: NA
Text: that he was greatly distressed by the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: missal of the forestry workers. He agreed

Speaker: NA
Text: that there had been large numbers of

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissals in the Forestry Department. He

Speaker: NA
Text: said-

Speaker: NA
Text: The necessity to terminate the services of

Speaker: NA
Text: Forestry workers' at all centres in Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: has been brought about by the insufficiency of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Loan Funds available to the Department for

Speaker: NA
Text: the financial year 1965-66.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been necessary to reduce the work

Speaker: NA
Text: force of the Department by over 200 men

Speaker: NA
Text: and unless additional funds become available

Speaker: NA
Text: the prospects of re-employing all or some of

Speaker: NA
Text: them is remote. Unfortunately the dismissals have

Speaker: NA
Text: in many cases brought the staffing below a level

Speaker: NA
Text: which was regarded as permanent staffing.

Speaker: NA
Text: .The Minister expressed his sorrow at the

Speaker: NA
Text: dismissals and said that unless there were

Speaker: NA
Text: some, change in the financial position of the

Speaker: NA
Text: State there was not much he could do in the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. Perhaps the honorable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Gippsland ( Mr Nixon), whose party claims

Speaker: NA
Text: to have an interest in rurai areas, could

Speaker: NA
Text: make representations in support of those

Speaker: NA
Text: that I now make for special funds to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made available by the Commonwealth to

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland in order to permit forestry

Speaker: NA
Text: works to be carried out unhindered.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tonight I received a reply to a question

Speaker: NA
Text: that I asked upon notice of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for National Development ( Mr Fairbairn).

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister's answer was a masterly effort

Speaker: NA
Text: at evasion. He used between 150 and 200

Speaker: NA
Text: words to say exactly nothing. I am no wiser

Speaker: NA
Text: now as to the Government's intentions in

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter than I was before I asked my

Speaker: NA
Text: question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me refer to some of the background

Speaker: NA
Text: of forestry. The current rate of expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: pn softwood plantings indicates that over

Speaker: NA
Text: the next five years we will be spending the

Speaker: NA
Text: annually about Â£16 million, but we should

Speaker: NA
Text: be spending Â£26 million or 624per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: more annually if we are to surmount the

Speaker: NA
Text: problem of the increasing demand for soft-

Speaker: NA
Text: woods- a demand which is leaping ahead of

Speaker: NA
Text: our capacity to supply. The Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Forestry Council, which comprises State

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers concerned with forestry, has said

Speaker: NA
Text: that we should be planting 75,000 acres of

Speaker: NA
Text: softwoods a year if we are to have self-

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiency by the year 2000. Newspaper

Speaker: NA
Text: articles have been written underscoring the

Speaker: NA
Text: urgency of the need to act immediately. We

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot put off this matter much longer. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is an important matter for Australia and Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian industry. Our present planting rate is

Speaker: NA
Text: only 37,000 acres a year. We must double

Speaker: NA
Text: our planting rate if we are to achieve self-

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiency by the turn of the century. Ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to one authoritative report, we have

Speaker: NA
Text: only to spend Â£3 million on softwoods in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to save an import bill of Â£200 million

Speaker: NA
Text: by the year 2000. This seems to me to be

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap insurance. Surely the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: should act. Apart from the fact that people

Speaker: NA
Text: will suffer because of retrenchments, apart

Speaker: NA
Text: from the fact that towns will suffer and

Speaker: NA
Text: their standard of prosperity decline ancl

Speaker: NA
Text: apart from the fact that decentralisation will

Speaker: NA
Text: suffer, there is an extremely important long

Speaker: NA
Text: term consideration. We talk about import

Speaker: NA
Text: replacement. Here is an opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent action. We must act now to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: serious problem that will present itself in the

Speaker: NA
Text: next 20 years and most emphatically by

Speaker: NA
Text: the turn of the century. There is a need for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government to aot urgently and in a

Speaker: NA
Text: positive manner to overcome this problem.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order ! The honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's time has expired.

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to say a few words on what has been

Speaker: NA
Text: called the " battle of the pamphlets ". Last

Speaker: NA
Text: week the honorable member for La Trobe

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Jess) asked the Prime Minister ( Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: Robert Menzies) a question in which he

Speaker: NA
Text: suggested that I had written a pamphlet

Speaker: NA
Text: about Vietnam and that the pamphlet had

Speaker: NA
Text: been distributed in schools. Assuming this

Speaker: NA
Text: to be correct the honorable member asked

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister whether he would see

Speaker: NA
Text: to it that some action was taken to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a proper statement made on the matter for

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit of school children. The first point

Speaker: NA
Text: I make is that the proposition in the question

Speaker: NA
Text: asked by the honorable member for La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe was completely incorrect. I did write

Speaker: NA
Text: a pamphlet about the war in Vietnam and

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,500 copies of it were printed.

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Text: B y whom?

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: I t was printed for

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Labour Party by the In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustrial Printing and Publicity Co. in Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne. The pamphlet was priced at 6d.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was advertised through the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: branches of the Australian Labour Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: The newspapers in the capital cities reported

Speaker: NA
Text: on it and we notified people that, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: would like copies of the pamphlet, they

Speaker: NA
Text: could get them at a cost of 6d. We had

Speaker: NA
Text: very many requests and copies of the pam-

Speaker: NA
Text: phlet were supplied at a cost of 6d. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: not a give away job like that of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bryant -I t was not done at public

Speaker: NA
Text: expense, either.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: A s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member says, it was not done at public ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pense. It was done at private expense. It was

Speaker: NA
Text: published with the authority of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Labour Party, printed by Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Printing and Publicity Co., sold for 6d. and

Speaker: NA
Text: 30,500 copies have been distributed, most of

Speaker: NA
Text: them being sold. The cost of more than Â£600

Speaker: NA
Text: has been more than recouped in the sale of

Speaker: NA
Text: the pamphlet. The pamphlet I wrote was

Speaker: NA
Text: sold. It was bought by people, a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of whom thought it was worth more than

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull -Tha t was before they

Speaker: NA
Text: read it.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Th e honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for Mallee is a great humorist at this

Speaker: NA
Text: hour of the night. We hardly hear anything

Speaker: NA
Text: of him during the day.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull -Wa s it before they read it

Speaker: NA
Text: or not?

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Ha s the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member read it?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Turnbull -No .

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: H e should get a

Speaker: NA
Text: copy and form his own judgment of it.

Speaker: NA
Text: In contrast to the way my pamphlet was

Speaker: NA
Text: produced, the Government, with all the

Speaker: NA
Text: resources of the Commonwealth at its distribution.

Speaker: NA
Text: posal, has chosen to publish at public

Speaker: NA
Text: expense a document that contains nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: but extracts from a few speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers. It is a party document. It con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sists of speeches made by a number of

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians, a number of members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament. It has been distributed at

Speaker: NA
Text: government expense to teachers and to

Speaker: NA
Text: other people in the community. It has been

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed at the expense of the people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. The suggestion was made that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was done because my pamphlet had been

Speaker: NA
Text: distributed in the schools. 1 should think

Speaker: NA
Text: that some teachers have asked for copies of

Speaker: NA
Text: my pamphlet. If they have, they have

Speaker: NA
Text: received them. But we have taken no action

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever at any stage to distribute the

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet that I wrote to teachers or to

Speaker: NA
Text: children in schools. It was not part of our

Speaker: NA
Text: intention to do so. But an attempt was made

Speaker: NA
Text: to justify the circulation through the schools

Speaker: NA
Text: of this drummed up job of extracts from

Speaker: NA
Text: politicians' speeches, produced at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of the public, by making the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely unfounded claim that my pamphlet

Speaker: NA
Text: was circulated through schools. If this is

Speaker: NA
Text: the basis on which the Government and the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for La Trobe seek to

Speaker: NA
Text: justify the circulation of this political docu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment through the schools at public expense,

Speaker: NA
Text: their justification disappears completely.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me mention two other matters. First,

Speaker: NA
Text: I thank the honorable member for La Trobe

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Prime Minister for the wonderful

Speaker: NA
Text: advertisement they have given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet that I have written, because we

Speaker: NA
Text: have had hundreds of requests for it. Most

Speaker: NA
Text: of the requests have come from teachers

Speaker: NA
Text: who, in letters that they have written to me,

Speaker: NA
Text: to my office and to the Australian Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: Party in Melbourne, have said that, if they

Speaker: NA
Text: are asked to distribute this document, this

Speaker: NA
Text: piece of paper that the Government has pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duced at public expense, they will also

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure that they distribute my pamphlet as

Speaker: NA
Text: well. Every second letter I open these days

Speaker: NA
Text: and have opened for five or six days con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tains a request for copies of the pamphlet

Speaker: NA
Text: that I wrote.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that is not right. That was corrected

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Wha t was corrected?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Th e allegation about dis-

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Ma y I state the

Speaker: NA
Text: made by position as I understand it?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: A copy was sent to the

Speaker: NA
Text: headmaster of each school.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Copie s were sent?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: On e copy.

Speaker: Dr JF CAIRNS
Text: Tw o copies in some

Speaker: NA
Text: Instances, because I know that is the num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber that was received. The Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: said the headmasters could have more

Speaker: NA
Text: copies if they wanted them.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Tha t is right.

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr JF CAIRNS What did I say that

Speaker: NA
Text: was contrary to that? Perhaps the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: can tell me. This is not thefirstpamphlet

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have seen distributed in schools. I

Speaker: NA
Text: remember that in the course of a teach-in

Speaker: NA
Text: at Maribyrnong High School in Victoria, I

Speaker: NA
Text: suppose six weeks ago, I saw a couple of

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred leaflets that had been published by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party. They were ready for cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: culation to the boys and girls in the leaving

Speaker: NA
Text: and matriculation classes at Maribyrnong

Speaker: NA
Text: High School. They had been taken there

Speaker: NA
Text: by former Senator Hannan. So, if any pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedent is wanted for the circulation of

Speaker: NA
Text: political documents in schools, there is one.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I make is that there is no justi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication for the position apparently taken

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Prime Minister. He seeks to justify

Speaker: NA
Text: the circulation to headmasters at schools of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party's pamphlet-tha t is all it

Speaker: NA
Text: can be called-whic h was produced at pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic expense and which contains the speeches

Speaker: NA
Text: of a number of Liberal Party members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Parliament, by alleging that my

Speaker: NA
Text: pamphlet had been circulated to schools. But

Speaker: NA
Text: this is completely false, because my pam-

Speaker: NA
Text: phlet never has been.

Speaker: NA
Text: I said that I thank the honorable mem-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber for La Trobe and the Prime Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: the publicity they have given to my leaflet.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope they will do the same for a book I

Speaker: NA
Text: will have published on Hth December. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: called " Living with Asia" and will be

Speaker: NA
Text: available through booksellers in the ordinary

Speaker: NA
Text: way. I hope that the Prime Minister, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member for La Trobe, the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Parkes ( Mr Hughes) and

Speaker: NA
Text: anyone else who wants to discuss the book

Speaker: NA
Text: will take advantage of the opportunity to

Speaker: NA
Text: do so. I believe it is most important that the

Speaker: NA
Text: war in Vietnam should be discussed. I

Speaker: NA
Text: believe it is important that pamphlets and

Speaker: NA
Text: books should be written about it. I approve

Speaker: NA
Text: even of the publication of the views of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister and the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: External Affairs ( Mr Hasluck), but not at

Speaker: NA
Text: public expense. If honorable members oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: site want to answer what I have done, let

Speaker: NA
Text: them to do it their own expense. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: a darn sight more money than I have. If

Speaker: NA
Text: they want to put their point of view to

Speaker: NA
Text: teachers or to anyone else in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity, let them do so at their own expense.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is precisely what we do.

Speaker: NA
Text: I welcome the publication of pamphlets

Speaker: NA
Text: and books. More of them on this subject

Speaker: NA
Text: have never been published; there, is now a

Speaker: NA
Text: flood of them. The other day someone sent

Speaker: NA
Text: me the titles of three books that had been

Speaker: NA
Text: recently published and said: " I hope you

Speaker: NA
Text: will make sure that they are in the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Library because, if these three books and

Speaker: NA
Text: most of those that have been published on

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam could be read even by members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party, I think the truth would

Speaker: NA
Text: eventually sink into their heads too." I hope

Speaker: NA
Text: that every pamphlet and every book that

Speaker: NA
Text: has been written on this subject receives the

Speaker: NA
Text: widest publicity. I hope that we continue

Speaker: NA
Text: with this great national debate on the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of Vietnam which began with the teach-

Speaker: NA
Text: ins at the beginning of this year. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been made available to university

Speaker: NA
Text: students in the form of teach-ins will be

Speaker: NA
Text: made available to the people of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: I conclude by challenging every memberof

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal Party and the Australian Coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try Party in Victoria to meet me in a debate

Speaker: NA
Text: on Vietnam in their own electorates between

Speaker: NA
Text: now and the time that the Parliament re-

Speaker: NA
Text: assembles next year. I formally issue a chal-

Speaker: NA
Text: lenge to every member of the Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Australian Country Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria to meet me in debate in his own

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate in a teach-in for the people on the

Speaker: NA
Text: vastly important subject of Vietnam.

Speaker: NA
Text: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11.29 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following answers to questions

Speaker: NA
Text: Forestry Employees in Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1356.)

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Is he able to say whether the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has undertaken a retrenchment of

Speaker: NA
Text: forestry workers which has already affected over

Speaker: NA
Text: 200 employees?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If so, is it a fact that this action was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessitated because of a shortage of funds and is

Speaker: NA
Text: there little likelihood of the dismissed employees

Speaker: NA
Text: being re-engaged unless extra funds become avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Have these dismissals in a number of in-

Speaker: NA
Text: stances resulted in staffs being reduced below

Speaker: NA
Text: what is regarded as the minimum level necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to maintain plantations, apart from carrying out

Speaker: NA
Text: forestry expansion policies? -

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Is it a fact that this retrenchment has

Speaker: NA
Text: occurred at a time when Australia should be

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in stepping up its softwood planting

Speaker: NA
Text: programme if it is to have any hope of adequately

Speaker: NA
Text: supplying its own future needs?

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. Will he consider taking steps.to grant special

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to Queensland in order to avoid any

Speaker: NA
Text: harmful restriction of its forestry programme and

Speaker: NA
Text: to ensure that the employment of forestry workers

Speaker: NA
Text: in that State is not jeopardised?

Speaker: Mr FAIRBAIRN
Text: Th e answers to the hon-

Speaker: NA
Text: orable member's questions are as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1, 2 and 3. I do understand that the Queens-

Speaker: NA
Text: land Government has undertaken a retrenchment

Speaker: NA
Text: of about this number of forestry employees. As

Speaker: NA
Text: this is essentially a State Government responsibility

Speaker: NA
Text: it would not be appropriate for me to comment

Speaker: NA
Text: on the reasons or precise results of this decision.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 and 5. The Australian Forestry Council has

Speaker: NA
Text: recommended that the softwood planting pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gramme be stepped up as early as possible to

Speaker: NA
Text: 73,000 acres per annum. This recommendation

Speaker: NA
Text: and itsfinancialimplications are at present under

Speaker: NA
Text: active consideration by the Commonwealth and

Speaker: NA
Text: State Governments.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1514.)

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: the Minister for Immi-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. How many aliens have-

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) registered; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) not registered,

Speaker: NA
Text: under the new Aliens Act?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. How many prosecutions have been launched

Speaker: NA
Text: under the new Act since the end of October and

Speaker: NA
Text: what has been the result of the prosecutions?

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE.

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice were circulated-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Opperman -Th e answers to the

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. (a) Notifications of address, occupation or

Speaker: NA
Text: employment and marital status have

Speaker: NA
Text: been received from 283,735 aliens re-

Speaker: NA
Text: siding in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) Interstate movements of aliens, variations

Speaker: NA
Text: of foreign names, etc., have made it a

Speaker: NA
Text: time-consuming process to reconcile

Speaker: NA
Text: notifications received with the index

Speaker: NA
Text: which is maintained on a State basis.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, it has been established that

Speaker: NA
Text: the overall figure of 396,012 aliens

Speaker: NA
Text: recorded in the index on 30th August

Speaker: NA
Text: 1965 is an inflated one as deaths and

Speaker: NA
Text: departures have not always been noti-

Speaker: NA
Text: fied. In view of this, it is not as yet

Speaker: NA
Text: possible to determine the actual num-

Speaker: NA
Text: ber who have not lodged notifications.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Nil. Pending reconciliation of the notifications

Speaker: NA
Text: received with the index, general prosecution action

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be taken. However, prosecutions will be

Speaker: NA
Text: launched in individual cases where default is con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidered to have been wilful. '

Speaker: NA
Text: Drugs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1502.)

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: the Minister for Health,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Is it a fact that Sedormid tablets are not

Speaker: NA
Text: available in New South Wales because of their

Speaker: NA
Text: side effects?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If so, what are ibe side effects of the drug?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Are there any substitutes for the drug? If

Speaker: NA
Text: so, what are the names of the substitutes?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Text: Th e answers to the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's questions are as follows-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Yes. Sedormid tablets have been withdrawn

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Australian market, having been declared

Speaker: NA
Text: Aliens. a prohibited import as the result of a recommen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dation by the Australian Drug Evaluation Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. It has been found that medication with

Speaker: NA
Text: Sedormid tablets can cause a serious blood con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition known as thrombocytopenia purpura, which

Speaker: NA
Text: is sometimes fatal.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Yes. Barbiturates, chloral hydrate, paralde-

Speaker: NA
Text: hyde, sodium or potassium bromide, glulethimide,

Speaker: NA
Text: bromvaletone, meprobamate, promethazine hydro-

Speaker: NA
Text: chloride, and phenothiazine derivatives are alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive drugs which may be prescribed in lieu oi

Speaker: NA
Text: Sedormid tablets.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Military Forces.

Text: The number of volunteers for the Regular Army,

Speaker: NA
Text: the number accepted and the number rejected, in

Speaker: NA
Text: each of the last five years, was-

Speaker: NA
Text: Dredging of Botany Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 1483.)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bosnian asked the Minister represand

Speaker: NA
Text: senting the Minister for Works, upon Bay.

Speaker: NA
Text: notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Has a claim been received from the Governextended

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of New South Wales for compensation for

Speaker: NA
Text: damage to the foreshores of Botany Bay due to the

Speaker: NA
Text: dredging of the Bay for the Kingsford-Smith

Speaker: NA
Text: port runway extension?

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. If so, what is the Department's attitude to

Speaker: NA
Text: the claim?

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Have more suitable locations farther off

Speaker: NA
Text: been chosen for further dredging for the NorthWallingford

Speaker: NA
Text: West Terminal site.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Freeth -Th e Minister for Works has

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied the following information-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The Department of Works has received a

Speaker: NA
Text: letter, dated 19th November 1965, from the Mari-

Speaker: NA
Text: time Services Board of New South Wales expressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the opinion that the dredging of the area of Botany

Speaker: NA
Text: Bay for the runway extension has contributed

Speaker: NA
Text: materially to the erosion of Lady Robinson's Beach

Speaker: NA
Text: in the vicinity of Cook Park, between Bestic and

Speaker: NA
Text: Rowley Streets. The Board has asked the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to undertake remedial work to the beach and

Speaker: NA
Text: has suggested discussions with our officers to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable a satisfactory solution to this problem to be

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved. These discussions took place on 7th

Speaker: NA
Text: Rejected* December 1965.

Speaker: NA
Text: 9,276 2. The Department has closely followed the

Speaker: NA
Text: 8,400 directions and advice of the Maritime Services

Speaker: NA
Text: 8,590 Board in regard to the area of the bay from which

Speaker: NA
Text: 7,674 the contractor has been permitted to remove sand.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some time ago the Board engaged Wallingford

Speaker: NA
Text: Hydraulics Research Station, Berkshire, England,

Speaker: NA
Text: to supply expert advice in relation to hydraulic

Speaker: NA
Text: surveys and studies to determine the possible

Speaker: NA
Text: influence of proposed State Government works on

Speaker: NA
Text: movements and wave reflections in Botany

Speaker: NA
Text: Following Commonwealth proposals for run-

Speaker: NA
Text: way extensions into Botany Bay the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: arranged with the Board that the studies be

Speaker: NA
Text: to include the effect of these Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth works and the associated dredging. A pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: liminary report received from the research station

Speaker: NA
Text: Airhas been discussed with the Maritime Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Board but no decision has been reached as to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent of the Commonwealth liability.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The Department is awaiting further advice

Speaker: NA
Text: shore through the Maritime Services Board from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hydraulics Research Station, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: investigating this matter also.
